CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY.

LICENSE TO LAY PIPE UNDER RIGHT-OF-WAY.

PERMISSION is hereby given by the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway Company (hereinafter called the "Company") to His Majesty The King in right of the Dominion of Canada represented herein by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs (hereinafter called the "Licensee") to lay one inch pipe under the Company's right-of-way at a point near Fort Fraser Station, British Columbia, as shown by the red line on the plan hereto annexed (which is hereby declared to be a part hereof), to be used only for the purpose of conveying water to Fraser Lake Indian School:

ON THE FOLLOWING TERMS, which the Licensee hereby accepts and agrees to perform and abide by:

1. The said pipe shall be of the Canadian Society of Civil Engineer's standard, properly fastened at the joints and the top of said pipe shall be below the frost line and not less than four feet below the base of rail.

2. All work in connection with the laying, maintaining, renewing and repairing of said pipe and the continued supervision of the same, shall be performed by, and all costs and expenses thereby incurred be borne and paid by the Licensee, but no
work at any time shall be done in any manner so as to obstruct, delay or in any way interfere with the operation of any of the trains or traffic of the Company or any other Railway Company using the said railway.

3. The Licensee shall at all times maintain the said pipe in good working order and condition and so that at no time shall any damage be caused to the property of the Company, or any of its tracks be obstructed or the usefulness or safety of the same for railway purposes be impaired or the full use and enjoyment as heretofore by the Company, or any other Railway Company using the said railway, be in any way interfered with.

4. Before any work of laying, renewing or repairing the said pipe is begun, the Licensee shall give to the Local Superintendent of the Company at least ninety six (96) hours' prior notice thereof in writing so as to enable the Company to appoint an inspector to see that the work is performed in such a manner as in all respects will comply with this License. The wages of such inspector shall not exceed eleven dollars ($11.00) per day, to be paid by the Licensee, such payment to cover both wages and expenses. PROVIDED that the Company may at any time at the cost of the Licensee repair said pipe, or any part thereof, without notice to the Licensee should the Company's superintending official deem such repairs necessary or expedient, and the Company will render a bill to the Licensee for the cost.
such work, based on reasonable rates to be fixed by the Company and the Licensee shall pay the same forthwith.

5. The Licensee shall not have any claim against the Company for loss or damage by whomsoever caused to the property of the Licensee, whether due to the negligence of the Company, its employees, agents or otherwise.

6. The Licensee shall indemnify and save harmless the Company of and from all damage or injury which may be caused to or sustained by the Company's roadbed, or any part thereof, or any of the rolling stock or other property of the Company, by reason of anything done or omitted to be done whether negligently or otherwise or in any manner based upon or arising out of or connected with this License and the Licensee shall indemnify and save harmless the Company from all claims, demands, actions, suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, arising out of, or connected with this License, or anything done or left undone or maintained in any manner hereunder and notwithstanding that the same may be caused by or attributable to the negligence of the Company, its servants or otherwise.

7. The Licensee shall pay to the Company for the privileges hereby given the sum of one dollar ($1.00) per annum and the said rental shall be due and payable in advance on the first day of November in each year during the continuance hereof.

8. This License may be cancelled at any time upon one month's notice in writing signed by any
superintending official of the Company being given to the Licensee. Upon the expiry of the notice period the Licensee shall disconnect the pipe and remove the same from the Company's property, and upon failure of the Licensee to do so forthwith the Company may remove said pipe at the cost of the Licensee.

9. Neither this License, nor any right or interest thereunder is subject to any assignment or sub-lease without the consent in writing of the Company.

10. Should any default be made by the Licensee in the payment of any money or the performance of any work or the fulfilment of any condition due hereunder the Company may cancel this License forthwith without notice and may disconnect said pipe or remove same from the right-of-way, and may collect the cost of such disconnection or removal from the Licensee.

DATED this 22nd day of October A.D.1923.

GRAND TRUNK PACIFIC RAILWAY COMPANY.

WITNESS to signature of Licensee:

Licensee.
Sir,

In connection with the new water system at the Fraser Lake Indian School and facilities for fighting fire I have been in consultation with the Principal, Rev. rather Coccola and we decided it was very desirable that at least two and preferably three hydrants should be installed on the outside of the building.

I am advised by Mr Skelton, the foreman in charge of the present work, that these could be very easily installed at the inspection joints already provided in the pipe line.

I may state that the boilers are fired with wood largely, and there has to be a large supply kept on hand and there is more or less danger of fire during the hot summer days from this source. Even a fire within the building might be more conveniently fought from the outside.

I would therefore urge the Department to favourably consider this suggestion and have instructions given to enable the hydrants to be installed.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Sir,

Referring again to your letter of Sept 19/23 No 163/1/5 I beg to report further progress in connection with the installation of the new water system at the Fraser Lake Indian School as follows:

The concrete slab has been laid in the pump house, the pumps installed and water was delivered at the school on the 20th of January. Work is now proceeding on the storage tank, the heavy framed timber support above concrete foundation is all completed and the outside housing of the tank is well under way. When the housing is completed the tank timbers (all on the ground) will be assembled and the connection made with the pipe line which is all completed to the tank site.

At the lake shore work is proceeding to connect the lake water with the seepage bed and reservoir. This has been the most difficult undertaking of the whole system but with the lake at its very lowest point success is now assured. The foreman advises me that he expects to have the iron pipe rolled into position within two weeks when an abundant supply of water will be available at any season of the year.

Trusting you will consider this progress satisfactory I have the honour to be, Sir,

your obedient servant

Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Sir:— I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of January 21st, No. 163-1-5 and in respect to certain Vouchers sent in for payment in connection with the water system being put in at the Fraser Lake Industrial School by R. Moncrieff, Contractor. I beg to submit herewith all the received accounts for Voucher No. 1026 submitted on December 15th, which I trust are satisfactory.

I am submitting also another Voucher No. 1056 with accounts all receipted. The Voucher mentioned in your letter, No. 1039 and amounting to $3335-22, receipted accts. will be sent forward in a few days as I have one account which I have not yet got a receipt for. As soon as this is received it will be forwarded on. However I am of the opinion that it will be perfectly satisfactory and perfectly in order to forward a cheque to Mr. Moncrieff covering this Voucher as I can assure you that everything is in order.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

WJMOA/L.
Sir:

I beg to inclose herewith documents and plan received from the Canadian National Railway Superintendent at Prince Rupert these being permission to lay a pipe under the Canadian National Railway track on the No. 4 Indian reserve at the Indian School near Fraser Lake. I trust that these will all be found satisfactory and in order.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

WJMcA/L.

FIRST AID SERVICE REGULATIONS

Pursuant to the "Workmen's Compensation Act," the Workmen's Compensation Board hereby makes the following First Aid requirements, the same to take effect on and after the 18th day of September, 1922.

(1) Every employer having more than fifty and less than two hundred workmen shall provide and maintain at the place of employment, or at each place of employment if he has more than one, a First Aid kit or box containing the following supplies, with such additional quantities as may be reasonably necessary to provide First Aid to injured workmen, and same shall be available during all working hours, without cost to them. The said kit or box shall be in charge of some suitable person.

A Standard First Aid Manual.

CANADA
February 19th, 1924.

Dear Sir,

I have to thank you for your very kind letter of the 14th instant expressing your appreciation of the work done by this Department in connection with the Fraser Lake Industrial school. I am very pleased that the water system promises to be so satisfactory. I shall keep in mind your requirements in regard to accommodation for stock, grain products, and for the housing of farm employees.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. N. Coccola,
Industrial School,
Fraser Lake, B.C.
Dear Mr. Scott:

Seldom if ever has it been my good fortune to write a letter which affords me such real pleasure, as does this occasion. It is therefore with a feeling of distinction, that I choose this opportunity to convey my sentiments towards you in particular and the Department of which you are the efficient head in general.

Under your able administration you have given a large amount of thought to this Institution of which I am the local incumbent and just at present we are once again experiencing the exemplification of your untold consideration for our Indian children at Fraser lake in the way of the up-to-date water system now installed.

As you are aware work started last fall under the management of Mr. Moncrief, who substituted to one Mr. R. Skelton and I wish to say that I do not think that the work could have been put in better hands. He Mr. Skelton was assisted by Indians with two exceptions and the work was rushed at such a rate, that on the declining days of last month water at the great joy was pumped direct from the lake into the main building.

The equipment on the lake shore is efficient in every way while the house is most picturesque. The water filtering through a sand and gravel bed and coming from three hundred feet from water edge gives an abundant supply and is of the very best.

The tank and tower on the hill is being rushed to completion and
we confidently expect that the water supply will be taken from it with the next few weeks.

On the completion of the work I doubt if any place in this fair Dominion can be found a water system superior to the one which your Department is now installing for this Institution.

While we are most grateful for all that you have done and are doing I am ever mindful, as I am certain you are, of the pressing needs of a barn and proper accommodations for the working men for the coming summer.

Last year we cut sufficient fodder to feed 22 head of cattle and five horses, besides thrashing some 575 bushels of grain, all of which had to be placed in a stack as we had no barn room.

You will readily see how badly we need this building and in such a time as to take of the fall harvest. This year our harvest will be much larger as a greater portion of the farm will be under cultivation. I would earnestly pray you to have the barn and employees quarters erected in proper season.

Once again asking you to accept my sincere appreciation to which I have the honor as well as the pleasure to include each and every ward beneath our roof.

I am very gratefully yours,

H. Coccola

Sir:

I beg to advise you of the following: When I was up at the Industrial School the other day it was pointed out to me that the guttering on the edge of the roof of the building becomes clogged with snow and ice; the pipes running from various portions of the gutter become filled with ice and then the water overflows running down the pipes and freezing to the brick walls. There was quite a large amount of ice accumulated around each of the overflow pipes when I was there. I called Mr. Skelton in consultation in the matter and we came to the conclusion that if this condition was allowed to occur that in another year or two the portions of the brick walls would become very much deteriorated and it was decided to recommend to the Department that the whole of the guttering around the roof and overflow pipes be entirely removed. Perhaps the architects of the Department might know of some better solution of the trouble and if so it should be applied before another winter comes or the wall will certainly be injured. Discoloration is now in evidence where the ice thaws and breaks away. I would be glad if the Department would take this matter into consideration and issue instructions to remove the trouble before another winter.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, March 21, 1924.

Memorandum: Mr. Scott.

The Department was advised by Indian Agent McAllan of Fort Fraser, that it is very desirable that the Fraser Lake Industrial School be provided with reliable fire protection.

After consulting with the Principal of the School it was considered that the installation of three water hydrants with 200' of hose would be sufficient to provide adequate protection against fire. The cost of this apparatus and its installation would amount to approximately $800. The apparatus would be installed on the outside of the building, and, in case of fire, would be very useful as fire is sometimes more conveniently fought from the outside of the building than the inside.

Providing funds are available I beg to recommend that this request be given favourable consideration.

[Signature]

Referring to the second last paragraph in your letter of the 7th inst No 163/1/5 requirements of barn would be accommodation for 24 head of cattle and six horses. A harness room and feed room for the horse stable. A silo of about 75 tons capacity. Loft to be as roomy as possible for hay and grain crop storage and fitted with hay fork and traveller. May 16 1924

Sir,

Answering your letter of the 7th inst No 163/1/5 I beg to state that I have just returned from a consultation with the Rev Father Coccola, Principal of the Fraser Lake Residential School, in which the various matters mentioned in your letter were discussed.

With reference to the plumbing fixtures, also cupboards, tables etc it is the Principals desire that these installations should have priority over the erection of a combined carpenter and blacksmith shop and I so recommend, but the erection of the latter should not long be delayed as the Indian parents are demanding more mechanical and technical instruction for the boys and in my opinion they are right.

Re the erection of a barn—the purchase of the various materials and supervision could be jointly undertaken by the Principal and myself provided we could engage the services of a competent and reliable foreman. In this connection I have spoken to Mr Rupert Skelton who has just completed the new water system under Mr Moncrieff. He is waiting for a few days to install the hydrants and outside fire protection system authorised by Department but this work will only keep him a very short time. If the Dept. could wire me to start preliminary work I could retain him—for instance, it would be necessary to connect the present water system with the barn for which nearly 700 ft of 2 inch galvanized pipe sunk 5 ft in the ground would be necessary. Perhaps foundation work could be started while plans for superstructure were being prepared. Kindly wire me in this matter as competent men are difficult to get and being absent so much from the work I would not care to be responsible for its proper fulfillment unless I had confidence in the man in charge. With an efficient foreman the work could be satisfactorily handled on a day labour basis.

Barn items are made the subject of a separate letter.

I have the honour to be Sir,

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, June 28, 1924.

Sir:

With reference to the barn required for the Fraser Lake school, I beg to advise you that plans and specifications are being prepared and tenders will be invited.

I would ask you to please advise me if there are contractors at Fort Fraser, who would submit a tender for this barn. I would also be glad to have your recommendation as to where advertisements should be placed when inviting tenders.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. J. McAllan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Fraser, B.C.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of March 11th, 1924, No. 163-1-5, granting authority to purchase certain building material for an ice house and wood shed at the Fraser Lake Industrial School. I beg to state that when the authority was received the Principal had already commenced work and had purchased considerable material, as it was necessary to have the building ready to receive the ice before the thaw took place. I therefore decided to allow the Principal to purchase the rest of the material required for the building. Some I think had been paid for and it was decided that the best plan would be to allow him to pay for the whole thing and send in accounts covering the $800.00 allowed by the Department for material for the building. The whole cost of the material amounted to much over $1000.00. The whole cost of the building including labour is well over $2000.00.

One of the accounts submitted contains an item for interest. Evidently Father Coccolo had not paid the bill within the time limit. I am instructed by the Principal to say that if it is contrary to the practice of the Department to pay interest on an overdue account he is quite willing that the Department should deduct this item of interest from the account. Trusting the Department will favourably consider this account even although the instructions in your letter were not; for reasons already stated carried out.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Indian Agent.

Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa.

WJMcA/L.
INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL

Fraser Lake, B.C.

May 16th, 1924

W.J. McAllan Indian Agent,
Fort Fraser, B.C.

Re Ice or Meat house, Wood shed combined with an Upstairs.

Dear Sir:

The building marginally quoted for which the Department allowed an expenditure of $800.00 for the material is touching completion.

The construction 20 x 52 stands on cement post four feet in the ground that is below frost, beautifully painted and entirely in harmony with other buildings.

The total cost of the building is estimated at $2200.00.

The Meat house 20 x 22 has three ply of lumber with space of 3 inches and tarred paper between. The Ice room is lined with galvanized iron on each side of the ice space of 30 tons capacity.

The Meat room is 8 x 10 with walls 9 feet high with a ventilator in the ceiling; the doors are air tight and we hope that the difficulty we had in past summers to keep meat for days is over.

The Wood shed is 20 x 30 with an Upstairs which could be used for carpenter shop or for bed room for the employees during the summer months, to that purpose we put in it a brick chimney. The steps leading to the entrance of the said upstairs are on the outside.

I had to employ a skilful mechanic besides the foreman and the boys to assure complete satisfaction to the Department and myself.

Enclosed find bills for materials of the construction.

Amount $800.18.

Yours Sincerely,

L.M. Coccollo
Principal.
Office of the Stuart Lake Indian Agency,

Dear Sir,

Letters from your Department have in every case lead me to believe that the barn would be started in late spring or early summer. It is now the mid-July and nothing is done as yet.

I need not to draw your attention to the imperative necessity of this building, the absence of which greatly impedes the development of this Institution.

The majority of our children are young and milk is a daily necessity for them but how to supply them with it when we have accommodation for only six cows, the rest of the stock having to winter outside for the seven months of cold weather in this northern climate.

Owing to early frosts cement work should be completed by mid-September to insure good and lasting work.

Pardon me for bringing your attention to this urgent subject.

Referring to your letter of Sept 17 No 163-1-5 in connection with the erection of a barn at the Fraser Lake Residential School it would appear to me from the plans that provision has not been made for the draining and flushing of the gutters in either the horse or cattle stables. Sir

I have inspected the Septic Tank, and find it in first class condition, but an improvement can be made at the end of the Outlet Pipe.

Following is a description in detail.

The first Tank contains 6 ft of water covered with about 3 inches of seam, which is in a state of fermentation, there is about 3 inches of soft sediment at the bottom.

The second portion of the Tank carries 3 ft 4 in. of water, and is free of seam and sediment, the water level is the same in both sections of the Tank, but the depth of the tanks is not equal. The water leaves the outlet pipe at the same rate at which the water enters the Tank and the height of water does not vary.

The Tank is placed at the top of a bank, being well protected from frost. The Outlet Pipe empties about 20 feet below the Tank the end being placed in a bed of natural gravel. Rocks were laid at the end of the pipe and this allows some water to come to the surface where it runs on top about 10 feet before soaking in the ground again, this allow a bad smell to pass off. The greater portion of the water soaks through the gravel to a lower level, this water is perfectly filtered and free from smell.

I would suggest that three short trenches should be dug in the gravel and filled in loose, taking the form of a broad arrow. The gravel at the end of the pipe should be covered with a layer of clay tamped down to prevent the water coming to the surface. Clay for this purpose is available within a few yards of the job. Should this method be followed the water would be filtered and should be perfectly free from smell.

The natural lay of the ground with a deep layer of gravel gives an opportunity to make a first class filter bed at a very low cost, and makes it possible to dispose of sewerage water for a number of years with an entire absence of smell.

I would suggest that this information be forwarded to the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

(Signed) Yours respectfully,

H. Allen
Engineer.

Memorandum

Dr. Scott,

There is no water in the barn at the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School and the stock must cross fields under cultivation to secure a drink. A proper water supply was provided two years ago for this school, but the barn has never been connected up. I wish to recommend that water be placed in the barn, on a day labour basis, under the supervision of the Indian agent. The cost is estimated at $700.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir,

I have received a letter from Rev. Father [Name], Principal of the Fraser Lake Residential School which I quote in full as follows:

Re Water To Barn:
Having reference to the marginal noted, I take this occasion once again to place before you for your consideration the matter of water in the stable. The necessity of having water in the barn is now evident as the snow is now leaving and the stock must cross the road on their way to water which are hay lands and I am certain that you will readily perceive the destruction they are doing, which could be avoided by bringing the water into the barn. Undoubtedly it is the intention of the Department to do this at some time, if so, why not at once, which would mean considerable less destruction and a large amount of unnecessary work.

To this end I am making the liberty to attach an estimate of cost of labour and material and would add that I am in a position to superintend this work if the Department so desires.

I would suggest that a two inch pipe be run from the water tank to a point some thirty feet from the barn, at said point, place a hydrant for fire protection, then reduce to one inch to a point six feet inside the barn underground, then carry a pipe to ceiling thence to water troughs, one for the cows and one for the horses, thus arranged to drain as to prevent freezing. A one inch branch pipe could be taken from the two inch pipe to supply the engineer's offices and other buildings which may be erected in the future.

Trusting that you will bring this matter to the attention of the Department at once, "I am,

Yours truly,
N. Coccolo,
Principal.

I would strongly recommend that the Department undertake this work as it is really very necessary if the hay lands are to be protected.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

We trashed last fall some twelve tons of grain. Having no granary we stored it in a corner of the barn, the steam from the stock caused the grain to germinate. You see at once by that the imposing necessity of a granary.

Sir:

With reference to your communication of the 23rd ult. to the Rev. Father Coccolo, Principal of the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School, File No.163-1-5 copy of which I have received I beg to inform you that I have gone into the matters mentioned in your letter with the Rev. Principal and beg to advise as follows:

In going over the most important requirements of the Fraser Lake School this year I find that a set of new batteries for the lighting plant is the outstanding one. The present batteries which were put in when the school was built have been in constant use for the last five years, apparently these batteries were just large enough to supply the needs of the school alone without taking in the barn or any of the other out buildings, in fact Mr. Allen the Engineer informed me that the batteries have been carrying a maximum load and that when asked to do that their life is considerably shortened. The battery question was brought to my attention last fall by the Principal and after discussing the matter with him and the Engineer we thought that they would last for at least another year, however they have been getting worse during the winter until now they are far from satisfactory and the light in the school is anything but good. To my mind the batteries at present in use are too small and for that matter were too small right from the beginning except for the main building but when we consider that the barn is not lighted by electricity owing to the fact that the batteries are not strong enough to carry the additional load we can readily see how the fire risk is increased by using oil lamps around hay and straw, in fact during my first visit to the school after my appointment as Indian Agent I mentioned the fact of the barn not being lighted by electricity to Father Coccolo and asked him why it was so which he replied that his batteries could not supply any more lights than were being used in the School Building. I understand that a set of batteries suitable for a plant such as the Fraser Lake Indian School will cost in the neighborhood of $2000-00. This amount may seem large but a new set of batteries will be necessary before next fall and I think it wise to put in a set that
will carry the full load and supply the barn and other out buildings as well, rather than purchasing a set the same size as in use now for it will only mean a repetition of the trouble in another few years as well as not giving power enough to light the barn etc.

The next item in importance is the completion of the Carpenter and Blacksmith Shop started last year and still in an unfinished condition. The amount necessary for this work will be approximately $800-00.

Next in importance is a granary with root cellar underneath. I saw the plans of the proposed granary as submitted by Father Coccollo to the Department and think it a good one and one that should meet with the approval of the Department. No doubt you are aware that a good root cellar is a very important item in an institution such as the Fraser Lake School, especially in a climate such as the one we have in this district. The cost of this granary and root cellar will be in the neighborhood of $1000-00.

The next item of importance is the erection of a silo and one large enough to fill the want will cost around $400-00 including the cement foundation.

The erection of a hog pen is next in importance and one large enough to house six brood sows with litters and a boar with a feed room at the end should be something along the plan adopted. No estimate on this work has been given.

The completion of the cow shed which was started by Father Coccollo last fall is next in line. This building is close to the barn and is used for young and dry stock to feed and stay in during the winter with free access to water and pasture. To complete this building will cost about $500-00.

In conclusion I would strongly recommend that the above items be granted in the order they are given.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Lejac, B.C.

Sir:

On receipt of your letter of the 23rd ult. File No. I68-I-5, we discussed with our Indian Agent Mr. Moore the most important needs of our Institution.

First. We found the necessity of renewing the battery for the lighting plant.

Last year we noticed that the lights were dim but we hoped to overcome the trouble by overhauling the cells. In doing it we found them to contain a thick sediment and the disintegration of the Positive plates to be too far advanced to allow repair. At present the light is very poor.

This battery when first installed was to supply light for the main building the only one standing then, but when the Laundry and the Chapel were built it became too small for the number of lights in service and was overtaxed.

Now as the light is to be extended to the barn and workshop and other outside buildings the size of the battery has to be increased also. A battery of 320 Ampere Hours would be more economical to operate and should have longer life.

Our engine is IO H.P. Special Electric and our generator is 5 Kilowatt at 125 Volts. The switch board has two Amperage Rheostats and it is so arranged that we could charge the large battery successfully to supply light for Barn and other buildings all at the cost of about $2000.00.

I suggest that the firm who is to install the new battery should send a competent man electrician and guarantee the work.

Second. The next improvement of importance would be a Granary with Root cellar underneath as per plan sent for about $900.00.

Third. Then the completion of the workshops for about $750.00.

Fourth. A hogpen to cost about $1000.00.

Fifth. And last the completion of the cowshed which I began to build last Fall to be finished as to be in harmony with the other buildings with paint and shingle roof, it would cost $600.00.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

N. Coccola

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the 5th inst., File No. 163-1-5 which refers to the electric light battery at the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School and in reply I beg to advise as follows:

There is no mark on the batteries which would indicate the make but I have been informed that they were supplied by the Fairbanks Morse Company of Vancouver to the Contractor who built the School and who is alleged to be the cause of the batteries spoiling so soon. The battery consists of 50 cells, 240 amp. hr. The positive and negative plates as well as the separators are all spoiled, I have been thus informed by Mr. Allan the Engineer. As explained in my letter of March 8th last to the Department, I am satisfied that the batteries at present in use at the School are too small even though they were in first class condition, because they are and have been carrying the maximum load which has a bad effect on any battery and tends to shorten its days of usefulness to a considerable extent. The Rev. Principal has informed me that he has been in communication with an Electrician called Mr. Alex Nash of Prince George on the matter and Mr. Nash has guaranteed to give the Principal satisfaction should he be allowed to install a new set of batteries. It seems desirable that this man should, if at all possible, get the work as he is in business locally and can give better service on that account. I would be pleased if the Department would take this matter into consideration at the earliest possible date and advise what action they wish to take.

Regarding the cost and necessity of providing a granary and root cellar as more important to the satisfactory conduct of the School than the completion of the Work Shop, I beg to inform you that I went into this matter with the Principal and he is still of the opinion that the granary and root cellar should be attended to first. I can easily see the Principal's point in this case as he is naturally looking to the most economical way of operating the school, if the granary and root cellar is completed this summer it means that the Principal will have a place to store...
Sir,

his grain, roots and vegetables for winter consumption, while on the other hand if it is not completed he will have to do the same as he has been doing, viz., buy these commodities wherever he can and at whatever price offered.

On the other hand, completing the Carpenter Shop is just as vital, from the point of view of satisfactory manual training to the boys at the School. As you know this building was started last year and partially completed and while admitting the necessity of the granary and root cellar, I am still of the opinion that the Department should try and finish one job before starting another. So far as the Principal and myself agreeing on which of these buildings should be completed this year I am afraid it cannot be done, for as I have already explained, the Principal is looking at it from one angle and I from another. I am just as anxious as the Principal is to see the granary and root cellar completed but in fairness to the Department and the pupils I think that as the Carpenter Shop was considered to be of first importance last year it should still keep its place.

If the Department could see its way clear to complete both these buildings this year it would be filling a long felt want in the successful operation of the Institution as both buildings are of equal importance depending on which view point one wishes to take.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

When I paid my last visit to Fraser Lake School last fall, the Reverend Principal, Father Coccola pointed out to me that the cold storage building was not working very satisfactorily. It is, of course, important that this storage plant works well, as this particular school has to keep considerable quantities of stores on hand at one time, owing to their not being able to purchase locally. The following is an extract from a letter from the Reverend Principal regarding the installation of a refrigerator plant at the school:

"Knowing as you do the necessity of a refrigerator plant I wrote to Edmonton and Vancouver for plans. After much correspondence the Linde Co., of Vancouver are willing to install a plant for $1465.00, ourselves to supply the three horse power engine necessary to run it and which we have on hand. The building to be used will be our present meat house with some modifications, but that can be done by our carpenter instructor, and the boys. The advantage of a plant at once is to save putting up ice which costs us $300. every year. If the Department has not the funds available at present to go ahead with this work, I would like authority to do the work with my own funds and then be reimbursed by the Department as soon as the new appropriation is available."

Mr. Moore, Indian Agent, in commenting upon this matter states that he can appreciate the position that the Principal is in, and if there is any possible way that this addition can be made with the present equipment of the school, he would certainly recommend that it be done. Mr. Moore states that when he submitted the estimates for his Agency for 1927-28 to Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn, he included the sum of $1400.00 for a plant of this nature. He stated that if the Department would agree to this disbursement and give the Reverend Principal reasonable assurance that the item in question would be available later on, that the job be commenced right away.

As far as I am concerned, I certainly think that the installation of a refrigerator plant at the school would be a great improvement, and I should certainly like to see it done some time or other. However, I do not wish any of these estimates to upset the possibility of the work commencing on the Lytton School, or the final wing of the Kamloops School. Having in view the fact that the Reverend Principal states that he would save $300.00 every year, some agreement might be made whereby the school, having in view the fact that they are saving this money, contribute something towards the cost, apart from the fact that they are willing to contribute the work, and of course, the cost of running the engine. However, it is not a very large sum in question, and possibly the Department might see fit to pass this estimate.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Yours Truly,

Geo. S. Pragnell
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

My attention has been drawn to the fact that there is some faulty construction at Fraser Lake School, that is causing considerable trouble and annoyance as well as destruction every Spring there.

It appears that immediately behind the eaves troughs, there are certain boards missing that should be there. On account of the thawing and freezing, every Spring the eaves troughs fill up and then back up under the eaves and down inside the walls, doing considerable damage to plaster and everything else. It was not noticed that these boards were missing until one of the eaves troughs was removed for some purpose or other.

Mr. Agent Moore informs me that he has asked for an estimate and finds that it will run between $250.00 and $300.00 to have it done. He states that he included this expenditure in his estimates which he sent to Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn last September. He has heard nothing further in the matter and he wants to avoid the recurrence of the flooding and damage to the kalsomine and plaster which occurred last Spring, by dealing with the matter immediately. I consider the matter urgent and should be done straight away, and I shall be much obliged therefore, if you see fit, if you would authorize this. I think it would be best if you would communicate with Mr. Moore direct, probably by wire, as Spring is coming and it should be done before a thaw occurs.

I would have written you before upon the matter, but I have been laid up for the last week, sick with Flu, and could not, therefore, deal with the matter.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

A few weeks ago, Mr. Inspector Pragnell strongly recommended a refrigerator plant at the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School. The Rev. Principal wishes to proceed with the installation of an ammonia freezer, at a cost of approximately $1700. The plant, itself, is worth $1465; doors, etc., for the cold storage room, approximately $250. The Principal hopes that the scheme will effect a saving of about $300 a year in the matter of ice supply. Mr. Orr recommends the scheme.

$1600 is available for improvements at this school this year. It is the intention to erect a small hogpen, a silo and a cow shed. In a letter dated the 24th ultimo, the Rev. Principal states that the refrigerator plant is the most urgent of all their requirements. In view of these recommendations, I have to suggest that the Rev. Principal be informed that the Department will give a grant of $1600 if he meets the entire cost and forwards to us receipted accounts. He would be given to understand that the construction of the small outbuildings cannot go forward this year.

Memorandum,

Hon. Mr. Neighen,

I had an interview the other day with Colonel C. W. Peck, V.C., M.P., on the subject of erecting a building for the boarding school at Stuart Lake. The erection of a residential school for these Indians was promised them during a visit which they made to Ottawa in the year 1906. The Department of Fisheries had been having a great deal of trouble with them, on account of their methods of taking fish, and a promise and an arrangement was finally arrived at, and one of the items in the understanding or agreement was the provision of this residential school. In the first place we postponed it until the Grand Trunk Pacific should be completed, shortly after the war broke out, and we made that an excuse for a further postponement. Now Bishop Bunoz, the Roman Catholic Bishop of that diocese, is insistent that we should put up the school at once, and, by so doing, implement our promise to the Indians.

Colonel Peck is anxious to be able to send a favourable reply to the Bishop, who has communicated with him. I am in correspondence with the Indian Agent of the district on the subject of the proper location of the school, and the cost of materials, etc., and will submit a further report.

I would beg to recall our conversation of a short time ago, when you decided to recommend provision of funds for four new residential schools, one each for the
four denominations interested in Indian education. The Roman Catholic school was to be erected on the Peigan reserve, Southern Alberta. In consideration of the definite promise that has been made, it might be held that we should erect the Stuart Lake school first, although the conditions at the Peigan reserve are almost insupportable. The building of a school in this remote district is sure to be a heavy expense, but the Bishop is now very urgent about it, and I think it would be as well if you were to allow me to include an item in the Estimates for this school as well as $20,000.00 or $30,000.00, with which we might make a start and put in the foundation this summer.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Honourable Mr. Neighen,

I beg to report that it was owing to your direction that tenders were asked for the erection of a boarding school building for the Indians of Stuart Lake, in the Babine agency, B.C.

I attach hereto a report from the Architect on the tenders received. The lowest is that of R. Moncrieff, of Vancouver.

The Architect makes the recommendation that the building should be finished in brick veneer, which would make the cost $174,400.00. Our estimated cost of the building was $175,000.00.

In submitting this matter for your consideration, I would make the following remarks:

This school was promised to the Indians in 1906; on their agreeing to do away with aboriginal methods of fishing which had brought them into collision with the fisheries overseers. The erection of the building was postponed from time to time for two main reasons: first, it was decided to wait until the Grand Trunk Pacific was built, and second, to wait until the war was over. The obstacle which now may be considered to lie in the way of the fulfilment of the promise is the excessive cost at the present time.

The proposed building is shorn of all luxuries and is completely economical. All that is provided in the Estimates is $80,000, and the vote will not bear any additional charge for this building. It will, therefore, be necessary to
have a supplementary appropriation of $95,000.00.

As it would be a disappointment to the ecclesiastical authorities who have been conducting the school for some years in temporary quarters if the work is not gone on with, I would ask for your best consideration. I may suggest that perhaps under all the circumstances, the best plan would be to submit the tenders with a full memorandum to His Excellency in Council, recommending the acceptance of the tender and the provision of the necessary amount.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Neishen -

Stuart Lake Roman Catholic Boarding school building.

Plans and specifications for the above building are now ready and I have a telegram from Col. Peck, M.P., asking whether we have advertised for tenders. Col. Peck is very much interested in the erection of this school and he and Bishop Tunoz expect that we will advertise for tenders immediately. Before doing so I wish to say that we have prepared plans for a building to accommodate 150 pupils. Due economy has been shown and the construction is in no way extravagant or beyond our needs for that number of pupils.

This school is to be erected on an Indian reserve on the south side of Fraser Lake, midway between the stations of Fraser Lake and Encomb, B.C. Our architect estimates the cost of the building as it stands at not less than $149,000.00. In my memorandum on the estimates, submitted on the request of Sir Henry Drayton that we should cut them down, I mentioned that we had simply asked for the same amount as last year and of this amount I had allotted $80,000.00 for the building at Stuart Lake. I do not think it proper even to advertise without letting you know the situation. If we advertise and find that our estimate is correct we will have to decide to provide for the difference before letting the contract.

Proposal and Specification

To Industrial School,
Dejac, B.C.

We propose to supply, crate where necessary, and deliver
Refrigeration Plant on the "Linde System,"
consisting of the following principal parts:

One (1) vertical twin ammonia compressor,
One (1) double pipe ammonia condenser,
One (1) liquid ammonia receiver,
One (1) oil trap,
Pipe coils and valves,
Congealing tanks,
Mains,
Ammonia,
Delivery and erection.

All in accordance with detailed Specifications given hereinafter.

Page 1.
AMMONIA COMPRESSOR
(Vertical Enclosed Linde Type)

To be supplied of our vertical enclosed self-oiling type having one single acting cylinders.

Cooling Power—The compressor when working in connection with condenser and refrigerator of equal capacity, has a cooling power equal to one refrigerating tons per day, when operating at 200 revolutions per minute, and in accordance with the standards of the American Society of Refrigerating Engineers.

Construction—Of this compressor is such that the connecting rods as well as the main bearings are enclosed in the hollow base of the compressor, but easy of access by removing the front cover of the base. The cylinders being cast separately are securely and accurately bolted to the compressor base, therefore can be easily removed and replaced.

Cylinders—To be water-jacketted, each cylinder to have a diameter of 3½ inches and a stroke of 4 inches.

Safety Heads—Each cylinder to be supplied with a safety head so that in case any foreign matter, or a rush of liquid should enter the cylinders, the safety heads will lift, thereby preventing as far as possible any damage.

Valves (patents pending)—Are so constructed that they can be readily withdrawn and examined by removing the cylinder covers. The valves are guaranteed to work mechanically silent.

Pistons—To be supplied of our double trunk construction, accurately turned and fitted with metallic rings.

Connecting Rods—To be supplied of steel with anti-friction metal bearings. The construction to be such that both bearings can be easily adjusted after removing the compressor base cover.

Crankshaft—To be made of steel and to pass through a stuffing box on the compressor base.

Flywheel—To be supplied turned and faced suitable for belt drive and to be 24 inches in diameter by 4 inches face, and to weigh about 200 pounds.

Lubrication—The compressor base is made hollow and filled with a special nonfreezing oil so that the main bearings and connecting rods are running in oil. The base cover is fitted with an oil gauge.

Oil Trap—One to be supplied by us.

Scale Trap—One to be supplied by us.

Relief Valve—One to be supplied of the automatic safety type to prevent damage in case of excessive pressure due to failure of water supply, etc.

Packing—Compressor gland to be provided with flexible, semi-metallic packing.
AMMONIA CONDENSER

(Double Pipe)

To be of our latest Double Pipe Type, and to consist of one section, each section to contain two double pipes about 12 feet long over all.

Construction—The Construction of this double pipe condenser is that a 1\(\frac{1}{4}\) inch water pipe is placed inside of a special 2 inch lapwelded ammonia pipe. The water for condensing purposes passes upwards through the 1\(\frac{1}{4}\) inch pipe and the ammonia gas to be condensed passes downward between the outside surface of the 1\(\frac{1}{4}\) inch and the inside of the 2 inch pipes. On account of the gas and the cooling water travelling in opposite directions and on account of the small space between the two pipes, the ammonia gas is cooled and liquified quickly.

The 2 inch ammonia pipes are fitted with special ammonia flanges screwed thereon and bolted at each end to special semi-steel flanged return headers and fitted with lead gaskets, thereby securing a tight joint. The 1\(\frac{1}{4}\) inch water pipes are fitted at each end with unions and connected to return bends.

Where more than one section of condenser is supplied the different sections will be connected at top and bottom by special headers and each section to have a valve on the inlet and outlet, so that each section can be shut off and disconnected from the main system either for inspection or repairs without interfering with the working of the remaining sections.

Stands—Of heavy construction are supplied by us.

Liquid Ammonia Receiver—One to be supplied about 6 feet long by 6 inches in diameter and to be of suitable construction. The receiver to be supplied with inlet, outlet, and drain valves, and to have suitable stands on which to rest.

Receiver will be fitted with safety valve and connections.
Large Cooler

We will supply the following:

Approximately 192 feet of 1½" ammonia coils with stands,
One expansion valve,
One globe valve,
One 16 gauge galvanized condensing tank about 9' long,
by 2' wide by 3' deep.

Small Cooler

Approximately 96 feet of 1½" ammonia coils with stands,
One expansion valve,
One globe valve,
One 16 gauge galvanized condensing tank about 9' long,
by 1½" wide by 2' deep.

This allows each room to be operated singly or together as required.

Exclusions.

It is understood that you will supply the following:

Cartage on equipment from Railway to Industrial School,
Board and room for our Engineer,
Foundations for machinery,
Water and drain connections,
Salt for condensing tanks.
Ammonia Connections—Sufficient ammonia connections to be supplied to connect the various parts of the plant. It is understood that the plant is to be arranged with the various parts adjacent to each other.

These connections to consist of Pipe Mains, Valves, Flanges, Bolts, Nuts and Gaskets, also necessary Bends and Tees. Where possible all mains will be cut and flanged in our shops to facilitate erection. All ammonia pipes under two inches diameter to be extra heavy.

Gauges—Consisting of one high and one low pressure gauges to be supplied by us, mounted on suitable gauge board.

Spanners—To suit each size of nut on the machine to be supplied by us.

Testing—For testing the various parts of the machinery in connection with this plant to be supplied by us.

Ammonia and Calcium—The first charge necessary for the testing and starting of the plant to be supplied by us. If the ammonia is supplied by us the cylinders remain our property and to be returned to us immediately after plant is erected, otherwise must be paid for by the purchaser within 30 days after the erection is completed.

Drawings—Showing the general arrangement of the plant and of the pipe connections between the various parts to be provided free of charge. Sufficient details are to be given in the drawings to enable the work to be erected. Instructions for starting and working the plant to be supplied by us.

Testing—All parts of the plant will be thoroughly tested by hydraulic or air pressure in our shops before delivery, and if the plant is erected by us, same will be tested after erection by air pressure to assure that all joints are tight and properly made before charging with ammonia.

Delivery—The plant will be delivered F. O. B. our Works freight paid to Lejac, B.C., in four weeks from date of order, unless delayed by causes over which we have no control such as Fires, Acts of God, Riots, Strikes, Carriers delay or similar commotions of any kind.
Erection—We to supply one engineer to erect our machinery and plant according to our specification and drawings and we will supply all labour necessary for the assistance of our engineer.

After the erection is completed and the plant started, our engineer will instruct your engineer how to operate the plant.

It is advisable that your engineer or employee who is to run the plant, should assist our engineer in the erection of our machinery so that he becomes thoroughly acquainted with the construction and arrangement of the whole plant.

It is Understood—and agreed that you are to furnish light for our men to work by, to supply necessary timber and scaffolding needed for the erection, and also provide our engineer with suitable places wherein to work and keep the machinery, tools and fittings free from damage.

Responsibility—Our engineers are supplied by us for the erection of our machinery and plant only; if our engineers do other work than specified herein, either on the Purchaser's request or otherwise, it is distinctly understood and agreed that we are not responsible or liable for such work.

Delays—After our engineers have started with the erection and they are delayed by the Purchaser in not having completed the work he has to supply under this contract, it is understood and agreed that for any such delay the Purchaser has to pay us the engineer's wages and all expenses we are put to thereby.

Damages—If while our engineers are erecting our machinery, some part or parts get broken, or if after same has been erected either by ourselves or by the purchaser, and during testing or running any part or parts of our plant are found defective, we shall use our utmost endeavour to replace such part or parts as quickly as possible. It is, however, distinctly understood and agreed that we are not liable for any damage whatsoever resulting from such broken or defective part or parts beyond replacing same free of cost to you.
Testing—Immediately after our engineers have erected and started the plant, they will operate our machinery for one week to show that the plant fulfils our guarantee.

If, after this test is made, or if the erection is done by you, you are unable to obtain the guaranteed results, and if we are informed of this by you by registered letter to our Head Office in Montreal within 60 days after completion of the erection of the plant we agree to have our engineer or engineers make a further test, and should he or they not succeed in demonstrating the full guarantee of the plant, we agree to supply a larger plant which will do the guaranteed work without additional cost to you. It is, however, distinctly understood and agreed upon, that our entire liability is limited to the enlarging of our plant.

If our engineer, or engineers, should show that the plant is capable of accomplishing the guaranteed work under the conditions as stated herein, then you agree to pay to us, his or their salary and expenses in connection with such tests and accept the plant.

It is further understood and agreed upon, that the termination of the above mentioned 60 days constitutes your acceptance of the plant as being in accordance with our guarantee.

Taxation—All local or provincial taxes liable to be levied on outside Companies or their employees to be paid by the purchaser.

Verbal Understanding—It is distinctly understood and agreed that outside of what is stated in this Proposal and Specification there is no verbal understanding of any kind whatsoever.

Proposal and Specification—It is understood that the sizes of the different parts of the apparatus as specified herein may be changed by us if we consider it advisable to do so for the efficient working of the plant or to suit prevailing conditions.

Prices—Prices submitted are for immediate acceptance.

Exclusions—This offer is exclusive of all masons', bricklayers', excavators' and carpenters' work other than specified. Cutting away and making good to walls, ceilings, doors or partitions through which our pipes have to pass. Fire Insurance—As soon as the whole or any portion of the above plant is delivered on your premises, you to insure same (with loss payable to us) against loss or damage by fire, in a first class Insurance Company, for the total amount as per contract price, and to keep it fully insured until the full amount for the plant has been paid to us in cash. It is understood that all damage or destruction occasioned directly or indirectly by fires, etc., to the plant or any portion of it, on your premises shall be borne by you whether the plant be wholly or only partly erected or be lying unerected and notwithstanding any arrangements as regards terms of payment, and that the value of the plant or such portion of it as may be so damaged or destroyed shall be paid by you to us within thirty days from the happening of such damage or destruction.

Property Rights—It is specially understood and agreed that the title, ownership and right of possession in the said machinery and plant shall not pass from us, notwithstanding its delivery to you, until the whole price thereof shall have been paid to us in cash; and it is further agreed that we shall have the right, in case of default by you in any of the payments as stipulated herein, or any note or notes given by you in connection herewith to take possession of the machinery and plant, and to retain all sums which may have been paid by you to us on account thereof, as a rental charge therefor without prejudice to any rights under this contract or by way of damages. It is furthermore understood and agreed that in case of a judgment obtained against the purchaser that the judgment does not merge or interfere with any of our rights under our lien or property rights.

Guarantee—We guarantee you against all suits at law for infringements of patents.

We undertake to replace free on your premises, any part of our machinery that may fail within twelve months from date of delivery, owing to original defects in the material or workmanship.

We guarantee that the plant when erected according to the drawings supplied by us, and operated in exact conformity with our instructions, shall be capable of doing the following work:

That the compressor has a cooling capacity equal to the melting of one ton of ice in twenty-four hours, according to the Standard of the American Society of Refrigerating Engineers.

Under the following conditions:—That sufficient dry steam, electric current of specified characteristics, or other driving power is supplied by you to run our machinery the necessary hours per day at the specified speed. Dear Sir:

Herewith I submit the Quarterly Report ending Sept. 20, 1927.

The pupils enjoyed their holidays, though some of those who spent them at home are not so healthy looking as they were in leaving school, likely for want of proper food or regularity.

As usual we had to go around the camps to gather them, the generality of parents do not appreciate yet the advantage of education; they would rather keep their children with them.

The refrigeration plant has proved satisfactory during the exceptionally hot summer.

We purchased a truck to haul freight from the station so necessary when north trains bring perishable goods. A garage for same was also erected.

At present the electric light is extended to the barn and outside buildings.

Having to break new ground we have ordered a tractor with necessary attachments for the purpose, besides it will give our boys a general knowledge of farm implements.

The crops are better than we expected, having had no rain to speak of all this summer. For same cause the potatoes are rather small.

It will take a few weeks more for the pupils to settle down and give entire satisfaction.

Hoping that you will appreciate the efforts made to improve the coming generation in your Agency

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have been informed that there are about 19 School desks still left at the Old Mission School at Fort St. James the property of the Department and as the building that these desks are in is not quite weather proof I felt that the Department should be notified so that if the Department wishes the desks in question could either be sold to the local schools or shipped direct to the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School where I understand they could be used. If the Department decides on the latter course I would be pleased to receive the necessary authority to move the desks right away before they go through another Winter in a building that is not rain proof. If this authority is granted I would respectfully request that cartage charges on the desks be allowed as the move is about 100 miles by road and would have to be done by motor truck and the sum of thirty-five or forty dollars would be necessary to cover the dray man's charges.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Pragnell, who visited the Fraser Lake Residential School in August, last, makes the following recommendations:

1. That a new root cellar be provided.
2. Fire extinguishers refilled and the boys trained in their use.
3. Stove pipes from the jacket heater, which are in a dangerous condition, having eight bends from the heater to the exit, should be made safer and given better draft.
4. The heater is too close to the gasoline engine to be safe.
5. Steam boiler in laundry too small for work required and should be replaced by a larger boiler.

You should arrange for the purchase of the refills required for the fire extinguishers and see that they are installed and the extinguishers placed in a satisfactory condition and ready for immediate use in case of fire. The older boys should receive instruction in their use, and fire drills should be given the pupils.

Please report regarding the other recommendations of the Inspector, giving an estimate of the cost of any work you would recommend be carried out. Full particulars should be given regarding the root cellar and the replacing of the present steam boiler in the laundry by a larger boiler.

The school authorities should change the present location of the jacket heater and adjust the stove pipes therefrom in order that there will be no danger from fire.

The Department will be pleased to hear from you regarding the matters referred to at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

INSPECTION REPORT ON STUART LAKE AGENCY (NO.7) AUG 26, 1929.

I visited and went over Le Jac Residential school at Fraser Lake. Holidays were on but I met the Principal, Rev. Father Cocoola. The crops were excellent. I also saw the new pig pens. The barn was also in first class condition and I saw the new pedigree bull. A new root cellar is badly needed. The Manual training shop is working well and some very good work is being turned out by the boys. I also went over the main building with Mr. Moore and the Principal. The Fire extinguishers want refilling and the boys trained in their use. Mr. Moore is going to test their fire drill when school reopens. The stove pipes from the Jacket heater are dangerous. It is too far to its exit, and takes too many bends, about eight. This can be rectified at little cost, made safer, and with better draft. The heater is also too close to the gasoline engines to be safe. The steam boiler in the laundry is now too small for the work required. It cannot supply enough steam for the washing machines, and drying machines in the laundry, especially in winter. It should be replaced by a larger boiler.

C. S. PRAGNELL.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

In acknowledging receipt of your letter of the 14th inst., File No. 163-1-5 relative to the erection of a hog pen at the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School, I hereby state that I forwarded a copy of your letter to the Principal so that he would understand and give the views of the Department in the matter.

In reply to this I received a letter from the Principal, copy of which I attach hereto along with the Blueprint of the proposed Piggery, and you will see from these that the amount allowed by the Department is just about half enough, however, I must say that I feel very much the same way about the Building as the Reverend Principal does and would prefer to see a Piggery built that would be in keeping with the other buildings already on the ground. Furthermore, material is much more expensive here than in more accessible places owing to the high freight rates which prevail along this line of Railway, and should we erect an $800.00 building it would not begin to accommodate the number of pigs that are usually kept at the School and for your information I would respectfully point out that there are on an average of four brood sows with their litters always on hand as well as a Boar and some ready for killing. However, I am also enclosing the blueprint sent by the Principal and I think you will agree with me that the proposed building is not only substantial but will also be a credit to the School and to the Department.

Please do not misunderstand my action in again bringing this question before the Department, but I feel that I would not be doing the right thing to the Department were I to commence building before laying all the facts before you. Consequently, I would respectfully suggest that you please take this matter into consideration again, going over the plans carefully and if possible raise the appropriation by as much again. I fully understand the difficulties that you have to contend with insofar as finding funds to cover all these different improvements, but in case funds are not available this year could the Principal advance an equal amount with the Department on the understanding that he would be reimbursed after April 1st, 1930. If so I am sure that he would be willing to go ahead. In closing please allow me to again thank the Department for the many kindnesses and considerations allowed me on behalf of this Agency on previous occasions and it is knowing the consideration you have always given my recommendations before that make me hesitate before asking you to again consider this question. Trusting to hear from you favourably in this regard at your early convenience.

I have the honour to be, Sir:
Your obedient servant;

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, File No. 163-1-5, relative to certain recommendations made by Inspector Fragnell, after he visited the School during the month of August. In this connection I wish to point out that I made a regular visit to the School last week and took the different items mentioned in your letter, up with the Principal and we arrived at an understanding on each of them, the result of which I would respectfully submit here-with for your consideration.

(1): New root cellar can wait until next year.

(2): Fire extinguisher refills have been ordered by the Rev. Principal and instruction and fire drill are given the children once a week.

(3): The location of the Jacket heater should be moved outside entirely where there is an ideal place for it in an alcove between the main building and the chapel, owing to the fact that I have not got a plan of the school where the alcove in question is shown I am unable to explain its exact location so that you would fully understand but it is a good location and should prove satisfactory, all it needs is a small room built in brick and roofed which will cost approximately $450.00. There is no other place where the heater can be changed to without having just as much stove pipe and alcoves as there are at present owing to the distance away from the chimney.

The steam boiler in the laundry is much too small and we got a price on one that is large enough from the Fairbanks-Morse Co. amounting to $555.00 plus $150.00 for freight charges and pipe connections and fittings. It can be installed by the engineer without any cost to the Department and if the Department would kindly take this matter into consideration at an early date and advise what action you wish me to take, I would greatly appreciate it as it is getting late in the year and the work should be done as quickly as possible.

I would also respectfully suggest that arrangements be made at an early date to provide Fire Gongs for the school, the one in use at the present time is much too small and cannot be heard all through the building. I would recommend that four be purchased, one for each floor, and connected up in such a way that they can be rung from any floor and will ring at once on all the floors. These gongs should be a reasonable size so that they will be heard above any other noises that may be happening. I did not get a price on the gongs but no doubt you could get an approximate cost from one of the stores in Ottawa.

Trusting that the several points mentioned in your letter are fully covered so that you will understand them, and that I will hear further in the near future.

Yours obedient servant;

The Secretary:
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Sir:

I beg to refer you to your letters of August 14th and September 11th last, with reference to the Hog Pen which was to be built at the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School, and would take this opportunity to advise the Department that the building is now complete with the exception of putting down the cement floor and this will be done just as soon as the weather moderates sufficiently that it will be safe to lay the cement.

I wish to state that the work was done on this building by the Manual Training Instructor, who I might say is a very competent man, and the bigger boys. That saved the expense of hiring Mr. T.P. Smithers by day labour and made it possible to have the building completed this year. The only outlay for labour was for digging the water mains and sewer trench which amounted to $177.00 and which was paid for by the Reverend Principal at the time and which amount he is asking to have repaid as per attached Voucher. All the material in the building, with the exception of some small items, amounted to $159.15 for which Vouchers have gone forward and which leaves a balance of $140.85. The Voucher attached for $177.00 will overdraw the amount allowed but I am sending it in and should you not be able to meet the few dollars extra kindly deduct from the amount of the Voucher, but to show you that we did the best we could under the circumstances to keep the expense within the amount allowed and still build a structure that will be in keeping with the other buildings, I am also attaching a letter from the Rev. Sir:

In connection with the attached Voucher No. 4352, amounting to $483.62 in favour of the Rev. Father N. Coccolo, O.M.I., I would respectfully refer you to your letter of May 21st, last in which you authorised the sum of $450.00 for this work. Upon receipt of your letter I wrote the Principal acquainting him with the contents, and under date of May 29th, I received a letter from him in which he stated that owing to other work of an important nature that he was not quite ready to proceed, but when convenient he would get prices on the materials etc. and let me know. This happened last May and as nothing had been done about it, so far as I knew, on the 5th, of the present month, I wrote the Principal again pointing out that I had not been advised of what he proposed doing or the prices obtained, and suggesting immediate action be taken so that the work would be completed before the cold weather. I received a reply to that letter, from the Principal in which he stated "that the surest way to find out the cost was to go ahead and build it, this work has been done and in the near future he would send on bills for labour and material which he had already paid." In due course these arrived and as I thought the carpenter work should have been done by the Manual Training Instructor at the School I wrote the Principal and asked for an explanation why this was not done to which he replied under date of the 25th, inst., copy of which is also attached. I trust that the above explanation will be satisfactory and that a cheque in favour of the Rev. Principal will be sent him in due course.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that I have this day received a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School, which says in part:

"I have to bring to the attention of the Department that our lighting battery is in bad condition and should be rebuilt as soon as possible. I would suggest that the necessary material be supplied and the work done during the vacation period by our Engineer. We have obtained competitive prices from two firms in Vancouver and the cost of material will be about $500.00. If repairs are delayed it may become necessary to renew the battery."

For the information of the Department I wish to point out that the set of batteries in question was installed at the School in June 1926, and from information I got, I understand that the average life of a set of batteries, such as we have at the School, lasts about six years. The batteries cost $1145.00 at the School siding so that to have them rebuilt will cost almost half of the original cost. If the price of batteries has gone down anything worth while we might be able to get a new set for very little more than it would take to rebuild the old set. However, I can not get that information here without sending out for it, but you might be able to get it in Ottawa, so if you would kindly take the matter into consideration at your early convenience and advise if we may incur the necessary expenditure this year. I might add that when the estimates were made last summer this battery was in good shape, but they go in a hurry once they start.

Your obedient servant:

R.H. Moore
