A cement cellar is required for the storage of fruit and vegetables. The old one is not much further use as it has fallen in. A cellar big enough to store carload lots of fruit and vegetables is required. I understand from the Principal that such a cellar will cost between $2000 and $3000 to construct. I wish to recommend that a large enough cellar be authorized; but I do not know just how correct the Principal is in his estimate of the cost. It is, of course, essential that in this cold part of B.C. some satisfactory method of storage of roots, etc., be authorized.

The Pig Pen has a concrete and rail interior. It has been well built. I have been asked to recommend that tiles be supplied to construct a drain from the Pig Pen to the top of a hill, from which there is a large natural fall in the ground, which would drain off all water. The length of such a tile drain would be about 100 yards. I think that a wooden box drain would be satisfactory here. The important thing is to have it deep and well covered, so that the water in it will not freeze in the winter. This would probably be much less expensive than a tile drain. Some sort of well protected drain is necessary as the water freezes and will not run off. More and more collects in the Pig Pen and this too freezes.

I wish to recommend the supply of 100 yards of half inch wire cable for the hay fork on the Hay Barn. The present rope breaks constantly and is a danger to the children working with the hay. The cable now recommended would cost about $50.00.

In the Blacksmith's Shop the following are required and their supply is recommended:- One new set Drills for mending farm machinery (one sixteenth inch to one inch are required). This set of drills will cost about $10.00. - One complete set of Taps and Dies are also very badly needed, as the old ones are now completely worn out and quite useless. This set will cost about $15.00.

Laundry:- I wish to recommend that a guard rail be placed around the extractor. This will keep a child from walking or backing into the moving parts of the machinery and is, I think, very necessary. The engineer will probably have done this work by now, as we had a talk about its necessity when I was at the school. The materials are available at the school and he is quite able to do the necessary work of installing such a guard rail.

Sir:

I would respectfully refer you to previous correspondence in connection with the new pigery that was built at the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School about two years ago. At the time no provision was made for a drain to take off the water from the building except for a short distance below it, which answered the purpose for a time but this fall the water is starting to run over the grounds and to insure against disease among the children, I made arrangements with the Rev. Principal to go ahead and dig a drain from the Pigery to a point about 100 yards below which is well out of reach of the School yard and buildings. This drain I arranged to be deep enough so that it would not freeze and would consist of a box drain set at the bottom of the ditch that is now almost dug. Insofar as getting prices from the firms above mentioned, I would just like to say that they are small garage owners and if asked to quote on a job of this kind they would have to order the materials from the wholesaler, or the manufacturer as the case might be, have them shipped to Ladac direct where they would be taken over by the Engineer at the School and the necessary repairs made. This is just what the Rev. The point I wish to make is, this work was done before your letter of authority arrived as the Principal had to assure himself of light for the School before the end of the holidays, hence his hurry in having the work attended to.

Sir:

Under date of August 26th last I submitted the estimates to the Office of the Commissioner, for this Agency, for the year 1933-34.

In my covering letter sent with the estimates, I mentioned particularly about a new lighting plant for the Lejac Indian Residential School, attaching a letter from the Rev. Principal on the subject.

Apparently when the present plant was first installed, it was just large enough to carry the load of the School alone, since then the load has been increased every year with new lines being run to the outbuildings etc., so that now the plant is most unsatisfactory. About a year and a half ago, we had the present batteries rebuilt after five years service, thinking that we would save the cost of a new set, as the cost of rebuilding was only a fraction of the cost of a new set. However, the batteries after about a year's running (after being rebuilt) commenced to go down again and would not hold a charge at all, until now the plant has to be run almost day and night to keep them even half charged. This is a very unsatisfactory state of affairs and the light is getting worse and worse. I send a copy of the Rev. Principal's letter now to you and would suggest that if at all possible that arrangements be made this fall to install a new plant large enough to carry the required load, or else buy a new set of batteries. The drawback about installing new batteries is that, the present generator is too small, so that we would only have the same thing to contend with again in the near future. I would respectfully urge that early action be taken in this matter.

Your obedient servant;

The Secretary;
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Allow me to bring to your attention to the unsatisfactory lighting condition in our school, remarked by Inspector Barry in his inspection last October.

The battery is worn out, the present engine 10 H.P. Z type by Fairbanks-Morse has been obsolete for 10 years and the 5 K W Generator is too small to charge a battery rated at 240 Ampere hours.

The cost of a new battery is almost equal to the cost of a Diesel direct connection lighting plant, which a firm is prepared to install in the School for the sum of $2875-00, sales tax extra.

INSPECTION REPORT STUART LAKE AGENCY No. 10.

I visited LeJac Indian Residential School. There were 163 children there at the date of my visit. I found everything neat and clean and went over the whole school. Fire equipment was in good order and the chemical extinguishers had been properly refilled. The children were having fish, soup, potatoes and bread for dinner, and were getting plenty of milk to drink. The shingle roof of the building should be painted. The Rev. Principal contends that the summer holidays should officially be made two months and Mr. Moore is inclined to agree with him. Apparently, owing largely to long distances travelled to their homes, and the fact that having in the agency takes place late, it is almost impossible to get the children back at the prescribed time.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to letter No. 163-1-5, referring to lights at this school, I would say that the plan referred to is not practical. We could not operate a 5 K.W. generator in addition to our 5 K.W. generator, as our 10 H.P. engine has not power to run them. In its present condition the engine is fully loaded running a 5 K.W. generator.

The engine is a 10 H.P., R.Z. type by Fairbanks Morse, the type has been obsolete for 6 years. The number of lights in use is kept down to the smallest number and will average about 90 lights of 40 watt capacity. The load including loss in lines shows 35 Amps at 110 volts on the switchboard.

It would be possible to get over our present difficulty by installing a battery of 160 Amp hour capacity, without the 5 K.W. generator but with the addition of a new switchboard to control charging, this would however be a very temporary arrangement, as we are 600 miles from a reliable source of repair parts (Vancouver and Edmonton) train and mail service will not allow of any orders being filled in less than 10 days. A battery of 160 hour capacity would run out in 3 days and would be dead in 10 days, that is, after standing 7 days after being exhausted. The fact that we have carried on for 11 years without mishap is no guarantee, but only shows we are nearing the time when accidents can be expected.

I cannot recommend dealing with Fort Fraser or Vanderhoof people in this matter as they are not in a position to render service.

I would respectfully urge that our application for Lister equipment be given careful consideration. These plants are as near fool proof as they can be made, and are used all over the world, often being successfully operated by Peons and natives.

The first cost of the Lister plant is low. The elimination of a battery is good economy. The cost of operation is very low, and the system of using 2 small units of different size will give 3 load variations.

This is good practice.

Yours Respectfully,

Signed:- Harold Allen, Engineer in charge.

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Lejac, B.C.

On July 29th and 30th, 1933, I made an inspection of the mechanical plant of this school which consists of:

Two Horizontal return tubular boilers, 60 in. in diameter by 16 ft. long, containing 75 3" x 16" tubes, longitudinal joint, 3 rivetted lap. Nos. 22460 and 22461 B.C., rated at 104 H.P., each and built in 1923, making them ten (10) years old.

One Vertical tubular boiler, 28 in. in diameter by 67 in. high, containing 36 3" x 36" tubes, longitudinal joint, double rivetted lap. No. 44411 B.C., rated at 6.9 H.P. and built in 1929, making it now 4 years old.

Two 3-1/2" x 6" Duplex pumps belt driven by a 10 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse Z Type Gasoline Engine, used for fresh water supply.

One 2-1/2" x 4" Ammonia Gas Compressor, driven by a 3 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse Z Type Gasoline Engine.

One 6 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse Z Type Gasoline engine, operating the Laundry Machinery.

One 7 H.P. Gasoline Engine, operating the wood cutting plant.

A new Lister cold starting Diesel lighting plant of one 5 K.P. Diesel Engine direct connected to a 2.5 K.W. Generator and one 9 H.P. Diesel Engine direct connected to a 4.5 Generator is being installed.

BOILER NO. 22460.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found that all stays, rivets and plates in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 40 lbs. per sq. in. and found it quite tight.

The internal condition of this boiler is very fair. There is some pitting started on the plates and tubes, which must be treated.

The test cocks, water gauge and blowdown cock are in good condition. The main stop valve is to be overhauled. The blowdown pipes are fair. The fusible plug is to be renewed. The steam gauge is 1 lb. light. The Safety Valve works freely and blows off at 5 lbs. pressure.
BOILER NO. 22461 B.C.

This boiler is in a similar condition to No. 22460, but the pits are more pronounced. During the Hydrostatic Test, one of the tubes started to leak. An attempt to stop the leak with some patent preparation had been tried but without success. This tube must be renewed, or a bolt tube stopper be used for the next firing season. Owing to the very isolated position of this plant, I would recommend that 6 bolt tube stoppers be procured so that if any more tubes start to leak, repairs can be made in a few minutes by the Staff instead of shutting down the plant for perhaps weeks until new tubes arrive from the Coast. Owing to the pitting, leaky tubes must be expected until the pitting has been arrested. If this had been reported sooner, measures could have been taken to prevent it.

I would recommend that a solution of 1 lb. Sal Soda to 3 gallons of clear lime water be used, using one gallon of the solution every three weeks and blowing two inches water from the boilers every week.

The test cocks and water gauge must be overhauled and repacked. The main stop valve must be repacked. The fusible plug must be renewed. The Steam Gauge is correct. I have issued a Certificate allowing a steam pressure of 5 lbs. and condition, on account of pitting, fair.

BOILER NO. 44411 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found that all stays, rivets and plates were in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test, but could not complete it as several tubes were leaking at the top tube sheet. These must be re-expanded and will last a little longer.

The internal condition of this boiler is very poor. It has the appearance of being badly used. Steam must have been raised too quickly as the tubes have the appearance of being badly burnt and will require renewing next summer.

The test cocks, water gauge and blowoff cock are in good condition. The Safety Valve works freely by hand.

I must now state that the boilers of this plant have been neglected, but better results are expected with the new Engineer.

I have issued a Certificate allowing a steam pressure of 125 lbs., but condition fair.

LAUNDRY.

It consists of one large double washing machine and one 26" Hydro extractor. These are in good condition, but a new pipe guard must be placed around the belt end of the washing machine. The materials are at the School and the work can be done by the Staff.

FRESH WATER SERVICE.

The water supply is pumped from the Lake. The pumps are connected together and have independent shutoff valves on the discharge line, but there are no relief valves between the shutoff on the discharge and the pumps. One should be installed, as if these valves are closed and the pumps started, a serious breakdown of the pump might occur. At present, the pump house, pumps and gasoline engine are in a very dirty condition which will contaminate the drinking water if not attended to.

COLD STORAGE.

This is of the direct expansion type. The expansion mains have been allowed to get badly corroded and there is an ammonia leak in the Fresh Meat Room. These must be attended to, the mains cleaned off and painted with Black Asphaltum.

ELECTRIC LIGHT PLANT.

A new plant is being installed, but upon looking at the specifications I noticed that there is no guarantee of performance except a 48-hour run after installation. Owing to the position of this school and the importance of having continuous operation, I should think that a 12 month guarantee would be required.

My dear Mr. Moore,

Lately you sent me, Father Cocoola's letter, in which he said that the Lejac School was ready to pay as much as $1500.00, if necessary, towards the installation of a new electric plant. Dear Sir: Re: Inspection of Boilers & Machinery,
Indian Residential School,
LaJac, Fraser Lake, B.C.

Boiler #22460.

On July 20th, 1934, I gave this boiler a careful
internal and external inspection and found all stays,
rivets, seams, plates and tubes in good condition.

There were some scale blisters on the tubes and plates,
but very slight pitting.

I gave it a Hydrostatic test of 25 lbs. and found it
quite tight. The leaky tube reported last year has
been renewed. The brickwork is under repair and when
finished will be in good condition.

The Safety Valve is set to blow off at the required
pressure. The Steam gauge is 2 lbs. light.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure
of 15 lbs. and condition good.

Boiler #22461.

On the same date I gave this boiler a similar
inspection and found it in the same condition as Boiler
No. 22460. The steam gauge is 1 lb. light.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure
of 15 lbs. and condition good.

Both these boilers are very much improved over last
year.

Whilst I was there, the question of hot water for the
domestic supply was raised. I recommended that a
steam coil be installed in the storage tank and steam
be supplied from the main boilers. If this is done,
it will help the situation considerably.

These boilers are high pressure boilers with a special
low pressure spring on the safety valves. If new
25 lb. springs were procured and a pressure of 25 lbs.
carried on them and a reducing valve installed on the
steam heating mains, then all the hot water required
in the building and laundry would be available and
most of the excessive load on the laundry boiler would be easily relieved.

Boiler No. 44411.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found it in very good condition. This boiler has been retubed since my last inspection.

I gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 195 lbs. and found it perfectly tight. This boiler is much too small for the amount of work required and if my suggestions are adopted will last for some years. If not, then a new boiler will be required in a very short time.

I set the safety valve to blow off at 130 lbs. The steam gauge is correct. I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 130 lbs., and condition good.

Auxiliary Machinery.

The new Lister semi-diesel electric lighting plant is installed and working fairly satisfactory, but considerable trouble is experienced with carbon deposits in the exhaust pipes which necessitates frequent cleaning. With a slight alteration of the exhaust pipe, it will be helped.

This unit is on the small side and will need enlarging in the near future or a peak load unit installed.

All the recommendations of my last report have been carried out, the new guards installed, the water pumps cleaned, etc. In fact, I was very much pleased upon the whole condition of the plant. From appearances, this plant will be in splendid condition in the near future.

Yours respectfully,

T.J. Arnall

Engineer.

Dear Mr. Moore,

Since taking over the principalship of the Lejac Indian School in August 1933, it has come to my attention that in past years there has been practically no vegetable crops grown on our property. This seems very strange insomuch as surrounding farmers manage to produce successfully and sufficiently both for their own needs and for marketing. It would therefore appear that poor management has, in the past, been responsible for the failures along this line.

With so many mouths to feed and so many extra necessities required, it is quite evident that a radical change is needed and the school produce its own necessities of life. I am fully convinced that what others can do so can we with proper care and management. This year I have a certificated gardener in charge of the garden and I am very determined to see my desires accomplished; that is, to have an over supply of vegetables to carry the school over the next winter. We already have 22 acres of ground in preparation for vegetables alone.

However, there will not be much sense in producing the crop if we have no place in which to store it. For that reason I write to solicit aid from the Department in the construction of a new root cellar. As you already are aware, ours is in a very poor condition. It is constructed in a rather haphazard way which will result in its one day caving in and perhaps causing injury to limb or body. Many of the logs used were poplar and as you well know Poplar wood will not stand the weather conditions and soon decay. Besides its improper construction will not allow for our zero weather and only with much difficulty do we manage to keep our vegetables from freezing.

A larger root cellar is also a necessity insomuch as, as I represent the Department here, they expect me to get results and for the same reason I am determined to see the ambitions of the Department realized and the school's good name re-claimed.
At an earlier period in the school's history, the Department contemplated allotting sufficient funds for the erection of a concrete cellar. I disfavor this move because concrete is a conductor of cold and in our northern country such a building would not be advisable. Secondly, a building consisting of the dimensions we require, in concrete would cause the Department an outlay in the vicinity of from 10 to 12 thousand dollars. The same building could be erected from logs properly hewed and seasoned for about two thousand dollars. A properly constructed root cellar will give many years of service and there is no danger of freezing nor cracking caused by the frosts.

The building we will require would be 100 ft. long by 32 ft. wide, dug into the ground and timbered with 6 bins along each side and a 6 ft. aisle in the centre. Each bin will have a separate ventilator extending through the roof which will be 5 ft. above the ceiling.

The school is not in a position to meet the cost of constructing such a building and our present cellar will not suffice for another year. It seems a pity that for lack of accommodation we are compelled to harvest a smaller crop than will supply our own requirements when we have the land, the time, and the ability to produce our own needs.

I would, therefore, greatly appreciate your co-operation in presenting our cause to the Department and, if possible, obtaining their help in our need for a new root cellar.

Very truly yours,

Rev. L. H. Rivet, O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Sir,

Re: LEJAG RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

In company with Mr. Moore, I spent Monday last, the 16th inst., at this School. I must say that this is one of the best Schools I have yet visited. The principal, from all accounts, has money of his own, and has apparently spent a considerable amount of it for repairs and improvements. He feels that the Department is not supporting him as well as we should. However, I convinced him otherwise.

I authorized Mr. Moore to buy paint to the value of $250.00. This is the only amount specially provided in this year's appropriation for this School.

However, they really require a building to store their flour and other food-stuffs. As you are aware, this School is located in a very inaccessible place and they are obliged to carry heavy supplies of food and, as a result, a suitable storeroom is absolutely necessary. Mr. Moore states that if he were authorized to incur an expenditure of $1,000.00 for lumber and other material, a suitable building could be built. All the labour would be supplied by the School staff. While this amount is not provided in this year's vote, I feel that it is an expenditure that should be incurred - not only because it is required, but also it will show the principal that the Department wishes to co-operate with him in the splendid work that I feel that he is doing. I should therefore appreciate if you would take up this matter at once, and if the necessary authority can be secured Mr. Agent Moore should be advised. You can depend on Mr. Moore to handle the matter in a proper manner.

The principal also requested 300 sq. ft. of Battleship Linoleum, and 3 new sewing machines. No doubt you can arrange to have these purchased.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir:-

During the visit of Mr. Phelan to the Lejac Residential School two months ago the Rev. Principal made a request at that time that the Department supply battleship linoleum for the kitchen floor at the School. This floor is cement and apparently it is very hard on the feet of the cooks and it was felt that if linoleum was put down it might correct the situation. Sir:

I beg to attach hereto a copy of a letter in duplicate which I received from the Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School, which is self explanatory.

Mr. Phelan will remember that during his visit last spring to the School that this matter was discussed with the Principal and the understanding when he left was that nothing more be done about it until next spring. However, Mr. Barry visited the School this fall, (the first time in three years) and apparently gave the Rev. Principal hopes that the cellar would be authorised this fall on his recommendation. Please write me in this regard as Mr. Barry's promises seems to have raised high hopes.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing copy of letter received from the Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School with reference to the root cellar. As you are aware, the Department has expended considerable money at this school this year, and our Appropriation will not permit supplying the funds required for the erection of the root cellar.

Inspector Barry had no right to encourage the Principal in thinking that the root cellar would be allowed this year.

For your information, I may say that new instructions regarding his duties have recently been issued to Mr. Barry. In future, Mr. Barry will not be required to report on the maintenance and repairs of buildings. The Indian Agent, in future, will be expected to make recommendations in this regard. Mr. Barry will confine his efforts to the assistance of teachers and general inspection of the operation of the schools.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.
Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Mr. Moore:

Inasmuch as the season for harvesting our vegetable crops is close at hand, it is well that we again present our cause for a new root-cellar to the Department. Weather conditions have been most favourable resulting in an abundant yield, which, unless we receive some consideration, will be left a prey to the winter's cold and frosts.

As you are aware, the housing capacity of our present root-cellar is inadequate and will not answer our requirements for space needed to cope with the vegetable returns from our gardens. Also, were it possible to store the entire returns, we could not hope to keep them from freezing and thereby losing the profits of a whole season's labour.

With an ever vanishing hope in view, that we may expect the Department to lend an ear to our cause, we have from year to year repaired and re-repaired our present cellar trusting that the winter would not be too severe. However, after the resulting affects from the past winter we deem it useless to add further expense to a cellar which will not suffice to meet our needs and unless we may expect the necessary aid from the Department it is ridiculous for us to utilize soil in raising vegetables which might otherwise be put to good advantage.

On the recent visit of Mr. Barry, inspector, to our school, he strongly recommended the need of a new and larger root-cellar. With his recommendation going forth I feel certain that our cause will at least meet with success.

On Mr. Barry's suggestion I am taking the liberty of again bringing this matter to your attention and feel confident that I may expect the usual careful co-operation from your part.

Very truly yours,

Signed: M.M. Rivet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Sir:

I would respectfully direct your attention to your letter of July 2nd, last File No. 167-1-5 wherein you authorize the expenditure of certain monies for improvements at the Lejac Indian Residential School. In the second paragraph of your letter you instructed that all labour was to be supplied by the School Staff without expense to the Department. This I can assure you was the intention and the understanding that was arrived at when Mr. Phelan was here but it so happened that the Rev. Principal found it necessary to bring back some of the more advanced Indian boys who were home on holidays to assist on the work on the understanding that they would be paid one dollar per day. While this work was good training for the boys it was not possible to postpone the building of the store room until the School opened again at the end of August as the supplies would arrive about the middle of August and consequently some place had to be prepared, hence the rush. If you would have cheques made out in favour of the boys whose names are shown here and sent to the Rev. Principal, I could deliver them to those concerned.

Dear Sir:

On several occasions in the past, the school has asked the Department for a new root cellar and Piggery. Our need for these two buildings has been explained and re-explained in each requisition but as far as we seem able to get is the more exacting of a promise that our requirements will receive consideration.

Last fall we stored a sufficient quantity of roots and vegetables to carry the school over the entire season; but with the disadvantages to be gained by storing in a rather improvised cellar resulted in the ruin of at least one third of our crop.

In order to cultivate sufficient vegetables and roots to cover the needs of both the school and the stock, we require more and better storage room and, consequently, as well as a new cellar being sorely needed so also is a larger one.

Due to the loss of our piggery by fire, we deemed it advisable to butcher a number of brood sows we were considering keeping for the purpose of increasing our stock. Housing accommodation is scarce and if the Department does not soon see fit to grant the construction of a new piggery we shall have to dispose of our entire stock of hogs.

The foundation of the burned pig-sty can yet be used to raise a new building upon, while the stanchions, though burned and twisted, can be straightened and will again serve the purpose of serviceable pens. The only extra cost would be the enlarging to accommodate two extra pens.

We estimate that the total outlay, to cover both buildings, will be between $3500 and $4000 and should it occur that the Department's intentions have grown beyond the verge of a promise we should greatly appreciate knowing, at once, so that excavation work may be commenced as soon as the ground thaws.

Trusting to be favored with your co-operation in this matter which means so much to the school, I am,

Very truly yours,

L. H. Rivet, O. M. I.

Dear Sir,

Recently we purchased from your department a F.M. 10 H.P. type Z engine and a F.M. 5000 watt generator in a knocked down condition it being understood by us that this machine was in running condition before disassembly.

We examined the various parts of this machine as far as was possible allowing of course for a certain amount of replacement of worn bearings, piston rings etc to put the machine in good mechanical condition. A certain amount of the parts had to be taken on good faith since we had not the means of testing.

We have now assembled the motor and find that the crankshaft is sprung evidently done in dissembling, the shaft shows hammer marks which were noticed before but were not considered of serious import since it is hard to believe that any mechanical person would sledge a crankshaft to remove the flywheels but this seems to have been done.

The above condition could not have been detected without putting the shaft in a lathe or assembling the motor and testing since there is not a lathe, of sufficient size to swing this shaft, available in this community and we are unable to tell how much the shaft is out of true but it is sufficient that the bearing on one side cannot be fitted and consequently means the purchase of a new crankshaft since the hammering was done on the side of the crank-arm and has probably thrown the connecting rod also out of line.
The expense to date for parts for this machine has reached the sum of $95.00 which includes a new magneto that we had to purchase.

The above is for your information only.

Yours truly,
Taylor Bros.

Dear Sir:

Herewith, I beg to submit the report of the recent fire which resulted in fatal damage to the school piggery.

At 12:25 A.M. on the morning of October 9th, 1935, the blaze was first noticed by one of the employees who immediately sounded the alarm. The school fire alarm system was set into motion and it was at first taken as a night fire drill. Within two minutes the school was cleared of all occupants and upon ascertaining the cause the bigger boys were immediately put to work in an effort to keep the fire under control, while the girls and smaller boys were rushed back into their dormitories.

Within four minutes all forms of fire-fighting apparatus were on the site of the conflagration where boys and employees were working heroically to keep the blaze under subjection. Much effort and attention had to be centered on the surrounding buildings in order to avert other casualties and only due to the calmness of the weather and the concentration of the fire-fighters were we able to save them.

However, due to the fact that before being noticed, the fire had gotten away to a good start it was impossible to save the piggery from complete demolition.

Coincident with the loss of the building were 2 small week old pigs; 4 chickens; and about 4 tons of threshed oats which were being stored in an upper storey of the piggery.

The foundation is still in perfect shape and though the iron stanchions are badly burned and twisted, it is considered they can be straightened and re-used.

This catastrophe leaves the school without housing accommodation for its hogs and it is to be hoped that we may soon be allowed a grant from the Department covering the $1000.00 which is estimated to be necessary to rebuild our loss.

Very truly yours,

L. H. Rivet, O. M. I.

LHR/JM

   2. It seems probable that drain pipes from the heating system of the school run underneath the septic tank and it would be a simple matter to connect the waste pipes from the laundry to these drain pipes and obviate the necessity of having a grease trap either inside or outside the building.

I am told that this would not be very difficult. The plumber tells me that this is the easiest and best remedy for our present difficulties. Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 19th ultimo, enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School with reference to the pumping system.

After carefully considering the Principal's letter, it is felt that the following improvements to the pumping system should be made at once:

(1) The tile pipes at present used to convey the water from the iron pipes in the lake to the pumps should be removed and replaced with sealed joint metal pipe.

(2) If further investigation shows that the intake pipe is cut off close to the shore, this pipe should be extended several hundred feet into the lake.

(3) With regard to the laundry and kitchen outlets and the interruption of the normal action of the septic tank, the only remedy is installation of grease traps. Two types of traps are possible:
First, a trap of concrete construction for installation outdoors. Such traps have to be cleaned frequently and, therefore, should be located at a point where the loose earth or cover may be removed and replaced without trouble. Within reason, this trap should be located as far as possible from the building and to the leeward to minimize objectionable odours.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,

The second type, and possibly the most economical for this case, is the installation of a metal trap indoors on the waste line of the lines carrying grease or oil. This does not mean the main sewage line but only the branch wastes from the kitchen sink and laundry. If these two sources are united before reaching the main waste, one trap would serve the purpose. These indoor traps offer greater convenience for cleaning and may be used if the odour arising during their cleaning operation is not a serious objection.

It is not possible for the Department to decide which type of trap is the most economical or the most applicable in the case of the Lejac Indian Residential School. This will have to be decided by the Principal and yourself after consulting a competent plumber.

Provision has been made in the current year's appropriation for the sum of $300.00 for miscellaneous repairs at the Lejac Indian Residential School. It is considered that the above work can be done for less than this amount. You may, therefore, proceed with the work on this understanding but, if preliminary estimates show that the cost involved is more than the amount mentioned, you should communicate with the Department before proceeding.

If the above work is done promptly, it is hoped that it will result in an improved quality of water. In the meantime, the water used for drinking purposes should, of course, be boiled.

Dear Sir,

You will remember that on more than one occasion we discussed the trouble that we were having with the pumping system for the water supply. Matters came to a head with the spring thaw and we were obliged to make some temporary repairs in order to keep the pump working and to prevent too much ground water getting into the well. In doing this work our engineer discovered that the pipes used to convey the water from the iron pipes in the lake to the pumps were in a very unsatisfactory condition. Apparently the pipes are the ordinary tile pipes used for drainage; they are porous, merely laid end to end without any covering for the joints and are therefore no use as protection from contamination from the surface water.

As the overflow from the septic tank, which is not functioning well, drains in the direction of the pump house and as the surface soil in the vicinity of the pump house is exposed to contamination from various sources, I think it is duty to point out that under present conditions, the water supplied to the school cannot be considered safe, and I should be glad if you would kindly lay this matter before the Department at your earliest convenience and ask for instructions.

It would seem that the first step would be to obtain some chemicals that would make the water fit for drinking and cooking purposes. After the immediate danger has been removed, it would be well to consider having a thorough cleaning or thorough disinfection of the intake system. I understand that several hundred feet of two inch piping have been damaged by the action of the wind and waves. These pipes are now lying at the bottom of the lake. The water pumped to the house is therefore taken near the shore and quite likely to be contaminated.

The engineer is not prepared to say what it would cost to make the necessary repairs. I believe it would be worth while asking the Department to send a competent man who would be able to make a complete report on the water supply and the septic tank. I understand that the big trouble in connection with the septic tank is that no provision was made for a separate outlet from the laundry and the kitchen, with the result that the scum and fats cling into the septic tank as well as the heavy flow of water from the laundry, preventing the normal functioning of the tank, with the resulting contamination of the field below and the foul smell which comes from the tank. I believe that it has been suggested that there would be no trouble from the tank if it were cleaned out at regular intervals, but experience has proven that this is not the case and the only remedy seems to be to have a separate outlet from the laundry. I do not know whether the foul odors from the tank are dangerous as far as the health of the children is concerned. The boy's playground is near the tank, and they are constantly breathing the contaminated air, and on certain days when...

STUART LAKE AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT NO. 16.

I inspected the Residential School at Lejac.

Everything seemed, as a whole, very satisfactory at the school, though their farming methods might well be improved. I inspected the kitchen, which was clean and in good order. The children were having for their meal, soup, fish, potatoes, bread and butter.

All fire appliances were in position and in good order. Dormitories were in good order, and lavatories clean. The septic tank, however, is not working properly, and the overflow smells badly. This, I think, is due to the laundry waste flowing through the same system. As 1500 gallons is used on washing days, soap etc., prevents the correct bacterial action of the septic tank. The laundry waste could be connected, at not too great cost, with the boiler line overflow which empties over some low lying ground. Further, the iron pipe into the lake, from whence the school obtains its water supply, would seem to have got disconnected. This will mean no water supply in the winter and should be investigated and the necessary repairs made. Possibly ice last winter caused this break.

A pig pen is required on the farm. I should suggest that material be supplied and the boys erect the same as part of their manual training.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Moore:

Re: Septic Tank and Water Supply.

With reference to previous correspondence and our recent conversation concerning the water supply and the Septic Tank I beg to report as follows:

WATER TANK.

You will recall that early this spring before the break up of the ice our engineer installed a box reservoir in order to prevent sand and dirt from entering into the pipes leading into the pumps. Further work was prevented by the break-up of the ice and the subsequent rise of the lake level now that the water has gone down we are in a position to report on the steps necessary to safeguard the purity of our water supply.

a. It will be necessary to dig a trench 6' deep and 36' long between the pump house and the reservoir.

b. Another trench 30' long will be required to reach the end of the pipe now lying at the bottom of the lake. We estimate that this will require one week's work for one man.

The material required will be 30' of the special pipe recommended by the Department and 30' of six inch iron pipe to connect with the 300' now at the bottom of the lake. I have been unable to find any estimate of the cost of these pipes in any of our catalogues.

Once these two pipes have been installed I think that the purity of our water supply will be assured.
Lejac Indian Residential School
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers
LEJAC, B.C.

(2)

SEPTIC TANK

To remedy the defect in our septic tank caused by the action of the laundry water, we recommend the following solution:

The drain pipe of the laundry can be connected with the drain from the boiler room which runs from the school to the hillside without passing through the Septic Tank. To do this it will be necessary to break up 4-10 feet of the cement floor in the basement so as to bring the laundry drain outside the building and to dig a trench one hundred feet long and eight feet deep from that point to the drain from the boiler room. The material required will be one hundred and ten feet of four inch iron pipe which according to the catalogue would be worth about $1.25 per foot.

I believe that counting labour and material this work would cost about $175.

You will recall that the Department instructed us to refer these questions back to them if the estimate of the costs should be over $300. We have already expended close to $200 this summer in connection with the Septic Tank and Water Supply, the chief item being the services of an experienced Plumber for seventeen days at $2.00 a day and the purchase of a Diaphragm Pump and twenty five feet of hose at the cost of $70. If the Department is prepared to include these two items in their estimate of the cost of the necessary repairs to the two systems I believe that the total cost would be in the neighbourhood of $600 and I feel that the expenditure of this amount would be well justified since it would mean the permanent of a problem that has been a source of trouble for many years past.
Lejac Indian Residential School
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers
LEJAC, B.C.

The only problem untouched would be that of the accumulation of foul smelling water in the pasture field below the Septic Tank. Possibly this problem will no longer exist if the Septic Tank functions properly and nothing but pure water flows from its second chamber. I understand that according to the original plans the water from the Septic Tank was to be conducted underground to the ditch along the railway tracks but perhaps because the pipes were not laid deep enough to withstand the heaving caused by the frost this pipe system has never functioned and part of the pasture used by the dairy cows of the school has always been a foul smelling bog. Certain amount of criticism has been made on this point and I suppose that the Department should be informed of this situation.

I hope that the details contained in this report will be sufficient to enable the Department to understand the solution that we recommend.

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, C.M.I.

PROPOSED PIGERY AT LEJAC SCHOOL

The figures included in these estimates are based on three major considerations:

1. The quantity of pork and pork products consumed at the school.

2. The climate with its long and severe winter.

3. The probable wishes of the Department that the new building be permanent, well equipped and in keeping with the other farm buildings.

1. The quantity of pork and pork products consumed at the school. A study of our books shows that the consumption of pork can be grouped under three headings:
   A. Fresh pork, ham and bacon consumed in the school.
   B. Lard and other by-products
   C. Bacon and lard given to the Indians in payment for work done.

These three items work out at about 30lbs a day. During the past year we have purchased nearly one thousand pounds of lard, and an average of one hundred pounds of ham and bacon per month.

Some of this goes to the Indians who work for the school from time to time. Experience has proven that this system is far better than that of paying cash to the Indians since in most cases the cash is usually wasted. This heavy purchase of pork and pork products shows that to meet the requirements of the school at least eight sows are required. The four sows that we keep at present do not supply half our needs.

2. The climate with the long and severe winter. The climate affects both the size and cost of the building.

A. The size, because without adequate protection it is impossible to have more than one litter a year from each sow instead of the two litters required for economical production.

B. The cost, because experience has proven that the concrete footings and foundations usually found in the plans and specifications for buildings of this kind are not deep enough or strong enough to withstand the severe frost and the resultant heaving which takes place in the spring. We find that we use double the amount of cement and gravel in order to assure foundations strong enough to withstand the rigors of our climate.

Dear Sir:

Indian Commissioner Mackay has forwarded the Department copy of your letter to him of November 30th and his reply to you of December 5th; also Reverend Byrns-Grant's letter of November 26th in connection with the proposed construction of a new pigery at the Le Joc Indian Residential School.

While the Department is anxious to assist the Principal in the cost of the construction of this building; at the same time I feel that a much less expensive building than the one suggested by the Principal would fill the requirements of the Lejac School.

Dear Mr. Moore:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter enclosing one dated Jany. 22nd concerning the construction of a new piggery.

The original report suggested a building at an estimated cost of $1820 and while reference was made of the estimates furnished by the Beatty Co. of $1200 for modern interior fixtures this item was not considered as part of the original recommendation. By striking out this item altogether the building would cost only $1820.

This estimate is not high and perhaps the Department would be willing to go as far as possible in contributing towards this amount and the school would pay for the balance out of its own funds and possibly the Department could see its way to reimburse us next year or before the end of the fiscal year 1938-39.

Another solution would be to figure that on the basis of $1820 for a building 70 feet long, the cost would be $260 for every ten feet and the length of the building could be limited to the amount of money available and provision made in its construction for an increase in length at a latter date.

In these estimates there is nothing included that could be considered to be showy or unnecessary and the plans therefore would meet the wishes of the Department on this point.

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto a letter with certain recommendations by the Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School regarding necessary improvements to and additions to the fire fighting equipment at Lejac.

In commenting on the various points mentioned by the Principal I would respectfully point out that the icy condition of the fire escapes seems to be the worst feature that the successive Principals at the School have had to deal with over a period of years. It was thought that by keeping the snow swept off the fire escapes themselves that we would overcome some of the difficulty but the continual dripping of the roof made the fire escapes next to impossible to use except in case of emergency. However, if the emergency did arise the children could always get down although one or two of them might happen to fall and get hurt; but to use the escapes for fire drill during winter months it is not considered advisable and is not necessary. With reference to the windows which lead unto the fire escapes; these did get sealed up with ice but like the escapes in the case of an emergency the windows would be broken anyway as no one would take time to open them.

No doubt a similar situation to this must exist in some other schools and I would appreciate information from the Department as to what would be the best procedure to follow during fire drill.

We did put in some new fire fighting equipment at the School about a year ago but from the information given by the Rev. Principal it would appear as if we should replenish and replace some of the equipment that is faulty and out of condition.

Dear Mr. Moore:

With reference to the estimates for plumbing submitted by Marshall-Wells, the reason for the increase over the original estimate is due to the fact that in my first figures I did not allow for the necessary drain pipe and water pipe to connect the new piggery with the existing water and drainage system.

It was only when we began to consider the details that I discovered that the building would be 200 feet away from the water and drainage system and that the extra pumping would have to be allowed for.

Now that we have gone into the details, the figures read something like this:

1. Lumber and bricks ......................... $1100-00
2. Plumbing .................................. 350-00
3. Gravel and cement .......................... 680-00

Total $ 2130-00

If this is more than the Department can see its way to spend, we can fall back on one of the suggestions already made to the Department, viz., to shorten the building, or let the school absorb the difference out of the current revenue, with the possibility of being reimbursed later.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Phalen:

We are wondering about our pig pens. You will remember that the Dept. ordered and paid for the lumber and cement, but nothing has been done about the plumbing and the sand and the gravel. The Dept. has already received the estimates for the plumbing as submitted by Marshall-Wells. The amount of sand and gravel is indicated in the original estimates sent to the Dept. It can be brought to the school by C.N.R. freight car or by truck. We usually get it through Mr. Connelly of Fraser Lake Saw Mills to whom the Dept. already gave the contract for the lumber. His price is $3.50 per yard delivered at the school. This would be better for us than to get it by C.N.R. as we would not have to haul it up from the station.

We have already purchased the brood sows and we shall be in a quandry this winter, if permission to go ahead with the building is not given soon. You know how early our winters come. Would it be possible to hasten action by telegram so that we can get started? The gravel and the plumbing are necessary for the first part of the work.

Yours very sincerely,

Ottawa, September 15, 1936.

Dear Mr. Turgeon:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 31, in which you indicate that the Reverend Mr. Byrne Grant is anxious to proceed with the construction of a pigery at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

The records here indicate that the Principal of the Lejac School was authorized to proceed with the construction of a pigery in the early months of this year. The following supplies were purchased by the Department during the month of March: lumber $1187.77, cement $168.30, with freight charges amounting to $275.70. The Principal's letter to Mr. Phelan dated August 9, 1936, was the first communication received by the Department since March, with respect to the construction of the Lejac pigery. In the absence of any letters, the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch were naturally under the impression that the pig pens had either been completed or were at least in the process of construction. We still find it somewhat difficult to understand why construction work was not started toward the end of March or early in April.

In a departmental letter dated August 24, the Indian agent was informed that the sum of $500.00 was included in this year's estimates for repairs and improvements at the Lejac school. The agent was informed that this amount could be utilized for the installation -

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 31, in which you intimate that the Reverend W. Byrne Grant is anxious to proceed with the construction of a piggery at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

The records here indicate that the Principal of the Lejac School was authorized to proceed with the construction of a piggery in the early months of this year. The Principal's letter to Mr. Phelan dated August 9, 1938, was the first communication received by the Department since March, with respect to the construction of the Lejac piggery. In the absence of any letters, the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch were naturally under the impression that the pig pens had either been completed or were at least in the process of construction. We still find it somewhat difficult to understand why construction work was not started toward the end of March or early in April.

Dear Sir:

I wish to apply for formal permission to move our two electric generators from the room in the basement, in which they are now located, to a small and separate building behind the main building of the school.

There are several reasons which prompt this request:
1. Due to the proximity of the new root cellar to the power room, the exhaust pipe, instead of being in a horizontal position, has to be raised about twelve feet into the air; the resulting back pressure cuts the efficiency of the engines by at least ten per cent, and the engine becomes fouled very quickly.
2. Due to the position of the exhaust pipe, the silencers cannot be used, and the resulting noise is a great nuisance.
3. When the generators are running there is a great deal of vibration and noise in the chapel, which is situated directly overhead.
4. When the generators are removed we will have a good sized room in which to store cordwood for the furnaces. At present this wood has to be stored very close to the fireboxes, thereby causing a serious fire hazard, which was remarked upon by the Inspector on his recent visit.

Since this is a comparatively small undertaking we do not ask any special financial assistance from the Department in order to carry it out; we can do the whole thing by ourselves. The separate building already exists and needs very little alteration to fit it for its new use.

Captain Barry, who was here last week, heartily endorses this proposal; as also does our engineer, Mr. Leslie.

In order that we may go ahead with the job, an early reply will be greatly appreciated.

Very sincerely yours,

Rev. Alex R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Sir:

I beg to advise that yesterday afternoon the Rev. Father A.K. Simpson, Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School, sent word to me through the telephone operator at Ehdaio that a fire had occurred at the School and to come up at once. I left at once in company with Constable A.J.F. Rae and arrived at the School about an hour later.

The Reverend Principal showed us where the fire had broken out in the chimney at the back of the laundry. The fire was brought under control before it had done any damage. The only damage done was where the fire fighters broke through the roof to get at the inside of the chimney in the attic above the laundry.

We found that Mr. Gerald H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools had arrived at the School and was making his inspection when the fire happened. Mr. Barry is making a detailed report of the fire and making his recommendations to avoid any further happening of this kind, if possible.

Your obedient servant,

Jas. H. F. Lacey,
Acting Indian Agent.

Sir:

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School,
Electoral District of Cariboo,
Stuart Lake Indian Agency,
Province of British Columbia.

There was a fire on September 24 at the above-mentioned school due to a defective chimney but no heavy damage was done. Reporting on this fire the Principal wrote as follows:

"Once more I am obliged to send you a report of a fire having broken out in this school. The cause is substantially the same as that which caused the fire reported in my letter to the Department on December 19th., 1938, namely the high-pressure boiler for the laundry.

"After the previous fire I moved this boiler to another location, and piped it into the flue intended for the hot water heater and the bakery ovens. But this additional load has proved to be too much for the chimney and it overheated, cracked in many places, and had already charred the roof and the shingles when it was discovered. The house became filled with smoke that escaped through the cracks and holes in the chimney this morning, during the washing, and when we investigated we discovered the above mentioned condition.

"The chimney is built of home made brick, made of the local clay, and is not suitable for standing the heat from the fires. It is our opinion that the only..."
"permanent solution for the removal of this fire hazard is to tear down the whole chimney and rebuild it with high quality bricks. Also, a separate chimney should be erected on the other side of the building for the high pressure boiler and the hot water heater recommended by the Inspector of Schools."

The Indian Agent was requested by wire to advise the cost of erecting two new chimneys at this school. On the recommendation of Commissioner MacKay he secured the services of a competent contractor, Mr. A.P. Andersen, who has quoted as follows:

1. New chimney 18 x 18 flue with 6" wall lined with firebrick -- 60' high ...................$ 1,080.00

2. Tear down old chimney and rebuild 12 x 12 flue to be lined with ordinary flue lining ......$ 580.00

The above quotations have been supplied on the understanding that both chimneys will be built at the same time and the prices include concrete foundations for the chimneys.

The Lejac residential school was constructed in the fiscal year 1921-22 at an approximate cost of $185,000.00. In view of the two fires that have occurred as a result of the defective chimney it is considered that it would be advisable to erect two new chimneys immediately. The officers of the Surveys & Engineering Branch were consulted this morning and they expressed the opinion that the prices quoted by Mr. Andersen are reasonable.

Funds for the erection of the chimneys can be provided from the appropriation for the current fiscal year and I should appreciate receiving the approval of the Minister to accept Mr. Andersen's tender for the immediate construction of these two chimneys.

Director.

PP
Ottawa,

LEJAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Lejac, B.C.,

September 25th, 1939.

D.M. Mackay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for, B.C.,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Once more I am obliged to send you a report of a fire having broken out in this school. The cause is substantially the same as that which caused the fire reported in my letter to the Department on December 19th, 1935, namely the high-pressure boiler for the laundry.

After the previous fire I moved this boiler to another location, and piped it into the flue intended for the hot water heater and the bakery ovens. But this additional load has proved to be too much for the chimney and is overcrowded and cracked in many places, and had already damaged the roof and the stables when it was discovered. The house became filled with smoke that escaped through the cracks and holes in the chimney this morning, during the washing, and when we investigated we discovered the above mentioned condition.

The Inspector of Schools, Captain Barry, was here at the time and was a witness of the whole affair; which I am sure he will describe at length in his report.

The chimney is built of homemade brick, made of the local clay, and is not suitable for standing the heat from the fires. It is our opinion that the only permanent solution for the removal of this fire hazard is to tear down the whole chimney and rebuild it with high quality bricks. Also, a separate chimney should be erected on the other side of the building for the high pressure boiler and the hot water heater recommended by the Inspector of Schools.

For the present, however, in order that we may carry on, we will make temporary repairs with cement wherever possible. Inside the attic, for example, we found less than thirteen holes in the brickwork of the chimney, these can be stopped up, for the present, with cement. But, until this matter is remedied, it will be a constant source of danger to the building; and an anxiety to us.

Therefore, I beg that you will give this matter your prompt attention. I would suggest that a competent person be sent here to make a first hand investigation of the situation; and make suggestions that will entirely remove any danger of a third, or perhaps more serious, fire from the same source.

Yours very truly,

Signed: Rev. Alex. H. Simpson,
Principal.

Sir:— I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, File No. 163-1-5 regarding a recommendation made by Inspector Barry regarding the fire escapes at the Lejac Indian Residential School. I have taken this matter up with the Rev. Father A.K. Simpson, Principal of the School and he replies as follows:

"With reference to the remarks of the Inspector of Schools concerning the fire escapes, as contained in your letter of the 13th inst., I wish to make the following observations:

1. Due to the narrowness of the hand rail it would be rather difficult to put wooden rails on top so that they would remain permanently.

2. This precaution seems to me to be unnecessary, since the metal of the escapes is well covered with paint, which would prevent the metal from sticking to the hands of the school children, even in sub-zero weather, as the Inspector suggests.

Any further observations from yourself or the Department concerning this matter will be welcomed, by,

Yours truly,

Signed:— Rev. Alex. K. Simpson, C.M.I.,"

In discussing this matter with Constable Hae I found that his opinion was that the wood rails, on account of being exposed to the weather, would likely soon splinter and become equally as dangerous to the pupils as the iron railings. The principal agrees that the boys of the manual training class could do the work alright but that they have no material on hand that could be used for this purpose. Please advise, if in view of the principal's remarks given above, the Department considers that the suggestion of the inspector of schools should be put into effect.

Your obedient servant,

Jas. H. F. Lacey,

Sir:

An inspection of the sewage disposal system of the Lejac Indian Residential School, near Fraser Lake, B.C., was made on December 22, 1939, according to your instructions of November 27, 1939. The following is a report of the condition of the system. This report includes general information pertaining to the septic tank, a description of the condition of system at the time of inspection and suggested alterations. A detailed estimated cost of the proposed alterations is appended.

GENERAL

The Lejac School, built in 1920-21, is situated on the south side of Fraser Lake, a few hundred yards from the C.N.Railway track. The school is of considerable size and this year there are about 200 persons in residence, including students and staff. Water for the institution is obtained from Fraser Lake.

According to the school caretaker, approximately 3500 gals. are used in the school during an average day. A large percentage of this water is used for baths and for the flush toilets. There are approximately 20 flush toilets, 6 baths and 6 showers located in various parts of the building. On Saturdays, bath day at the school, 600 gals. of water are used in a period of 4 hours.

Waste water from the kitchen passes through a grease trap before reaching the septic tank. An inspection showed that the trap was working satisfactorily.

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer
Dominion Water & Power Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
The following disinfectants are used:
Lysol for disinfecting baths and sinks, chloride of lime for cleaning sinks and toilets and drain cleaner elsewhere.

Several years ago a bunkhouse was built for the farm and school workmen. This building is situated about a hundred yards west of the school. Approximately 10 years ago two flush toilets were installed and a four inch sewer laid from the bunkhouse to a point 180 feet from the school septic tank.

CONDITIONS AS FOUND ON DECEMBER 22, 1939.

General

The condition of the sewage disposal system of the school is not satisfactory. The filter bed is not operating and the effluent flows over the surface of the ground. Although the septic tank is functioning fairly well it can be improved. No objectionable odor was noticed in the vicinity of the septic tank at the time of inspection. Raw sewage from the bunkhouse is deposited on the ground within 250 feet of the school. Following is detailed description of the condition of the system and suggested improvements.

SEPTIC TANK AND FILTER BED

The capacity of the septic tank is rather small for an institution housing 200 people. However, the tank will operate satisfactorily if it receives reasonable attention.

At the time of inspection the septic tank was in an unsatisfactory condition. This condition was due partly to the need of cleaning. According to the school caretaker it was cleaned in July, 1938, seventeen months ago, which under normal conditions may
not be too long a period. Under the circumstances this is too long an interval and in the future it would be advisable to clean the tank more frequently.

The installation of a distribution gallery and baffle suggested later in the report, will improve the action of the tank and may lengthen the interval between cleanings.

Measurements were made of the thickness of scum and depth of sludge. There were two feet of scum on top and about three feet of sludge at the bottom of the tank. The sludge was in a well decayed condition and of good color.

An inspection showed the effluent compartment to be fairly clean and the effluent clear.

For the past six years the Miller syphon in the effluent compartment has not been operating and last year it was removed. The outlet was plugged with cement and now the effluent passes through the overflow pipe. The present state of the tank is shown on the attached whiteprint.

The filter bed has not been functioning for the past six years. Effluent runs from the tank to the distribution chamber at the head of the filter bed and then flows over the surface of the ground.

SEWAGE FROM THE BUNKHOUSE

There are two flush toilets in the bunkhouse. Sewage from them is carried in a 4" pipe and deposited on the ground at a point approximately 180 feet from the septic tank. This highly unsanitary condition has existed for the past ten years. The location of the sewer from the bunkhouse is shown on the attached whiteprint.
CHANGES IN SYSTEM

The following changes have been made in the system since it was installed:

1. Removal of Miller syphon last year.
2. Filter bed no longer operating.
3. Formerly the waste from the laundry passed through the septic tank but last year the pipe from the laundry was connected to the boiler blowdown pipe and laundry wastes no longer go through the tank. As 2500 gallons of water are used in the laundry over Monday this change should improve the action of the septic tank.

SUGGESTED ALTERATIONS AND IMPROVEMENTS

1. Sewage from the bunkhouse should either be carried to the school septic tank or treated in a separate tank. Owing to the long distance from the bunkhouse to the school tank it would be advisable to install a small septic tank adjacent to the bunkhouse even though the cost is slightly greater. The effluent may be carried to the proposed drain from the school septic tank by extending the present 4" sewer a hundred feet. The proposed extension of the drain is shown on the attached blueprint. A detailed drawing of the proposed septic tank is appended.

2. Install a distribution gallery and baffle board in lieu of present inlet to the school septic tank. This would reduce the inlet velocity and consequently there would be less disturbance of the sludge during periods of heavy flow. The action of the septic tank would be improved by the proposed distribution gallery.

3. Replace the manhole over the sludge compartment with a cleanout opening the full width of the tank. If the proposed distribution gallery is installed the existing manhole will have to be moved.
Rather than build the same size manhole a larger opening would be advisable. With the larger opening the tank could be cleaned more easily. A detailed drawing of the proposed distribution gallery and cleanout opening is appended.

4. At the present time the effluent from the septic tank is running over the surface of the ground. This condition could be remedied by reconditioning the filter bed and replacing the Miller syphon. If this policy were followed the system would operate satisfactorily until such time as the filter required further attention. Cleaning a filter 75 ft. x 50 ft. every few years would be expensive and consequently it may be advisable to dispose of the effluent by other means.

Proposed method of disposing of effluent:

Lay a 4" vitrified pipe from the existing 6" effluent drainpipe to a point about 500 feet away. The 4" drain should have about 4 feet of cover. (The location of this pipe is shown on the attached whiteprint). From the end of the drain the effluent would be carried in a shallow trench and distributed over a ploughed area. Two acres would be a large enough area. It would be advisable to build a fence around the ploughed area to prevent the school children from coming in contact with the contaminated soil. The effluent should be distributed over one part of this field for a few months and then over another part. The proposed disposal field would be entirely satisfactory and would not cause any objectionable nuisance.
The only attention required would be blocking off the distribution ditch every few months to allow the effluent to run over a new area and ploughing the field every year.

5. Large quantities of disinfectant hinder the action of the tank. The school authorities should be requested to use disinfectant in weak solutions which are quite effective.

The suggested alterations can be made at an estimated cost of $884.00. A detailed estimate of the proposed alterations is appended.

If the proposed alterations are made it would be advisable to do the work during the month of May or during the period September 1st to October 15th.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

While carrying out work on the sewage system of the Lejac Indian School, which was completed on the above date and left in good order, I took occasion to inspect the other services at the school and in this connection I wish to report as follows.

Water Supply

Water is obtained from Fraser Lake, situated about 1 mile from the school. The water is good and the supply abundant. The supply is pumped to an elevated tank situated about 2 miles from the lake and about 1000 feet from the school, through a 4 inch wood stave pipe. Originally the installation was made with 2 pneumatic tanks, 1500 gallons normal capacity, situated in the basement of the school, probably about 1923, but was altered to the elevated tank at a later date, pressure about 40 pounds static.

The pumping plant consists of 2 Fairbanks Morse horizontal type double acting 3" x 6" stroke pumps, #116995 and #99463 - belt connected to each side of Fairbanks Morse, 10 H.P., 350 RPM "Z" type horizontal gas engine C26287, pulleys 16" long to 23" pump. Plant will deliver 100 U.S. g.p.m. against 100 lbs. pressure. Pump house is frame building on concrete foundation over concrete well - 15 feet deep and on bedrock, into which a 6 foot pipe line leads from the lake.

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
The intake is situated at a distance of about 350 feet from pump house and lake depth at intake was 9 inches on August 15th. Normally the pipe line extends about 300 feet into the lake. There is a screen on the intake. A wooden settling box, 5 feet by 20 feet, is situated on the intake line a short distance from the pump house, to interrupt the flow of sand into the well by wave action. Pumping is not done when the wind is blowing if sufficient supply can be maintained. It is necessary to heat the pump house in winter. This is done by means of a stove.

It was noted that the gear covers on the pumps were missing. These should be replaced to guard against accidents. It was also noted that hold down bolts on one pump had no nuts, and that one bearing on #95465 pump had a broken housing cover, also that the crank guard on the engine was missing. This should be replaced.

Storage Tank

Wooden storage tank, 20000 gallons capacity, built on wooden tower about 20 feet high, all enclosed in frame building, provided with stove for heating in winter. Tank building appears to be in good condition, no leaks evident. Ashes are allowed to accumulate around the wooden pedestals supporting the tank and the walls of the building. These should be removed to prevent decay.

Fire Protection System

3 outside fire hydrants and about 200 feet of 2 inch cotton rubberlined hose on a reel. Inside hydrants and hose, also hand bomb fire extinguishers.
All appear to be kept in fair order. Iron fire escapes appear to be in good order - said to be dangerous due to ice and snow in winter.

**Heating System**

This is said to be operating satisfactorily. Wood fuel used. There is thought to be a leak in return line to boilers under concrete floors, possibly due to corrosion. This probably needs replacement as shows no signs of replacement in approximately 20 years school has been built.

**Electric Light Plant**

Consists of 1 - 6 horsepower and 1 - 9 horsepower Lister oil engine generator plant. Connected for individual or multiple operation, with switchboard. Appear to be in good operating condition.

**Laundry Machinery**

The laundry machinery consisting of a horizontal barrel washer and an extractor appear to be operating satisfactorily. A new 15 horsepower steam boiler was being installed at the time of my visit.

**Refrigeration Plant**

This plant was not in operating condition at the time of my visit although work was being carried out to put it in operating condition in part. It consists of 1 ton ammonia plant with 2 cooling chambers. Congealing tank and coils of larger chamber in bad condition. Leaks were evident in the high pressure circuit as well. There should not be the necessity for a plant of this nature at Lejac as there is always an abundance of ice.
in Fraser lake about ½ mile from the school which, with adequate storage capacity, should provide for all cooling requirements of the school probably at less cost than for artificial cooling.

The school building appears to be in good condition and reasonably well maintained. Outside painting will probably be necessary within the next two years.

Your obedient servant,

W.C. Warren
Ottawa,
October 9, 1940.

Dear Mr. Howe:

I wish to make formal report of a fire which occurred here last night. About ten-thirty one of the farm help discovered that the chicken house was on fire and gave the alarm. The fire had already taken firm hold of the west end of the chicken house, and our efforts had to be confined to trying to save as much of the remainder as possible.

About two thirds of the building was totally destroyed. The third section of the building was slightly damaged. We had been preparing the buildings in order to put the chickens inside for the winter and had started a fire in the stove to dry out the interior of the chicken house. Somehow, we cannot determine exactly just how it happened, the roof caught fire and the blaze spread very rapidly, despite all of our efforts to check it.

Our estimate of the damage is about $1200.00 for the buildings, and about $350.00 for equipment. The chickens were still on summer range, so none of them were lost. Rebuilding will have to be done immediately, so as to provide shelter for our 1100 birds before freeze-up.

This represents quite a serious loss for the school. We have found chicken and egg producing to be quite profitable, and of great assistance to the school. Will you kindly bring this matter to the attention of the department at once; and earnestly request that we might obtain some assistance in making good the loss that we have suffered through this unfortunate fire?

Thanking you for your valued cooperation in this matter,

I remain,

Very truly yours,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that a fire occurred at the Lejac Indian Residential School Farm on the 17th instant completely destroying two thirds and damaging the third section of the poultry house. Attached hereto is a report from the Rev. Principal covering the fire.

According to my investigation the fire started about 10-30 P.M. on the 17th. The alarm was sounded immediately and a fire hose from the nearest hydrant brought into action. Apparently a strong wind was blowing and they were only able to save a part of the section. The other two sections were totally destroyed. The cause of the fire is difficult to determine. There is no doubt it originated from the stove which had been lighted to air the house ready for transfer of the chickens from the summer pens to winter quarters. The stove is encased in cement with an iron firebox door and about three lengths of 6" stove pipe to brick chimney. It is quite possible the fire started from a loose stove pipe connection or the fire box door may have been carelessly left ajar.

The building destroyed measured 120' X 30' X 8' built in three sections 40 feet to a section of frame construction, double sheeting with sawdust filling, Ruberoid roofing and concrete foundation which is undamaged.

There is no other building available to house the chickens for the winter. It is therefore necessary to rebuild immediately. The damage is estimated at $1550-00. This sum includes $350-00 for loss of equipment, brooders, incubators, troughs, etc.

The Rev. Principal earnestly requests some financial assistance from the Department to make good the loss. No definite amount is stated in his letter but would recommend that an amount equivalent to half the damage sustained be granted for rebuilding purposes.

Your obedient servant,
