Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to Mr. Indian Agent Howe's Letter S-2-41 of the 24th instant, I have noted that considerable damage was done by fire to the chicken house at the Le Jac Indian Day School on the 17th instant.

The erection of the chicken house in question was, I believe, undertaken by the Reverend Father Byrne-Grant, O.M.I., while Principal of the school, though I do not know that the Department made any special grant for such construction, which was undertaken in 1937 mainly by the Manual Training class.

The keeping of chickens, as described in my report on the Le Jac School, dated October 26, 1937, is no doubt a profitable project as the authorities are provided at small cost with an important part of the children's diet.

I am, however, of the opinion that the Department should not be called upon for any special grant with respect to the replacement of the buildings destroyed by fire. Should the Reverend Principal wish to continue the keeping of chickens at Le Jac, he will no doubt be able to finance any necessary re-building out of the per capita grant, or from the funds of the Oblate Order.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith requisition for a proposed expenditure of $1985-00 for much needed repairs to the exterior of Lejac Indian Residential School Block. The repairs considered necessary are itemised on the requisition.

The roof and exterior of the School has not been painted since construction over 20 years ago. Quite a number of the shingles are rotted and curled up. The outside casings, eaves troughs and drain pipes are badly weathered and practically devoid of paint. Mr. Engineer Warren of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau in the last paragraph of his report dated August 17th, 1940 mentions that the repairs in question should be undertaken within the space of two years.

Attached hereto a tender from Mr. P.A. Andersen, General Contractor, Prince George, B.C., who, as far as I can ascertain is the only Contractor in the District equipped and capable of handling this class of work. Mr. Andersen built the chimneys at the School in 1939 and other buildings in previous years. His services were considered very satisfactory.

Included in the tender are two alternatives, 1st. one coat of paint on casings, roof, and shingle replacements at a cost of $190-00. 2nd. shingle replacements and two coats of stain on roof only $765-00. In the opinion of Mr. Andersen and the writer the first alternative should be ruled out completely. A single coat of paint on the roof and casings in its present condition would be ineffective.

However, if the amount $1985-00 for shingle replacements and two coats of paint throughout is not available it is recommended that the second alternative be accepted for repairs to roof only. This is considered urgent, as yet no leaks have been noted, but unless repairs to the roof are carried out soon leakages can be expected. You will note from a letter attached to the requisition that Mr. Andersen will probably be able to do the job, but due to the scarcity of labour and circumstances beyond his control would not care to guarantee it.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your favor of July 28th, file 215-13-9514, on the subject of inspection of the 5 H.P. Lister Engine which was sent in from the above school.

We have now received a report from our Diesel Mechanic, who has dismantled this engine completely, and we are able to give below, an estimate on the cost of re-fitting.

We are glad to report that the crankshaft, and main bearings appear to be in good shape, as we cannot detect any deflection, so that it would appear to be profitable to rebuild the engine.

The cylinder head has a crack along side one of the valve seats, and the cost of replacing this head is $60.00.

Another large item is the reboring of the cylinder and fitting an oversize piston, and it will be necessary to make a pattern for the piston. After these repairs are completed, the engine could be expected to give satisfactory operation for a number of years.

We would quote as follows:

Dear Mr. Howe:

It has been found that our small (5 h.p.) Lister Engine and generator, is in bad shape and needs immediate repairs.

The main shaft is bent, and the cylinder needs to be honed out and fitted with new piston. I would suggest that this engine be sent down to Hoffars in Vancouver and given a complete overhaul.

The Rev. Principal of the Lejas Indian Residential School reported on the 27th inst. that the sewage disposal system at the School is out of order and that immediate repairs are necessary. It was also reported that underpinnings supporting the water tank are rotten and should be replaced.

I inspected the sewage system yesterday and it would appear the field pipe from the cesspool is broken, probably at several points, causing a leakage in two places about 150 yards from the School building. The stench is horrible and certainly not sanitary.

The 12" X 12" underpinnings supporting the water tower are quite decayed at the ends and should be either spliced or replaced altogether. The tank holds a heavy load of water and is liable to collapse if repairs are not done in the near future.

Mr. Engineer Warren of the Dominion Water Power Branch repaired the sewage system at the School three years ago and I would suggest he be sent to Lejas as soon as possible to inspect and report on the system and the water tower.

At the same time I would like to have a report on necessary repairs to the foundation of the girls' playroom in the main school building. This item was included in the estimates for the current year.

Dear Sir:

Further to our conversation re your Department wishing a detailed statement of my extra costs in connection with job at LeJac Indian School, I would first state that the sum of $460, my original tender was not a liberal amount for that work.

I did inspect the work in a general way before pricing the job, more particularly with respect to suitable gravel and dry jackpine poles for false work etc. From the look of the country one would expect to get eighteen poles twenty feet long in that district, but found I had to haul them a distance of twenty-five miles. The gravel at the beach looked o.k., but upon closer examination found it too dirty for cement work, so had to cut out an old gravel road some ten miles away.

The additional cost, as explained in my last letter, was caused by the extra bolts, both top and bottom. The bottom, because of the small space to work in, and the top caused additional staging, for the reason that I could not swing the braces as I had figured, but had to take the entire brace off.

I naturally figured the job from the plan and specification.

I had to make two trips to Vanderhoof with a truck (the only unit I had on the job) to get the extra bolts.

The shortage of labor was an important factor in the additional costs. I paid three carpenters $1.25 per hour to do this work.

Yours truly,

"S. W. Cocker."

Dear Sir:

I am pleased to be able to report that my contract to repair water tank supporting framework at Lejac Industrial School is now completed.

You will observe from Drawing No. 202 from which I estimated this job that the ends of all braces and girts, only one bolt is shown, but when I arrived on the job, to do the work, I found two bolts at ends of all braces and girts. PROPERTY

A considerable amount of painting and kalsomining in the halls and dormitories and dining rooms was done during the summer. Once again we have to face the winter with a building that is almost impossible to heat due to the looseness of windows and doors. For several years we have been trying to get the exterior wood surfaces of the house painted, but have been unable to do so owing to the shortage of labour.

We find that our electrical output is now insufficient for our needs, and suggest that a larger Diesel generator be obtained by the Department from the War Assets Corporation. An output of at least 15 kw. would be desirable.

The boiler inspector made certain recommendations regarding our hot water supply which I hope will be accepted, because we are woefully short of hot water on bath days.

Re: Dough Mixer for the Lejac School.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt this morning of a letter from Reverend Father A.R. Simpson, O.M.I., principal of the above school, in which he requests me to ask for a dough mixer for his school.

The authorized pupilage of this school is 160 and if we add the staff and the personnel, along with the extra pupils that they always have, the number of persons for whom the baking is done, is at least 200. That number corresponds with the figures of 1200 lbs. of flour which is being used weekly in the school. As baking four times a week is about the general practice in our residential schools, I believe that a dough mixer capable of handling three bags of flour, would be the proper one to buy.

The older girls of the school were in the habit of doing all the work in the baking room but due to war conditions the girls are now much younger and unable to perform this task satisfactorily. I, therefore, hope that you will be able to meet with Father Simpson's wishes in this matter.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Flourde, O.M.I.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Water Supply, Lejac Indian Residential School, Lejac, B.C.

Introduction

Following instructions received in your letter of November 14, 1945, I made an inspection of the intake and pumping plant at Lejac Indian Residential School on November 21.

Present Water Supply

Lejac Indian School is situated on the shore of Fraser Lake about three miles east of Fraser Lake railway station and about ten miles east of Endeko, a divisional point on the Jasper-Prince Rupert Branch of the Canadian National Railway. The water supply for the school is obtained from the lake by means of pumps which pump the water from a well on the lake shore to a 20,000 gallon elevated wood stave tank situated about 1,000 feet from the school and a half-mile from the lake.

The pump house is of frame construction on a concrete foundation over a concrete well thirteen feet deep to bed rock. The pumping is done by two Fairbanks Morse horizontal type double-acting 3½" x 6" stroke pumps, belt connected to each side of a 10 H.P. Fairbanks Morse horizontal gas engine. This plant will deliver 100 U.S. gallons per minute against 100-pounds pressure.

The water enters the pump house well through an intake pipe, the screened intake being in the lake about 300 feet from the well. On the intake line and about 40 feet from the well is a wooden settling box, 5 feet wide and...
16 feet long to interrupt the flow of sand and gravel into the well. From this box the water is carried into the well by an 8-inch pipe.

The intake system has been working satisfactorily and ordinarily there is no drop in the water level of the well when both pumps are operating.

Reason for Inspection

On November 8 of this year the Principal of the School reported to the Indian Agent at Vanderhoof that owing to the low level of Fraser Lake, the intake pipe from the lake was exposed to frost and there was a grave danger of the domestic water supply for the school being cut off completely by freezing in the near future.

Inspection November 21, 1945.

On examining the well I found it to be 14½ feet deep, measured from the floor of the pump house, with a depth of water of 8½ feet. There appeared to be gravel on the well bottom.

Both pumps were put in operation and after about an hour's pumping the water in the well had been lowered eighteen inches and the pumps were starting to suck air. I was informed that the intake pipes from the pumps used to extend deeper into the well, but were shortened because of the tendency to suck up gravel from the well bottom. As this shortage of water coming into the well could only be caused by a plugging up of the intake pipe from the lake, and as under those circumstances the school did not have adequate water for fire protection, I suggested that the intake pipe be uncovered without delay so that the obstruction could be found and removed.
An examination of the intake showed the following arrangement (see plan attached):

1. A wooden settling box 5 feet wide and 16 feet long, divided into two 5 x 8 sections by a cross partition, is placed on the intake line about forty feet from the pump house. The box was originally eight feet deep but during the high water of last spring floating logs knocked off the top two feet and the plank cover. The bottom of the box was 4½ feet below the water surface. This box is necessary to allow the sand which is stirred up by wave action to settle out before the water goes into the well.

2. The settling box was connected to the pump house well by an 8-inch iron pipe about four feet below the water level.

3. An 8-inch iron pipe about 200 feet long extended out into the lake with a screen arrangement on the lake end. It was difficult to see exactly what the intake arrangement was but the screen appeared to be partially blocked with fungus and slime. The water was 3.5 feet deep at the intake, with the top of the pipe 2.6 feet below the surface. All of this pipe except the last sixty feet in the lake was underground and it is presumed that this was originally laid level, but that the shore end has gradually been heaved up by the frost since at this end the top of the pipe is only 1.6 feet below the water surface.

4. Between the shore end of the iron pipe and the settling box was a space of about twenty feet, which I was informed was left as a filter. Subsequently this was opened up and there was found to be a wooden box pipe made of 2 x 10 plank between the end of the iron pipe and the settling box, but though it was connected to the box, there was no connection with the iron pipe; the ends of the two being separated by about three feet of gravel. This wooden box pipe was 21 inches below the level of the water.
Inspection November 26.

Another call was made at the school on November 26. In the meantime the wooden box pipe between the iron intake pipe and the settling box had been opened up and was found to be blocked up with gravel. This condition had been corrected and the water was running freely into the well. As this part of the intake was definitely subject to freezing during a severe winter it was decided to cover it over with a big bank of snow for protection until the system could be put into proper working order at a later date.

From these inspections it was evident that the iron intake pipe in the lake was not functioning at all, the water evidently entering the settling box through the wooden box pipe which, being unscreened, eventually became full of sand and gravel.

Inspection of Lake Outlet

With the idea of determining whether or not it might be feasible to raise the level of Fraser Lake by a small dam at the outlet and also to find out how much lower the lake could drop, an examination was made of the lake outlet.

The water leaves Fraser Lake in two channels, separated by a low willow-covered island, evidently flooded at higher stages. (See attached sketch plan). The right hand channel was about 700 feet wide at the narrowest point, with a maximum depth of 0.3 feet. The left hand channel was 164 feet wide, with a maximum depth of 2.8 feet. The bottom was sandy for one to one and a half feet, and below that was hard blue clay.

These two channels come together into one stream about three-quarters of a mile below the lake outlet and just above the highway bridge. Here the stream is about 200 feet wide with a maximum depth of three feet. The fall
from the lake outlet to the highway bridge is 0.4 feet. An excellent aerial view of this outlet is shown in the attached photograph from "Report on Aerial Reconnaissance of Water Resources in the North Pacific Region", by C.E. Webb and dated February 12, 1944.

Previous Reports

In a report by Mr. E.H. Trederoft, dated June, 1923, he proposes a well and pumping plant similar to that now in operation, with an intake from the lake, but no details of the intake are given. The system was apparently installed along the lines of this proposal in the latter part of 1923, under the supervision of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Recommendations

Since the present system has been working satisfactorily except for the accumulation of gravel in the wooden box pipe (which can be cleaned without any great difficulty) the only requirement is to adequately protect the intake system from frost. This could be accomplished in two ways:

1. Raising the lake level
2. Changing the intake layout.

The first of these alternatives is not recommended because of the expense of building and maintaining the necessary dam, the possibility of interfering with the movement of spawning fish and the possible objection of farmers who have hay meadows on the lake shore.

I would therefore recommend that the intake be remodelled in the following manner (see plan attached):

1. Discard the iron pipe in the lake. The system has been working satisfactorily without it and it is therefore not necessary. It is also likely that this pipe would fill with sand and would require flushing out from time to time.
2. Repair the present settling box by replacing the part that has been broken off.

3. Place or drive ten 2-inch sand points horizontally toward the lake and connect each one to the settling box by a 20-foot length of 2-inch galvanized iron pipe. By this means the necessary volume of water will be supplied to the settling box, from which it will enter the well by the present installation.

This work should be undertaken during the present low water and after the extreme cold weather.

Estimate of Cost

The total cost of this work is estimated at $625.00. Details of the anticipated expenditure supporting this estimate are shown in Appendix I.

T.H. Boyd
Field Engineer

Attached in duplicate is a report by Mr. T.H. Boyd, dealing with suggested changes in the intake works for the water supply from Fraser Lake serving the Lejac Indian Residential School.

It would appear that the present water supply is being successfully obtained from the saturated gravel along the shore of the Lake. It is proposed to eliminate the intake pipe which is not connected directly to the intake well, and substitute a battery of ten sand points to draw and conduct the water into the settling box and thence via the present pipe to the intake well. The sand points are to be placed about a foot lower in elevation than the present entrance to the settling box, which should give extra protection from the effects of frost.

Dear Sir: Re: Mechanical and Electrical Plant -
Indian Residential School, Le Jac, B.C.

With reference to the letter of March 13th, 1946 from Mr. D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., enclosing letters from Survey and Engineering Branch, dated February 11th and March 7th, 1946, regarding the above and requesting further information, I beg to report as follows:

This plant was installed in 1933 and at that time, the estimated peak load was 6 K.W. What the actual peak load at the present time is, I cannot definitely say, but would be safe in assuming an increase of 30%. This will bring the present peak load to 7.8 K.W.

What the future requirements will be is quite hard to say, when you take into consideration an institution of this type where the student body and staff numbers over 100, and all modern appliances are electrically operated. You can readily assume that the electric load will gradually increase until it reaches the capacity of the supply.

When I recommended a 14 H.P. cold starting Diesel and a 7 K.W. 120 V. D.C. generator, I took the following into consideration:

In my report, dated August 29th, 1934, after the first season's operation, I pointed out that the plant was too small for peak load requirements. It has been operating under these conditions for the past 13 years.

The present plant is of English manufacture, and I doubt if there is a new spare part available at the present time anywhere in Canada or even at the factory. It has given remarkable service and reflects great credit on the manufacturer and the operating Engineer, but has reached the stage where a complete overhaul and renewal of parts are required.

I recommended the 7 K.W. plant because when it is running in conjunction with either of the two present units, it will give a 9½ or a 11½ K.W. electric supply and in case either of the present units are out of commission, could take most of the load.

I must also call your attention to the very isolated position of this school. The nearest point where supplies can be obtained is Edmonton, Alberta — 30 train hours away and Vancouver, B. C. — 58 train hours.

You can readily see the importance of getting a new unit, even if it is a K.W. or two over my recommendation.

Yours sincerely,

T. J. Arnall

T. J. Arnall,
S.P.P. Engineer.

Mr. T.H. Boyd, who made the inspection, submitted a report which has been condensed as follows, for your information:

1. There are 2-50" diameter x 14'-8" long horizontal return tubular brickset heating boilers and they are in first class condition. Either boiler should be able to handle the load.

2. Wood is used as fuel and Mr. Boyd states that 300 cords are used during the heating season; which is obtained at a cost of $5.00 per cord. Wood is plentiful but labour conditions make it difficult to arrange for cutting.

3. The report states that a low grade coal is obtainable from the mines at Telkwa, about 160 miles away, and could be supplied to the School at $8.00 per ton.

4. Oil is also available, but owing to the electric plant at the School being fully loaded, No. 1 grade oil or a distillate product, would have to be used. This would cost about fourteen cents per gallon. Please note that in order to burn the cheaper grades of oil, electric pre-heaters are required as part of the oil burning equipment.

5. Regarding complaints of an inadequacy in the domestic hot water supply, the report states that a jacket heater of 350 gallon capacity is used in connection with a 600 gallon storage tank.

6. Other items in the report giving data on the high pressure boiler and laundry service, do not enter into the picture. It can be stated that the report gives sufficient data to enable us to comment on the existing conditions and to recommend revisions to the plant which should overcome existing complaints.

Regarding the Principal's request that the boilers be converted to the use of oil, the following analysis is submitted:

The school has a heating load of 6000 square feet of equivalent direct radiation. This figure was obtained from a survey of the original drawings. Forecasting fuel requirements for oil, based on the latest available data and figured from 0° Fahrenheit to 70° Fahrenheit, it would seem that 45,000 gallons of oil would be required. This oil would have to be No. 1 or Diesel oil and is priced at fourteen cents per gallon, which would make the season's fuel bill $6,300.00. Combustion efficiencies of about 75 per cent could reasonably be expected.

If coal, of a type available were used, it is anticipated that 450 tons would be required for the season, which, at a cost of $8.00 per ton would amount to $3,600.00. Using coal, hand fired, combustion efficiencies of about 55 per cent could be expected. Comparing the costs, therefore, we have:

- 300 cords of wood @ $5.00 per cord (Mr. Bury's figures) $1,500.00
- 45,000 gallons No.1 fuel oil @ .14¢ gallon $6,300.00
- 450 tons low grade coal (assumed output 10,000 B.T.U. per lb.) @ $8.00 $3,600.00

It should be borne in mind that to convert to oil it is estimated that equipment including tanks, burner for one boiler; and pumping apparatus (oil must be pumped from railway siding 1000 feet away) would cost about $6,000.00. No mention is made in the report of the type of pump or its drive required to do this work.

It is also pointed out that if coal is used, apart from some relatively minor expenses in connection with possible new grates and ash removal facilities, there would be no major items. It is roughly estimated that $1,000.00 to $1,500.00 would cover such changes.

It is our opinion that until such time as electric current can be supplied to the building by a Power Company, it would be uneconomical to use oil. Heavy grades of oil are cheaper than No. 1 distillate but they require electric pre-heating and as previously stated, the School's electrical plant being already fully loaded could not provide current for this purpose.

Regarding the lack of hot water, it appears, after a study of the data contained in the report, that the present method of heating the water is at fault. A careful analysis reveals that a peak demand of 500 gallons of water per hour must be met according to accepted principles. One jacket heater, stated to be good for a 350 gallon tank, is in use in connection with a 600 Imperial gallon storage tank.

Since there is more than ample boiler capacity, it is recommended that an indirect steam fed heater having a capacity to heat 600 Imperial gallons of water per hour through a 100 degree raise, be provided. The existing storage tank should be retained but should be fitted with a new hot water self-contained regulating valve.

For summer.........
For summer service, one new high-test jacket heater, capable of raising 450 gallons per hour through 100° raise when hand fired with coal or wood, should be provided. Some revisions of a relatively minor nature to the piping will be necessary.

Below is a summary of the recommendations with an estimate of the cost involved:

(1) Provide new grates for boilers, ash disposal facilities and accessory items - $1,500.00

(2) Provide one new indirect steam fed heater with cast iron shell and removable copper tube element - $500.00

(3) Provide hot water self-contained regulating valve with accessory piping connections, etc. - $150.00

(4) Provide one new high-test jacket heater - $300.00

(5) Pressure relief valve, piping and fittings - $50.00

Total - $2,500.00

Labour - $1,000.00

Total - $3,500.00

Contingencies 10% - $350.00

Total - $3,850.00

Mr. R. Howe, Indian Agent, Vanderhoof, B.C.

The Department is now in receipt of a report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch regarding their recent inspection of the mechanical equipment at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

They have stated that the cost of heating the school and forwarded the following estimate:

1. 300 cords wood at $5.00 a cord (Mr. Boyd's figure) $1,500.00

2. 45,000 gals. fuel oil @ .14¢ a gal. 6,300.00

3. 430 tons low grade coal @ $.80 3,440.00.

You will note from the above that the cost of heating is much cheaper with wood than with either oil or coal.

The change from the present heating system to either oil or coal would cost approximately $3,850.00.

At the present time we are not in a position to favourably consider the expenditure that would be requested and as there does not appear to be any necessity for immediate action it has been decided to postpone further consideration until next year.
It has been reported that some difficulty has been experienced in properly heating the top floor. The reason given is that the windows are poorly fitted. The Surveys and Engineering Branch state that this can be remedied by weather-stripping being placed on the windows.

The work of putting on the weather-stripping could be done by the school staff and it is presumed that the cost of material would not be excessive. You may, therefore, purchase what is required.

Bernard F. Neary,
Sup't of Welfare & Training.

Re: Improvements at Lejac Indian Res. School, B.C.
Attention: Mr. F. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I found Lejac to be a modern and up to date school, in good condition. It is certainly a credit to your Department.

The following have been requested by the principal and I hope that his requests will be favourably considered:

(1) The pupilage is now 170. The principal has had at least 185 on the roll and he now asks that the pupilage be increased by at least 15. In his case, as well as in the case of all the B.C. principals, it is becoming impossible to keep children for whom no grant is received.

(2) This school is without any battery and the engine has to be started every time lights are needed. The engine, therefore, is running during the whole night. Consequently, this is very expensive and is also a fire hazard which should not exist.

(3) The school never had a frigidaire and should be provided with one out of the 1946-47 vote. One similar to that provided for Beauval, or St. Phillips would be sufficient.

(4) You have been mailing, for several years past, the school cheque to the bank manager at Prince George. This is useless and is only causing delay and annoyance. I know that you are not to blame for this but you will want, I am sure, to correct this strange anomaly.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Very truly yours,

J. J. Plourde, O.M.I.

June 6, 1923.

Dear Mr. Foran,

I beg to inclose herewith requisition for the extension of the temporary certificate in favour of Mr. Myles Morley as Inspector of Construction at the Fraser Lake Indian school. The last temporary certificate which was issued on his behalf expired on March 16, but, owing to the fact that some additional work had to be done, which was not foreseen, it was necessary to retain his services to May 31. He was written to, however, and advised that his services must cease on that date.

Yesterday we received a telegram to the effect that a fire had broken out in the Fraser Lake school, which had caused about $1500.00 worth of damage, and, as immediate steps had to be taken to have the repairs made, we instructed Mr. Morley to proceed to the school, and to superintend the carrying out of the necessary work by day labour. I am making the extension to cover the period for which Mr. Morley has been employed, and the time we expect it will take to repair the school.

I note from your letter of February 12, last, your file IA-IA2-362, that, if Mr. Morley's services are again to be utilized, you would like the position advertised, if considered necessary by the Commission, but it would be impossible for us to make a contract for the work, owing to the isolated location of the building and the fact that we do not call for tenders for repairs. The case is very urgent, and, as we know of no one available in British Columbia as well qualified to do the work as Mr. Morley, we trust you will favourably consider his appointment.

Yours very truly,

Wm. Foran, Esq.,

OTTAWA, February 26th, 1924.

Sir,

I beg to ask your attention to the payments made by you to Mr. Myles Morley, as Inspector of Construction at the Fraser Lake Indian Boarding School, since July, 1922.

Mr. Morley was paid during the fiscal years 1922-23 for 224 days at $6 a day, being for every day included in the period from July 16th, 1922, to February 26th, 1923, with the exception of 4 days in July. During the current fiscal year he has been paid continuously at the same rate from March 1st to May 31st. On looking over the returns for previous years I find that Mr. Morley was paid continuously at the same rate, from October 15th, 1919 to February 26th, 1922, while engaged on inspection work on other schools.

The rates established in the Classification List for the position of Inspector of Construction are:

Monthly - $100, 105, 110, etc., to $140.
Daily - Prevailing rates not exceeding $7 for services as required.

I understand this to mean that when the employment is not continuous the inspector may be paid up to $7 a day for those days only on which he is actually engaged on the work, but that when the employment is continuous the monthly rates shall apply. The prevailing rates paid during any month should not exceed the maximum monthly rate of $140.

I should

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
I should also like to ask your attention to the dates on which the certificates for Mr. Horley's employment were issued by the Civil Service Commission. On February 9th, 1928, a certificate for his employment for six months from July 16th, 1927, was issued, and on the same date a second certificate extending his employment to March 16th was issued; again on June 15th a certificate was issued further extending his employment to July 16th. As Mr. Horley received his pay regularly month by month it would appear that his pay cheques were issued in a number of cases prior to the authorisation of his employment. I trust you will take steps to prevent the recurrence of a like irregularity in the future.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

as, Auditor General.

February 27, 1924.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, with reference to payments made by this Department to Mr. Myles Morley as Inspector of Construction at the Fraser Lake Indian boarding school since July, 1922. I have noted what you say, that is, that when an Inspector of Construction is employed continuously during the month his services should be paid at the monthly rate.

In reply I beg to say that the certificates of temporary appointment were issued by the Civil Service Commission for certain specified periods with remuneration at the rate of $6.00 per day. No mention was made of a monthly rate, and the Department paid at the rate which was provided for in the certificates. However, in the future we will be guided by your interpretation of the regulations, and, in employing men as Inspectors of Construction, we will specify that they are to be paid at the rate of $6.00 per day, but that their monthly remuneration must not exceed $140.00, the maximum provided under the classification schedule.

The last paragraph of your letter has been noted.

Yours very truly,

Wm. Kearns, Esq.,
Asst. Auditor General,
Ottawa.

With reference to the Department's telegram dated February 11th last, I beg to enclose herewith, Voucher No. 145 for $234.00 in favour of Mr. C.F. Freeman, Prince George, P.C., for 14 second-hand radiators, replacing 13 radiators damaged beyond repair by recent severe sub-zero temperatures at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

Prior to my telegram requesting authority to purchase the radiators, I engaged Mr. R.M. Patterson, a local Mechanic and experienced Welder to inspect the damaged radiators at the Lejac School, to ascertain if it was feasible to weld the broken seams. We found that practically every seam, both inside and outside the sections, were open, and definitely beyond repair. I am enclosing Voucher No. 146 for $10.50, in favour of Mr. Patterson, for wages in this connection.

The second-hand replacements were formerly in use at the Prince George Military Camp for two seasons only, and they are in excellent condition, and very reasonably priced compared to new radiators which are practically impossible to obtain.

A Voucher covering the freighting of the radiators from Prince George to the Lejac School will be submitted shortly.

(Sgd. R. Howe,
Indian Agent.)

I beg to enclose herewith, a requisition with Tenders attached from G.H. Adomeit & Co., General Contractors, Smithers, B.C., for painting all exterior woodwork, fire escapes, screen and storm windows at the Lejac Indian Residential School, also Tender for supplying and making fifty storm windows.

The exterior facings have not been painted since the School was built in 1921, and it is in a very dilapidated condition. Re-puttying all windows and cracks and additional storm windows are urgently required in order to prevent a recurrence of conditions during the sub-zero temperatures last winter, when 15 radiators were frozen beyond repair and had to be replaced at considerable expense.

The roof of the School building was given two coats of stain 5 years ago, but judging from its appearance, it is considered another coat is essential while the painters are on the job.

We have been endeavoring for the past 4 years to obtain Tenders for this work, but due to circumstances beyond control, we were unable to interest any Firm in the work, until this year. As far as I am aware the G.H. Adomeit Company is the only competent Firm available for this type of work in the entire district.

Dear Mr. Howe:

In commenting on Major MacKay's letter of April 24th. re the relative urgency of the painting and repairs required at this school, and the changes suggested in the heating system by the Surveys and Engineering Branch; there can be no question that the painting and repairs should receive top priority.

The present state of many of the windows in the building makes it impossible to heat this house, no matter what kind of heating system might be employed, or how much fuel consumed. During the cold spell of last winter we were seriously considering the possibility of having to send a number of the children home; parts of the building being absolutely uninhabitable.

Mr. Boyd, the engineer who made the survey of the heating system, stated that the heating system of the building proper was adequate, and I agree with him. I would not expect the Department to spend $10,000.00 here to install an oil-burning system. Last winter, at our own expense, we converted one of the heating boilers from wood to coal. This boiler consumed about 200 tons of coal during the winter. The other boiler burned about 150 cords of wood, and was only fired when the coal burner was unable to heat the building alone.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
VANCOUVER, B.C.

I beg to enclose herewith, a requisition with Tender attached from the Fraser Lake Mills, Fraser Lake, B.C., for 174 peeled pine logs for repairs to the root cellar at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

The walls of the root cellar collapsed completely last spring, and it is essential that the cellar is placed in good condition for storage of roots and vegetables before next winter.

The Rev. Principal advises that although he is short of labour at the School, he will arrange for labour re-constructing the cellar without cost to the Department.

I am enclosing a Tender for the material from the Fraser Lake Mills, Fraser Lake, B.C. In view of the long haul and the fact that Indians in the neighborhood are otherwise gainfully employed, I was unable to obtain a Tender from the Indians for the logs required.

Lejac Indian Residential School  
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers  
Lejac, B.C.

Oct. 27 1947

Mr. R. Howe  
Indian Agent  
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Sir,

I am submitting a request for an increase in grant and my reasons are as follows.

1) FARMING. In this locality, according to meteorological reports, there is an average of sixty-five frost-free days a year. This does not give sufficient time for crops to mature. During the past four years there have been two complete crop failures. In 1945 $4000 was spent for feed for the stock at this school. The cash crop for farmers in the Prince George area is grass seed but it is not a practical crop for an Indian school. The grant given to schools that have farms is always smaller but in this case I think consideration should be taken of the fact that this farm is north of the fifty-fourth parallel where farming is not a paying proposition.

2) FREIGHT RATES. The cost of bringing one hundred pounds of repacked groceries from Vancouver is $2.67 or $3.40 a ton. For sacked grain or vegetables it is $1.69 per cwt. or $35.20 a ton. It strikes a medium of over $40.00 a ton. This is in comparison with $7.00 a ton to the Sechelt, Port Alberni, Christie and Alert Bay Schools.

3) CLOTHING. More warm clothing must be supplied in this area than on the coastal schools or those in the southerly parts of the country. In this backward district where the parents do not willingly send their children to school they do not furnish any of the clothing at all.

4) VACATION. Many of the children come from far off places and do not go home during the holidays. There were over forty children here for the holidays last year. At other schools the vacation time is the period when finances can be recuperated for the remainder of the year.

5) WAGES. Wages have increased during the past year. In this isolated spot inducements must be offered to the men and we have to compete with the logging camps in the vicinity. For the four men on the farm, manager, barn man, gardener and labourer the yearly wage is $5040. For engineer, carpenter and disciplinarian the yearly wage is $4020. This does not include other staff members.
Lejac Indian Residential School
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers
Lejac, B.C.

6) FIRE LOSS. A fire which took place last week destroyed $3000 worth of feed and $500 worth of barn equipment. The weather in this country was so rainy during the harvest months that the hay could not be properly cured. This condition was probably the cause of this loss.

The school is gradually going deeper into debt every year and it cannot keep on at this pace. In September when I took charge there was a deficit at the bank of $11000 and outstanding bills of approximately $3000. Would it be possible for the auditor to come here in the near future and audit the books having in view an estimation of the cost of running the school. Using these figures as a basis for setting an equitable grant.

Hoping this will meet with favourable consideration.

Yours truly

LEJAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

MEMORANDUM

November 18, 1947
Vancouver, B.C.

TO: The Indian Commissioner for B. C.

FROM: The Inspector of Indian Schools.

RE: Lejac Indian Residential School
Application for increased grant

I refer to Mr. Indian Agent Howe's letter of November 6th and the attached letter from the Principal of the above mentioned school. I feel that I am not in a position to make any recommendation with regard to the amount of any increase that might be allotted to this school. This should be based upon the per capita cost of operation and I have no information as to how much this is. At the present time there are three schools in this Province which exceed the per capita grant of the Lejac Residential School. These are: The Alberni Residential School - per capita grant, $225, The Christie Residential School - per capita grant, $235, and the Crosby Girls home - per capita grant $245. The present per capita grant for the Lejac School is $220. Due to the size of the Crosby Girls home it is not a satisfactory basis for comparison. There is no doubt in my mind that the cost of operating the Lejac School is higher than either of the other two schools which may be compared with it. The reasons for this are set forth clearly in the Reverend Principal's letter.

At the present time I understand there is a debt of approximately $14,000. This undoubtedly handicaps the operation of the school which is in need of a number of improvements. It is extremely doubtful if the principal will be able to effect these improvements as long as he is handicapped by a large deficit. Whether or not this deficit is the result of higher per capita costs or because of the loss involved in the operation of rather an extensive farm I am not prepared to say. I do believe however that some assistance should be given the school to enable it to free itself of its indebtedness and I recommend that consideration be given to the request of the principal that an auditor visit the school in the near future in order that some sound basis of assistance might be arrived at.

cc: Major D.M. Mackay.
Report of fire at Lejac School - Cowbarn and silo

At 3:40 P.M. on Oct. 23rd the farm manager, Mr. J. Farrell noticed smoke coming from the loft of the barn. He gave the alarm and the workmen and boys rushed over. The cows and horses were put out. The smoke was too dense in the loft to get a hose up from the inside so a hole was chopped in the roof and the hose was inserted. Water was played on the blaze which had started near the angle of the roof and floor of the loft. Within three or four minutes flames were leaping from both ends of the loft and an intense heat had developed. It was too late to save the barn then so I ordered them to hose the adjacent buildings. The silo which was attached to the barn burned but some of its contents were saved. The staff worked admirably, one of them a Polish Veteran manned the hose in such intense heat, saving the other buildings, that water had to be thrown on his clothing to prevent them from catching on fire.

The water pressure was sufficient but a dozen streams of water would not have quenched the fire three minutes after we had an opening made to reach the flames. The pressure at first was directly from the water pump but after half an hour it started to suck mud and sand from the lake bottom so we turned it over to gravity feed from the water tank.

The loss in addition to the barn and silo included 110 tons of hay and alfalfa, 15 tons of grain, milking machine, grinding machine, two sets of harness and assorted implements. The estimated loss of feed would be approximately $3000 and $500 in equipment.

The probable cause of fire—It was either spontaneous combustion or defective wiring. I cannot be certain but I would favour defective wiring. The lighting plant had been on less than ten minutes when the smoke was noticed. The origin of the fire was in the loft in the vicinity of the fuse box. On the other hand the blaze developed so rapidly that it might suggest spontaneous combustion.

March 6, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Amnell, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

As you are aware, the barn at the Lejac Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire last summer. We have received a letter from Indian Agent Howe and also a letter from the principal with reference to supplying a new barn. The principal's letter reads as follows:

"In reply to your letter concerning the estimate for a new barn I have gone into the question with a competent builder and find that the cost of materials for a barn 36 x 60 together with cost of construction would be very close to $15,000. To keep sufficient cows milking to supply the needs of the school we would need a barn 36 x 60 as a minimum. The cost of a barn in this cold climate is higher than it would be in other parts of the Province. It would be very poor economy to build a smaller barn that would not take care of our needs. I hope that this request will be granted."

We would appreciate it if you could have your agricultural supervisor advise what size barn he considers should be erected at the Lejac school. We would also like to obtain plan of the barn that he considers is needed and an estimate of the cost.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School,
Stuart Lake Indian Agency, B.C.

Mr. Hoey's memorandum of January 21st, to which is attached the Department of Public Works' Boiler Inspector's report and the Principal's letter, all in connection with the above, has been considered and you are advised as follows:

The information submitted is along general lines, and is all but completely lacking in technical data of the nature required for making a specific recommendation.

It can be assumed, however, that the mechanical services and some items of equipment at the above are in extremely poor condition and the continued operation of some of these items of equipment could not be recommended.

It is felt that Mr. Webb should be called on to delegate one of his engineers to carry out a more detailed inspection and gather technical data along lines which we will suggest, and submit a complete report. His report will enable us to decide whether or not it will be necessary to send our Mr. Hargreaves to the school before a final and complete recommendation can be made by this Division.

Consequently, we are writing to Mr. Webb and requesting him to have a preliminary inspection carried out at once, and upon receipt of his reply, you will be further advised.

Chief Engineer.

Director,

Mr.B.F.Neary
Supt.of Welfare&Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa,Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing copies of letters concerning repairs to the heating system and plumbing at this school.

In February the Engineering Department sent an engineer to make a survey of the repairs and he told me that they would have a report ready for April. Yesterday I wired Mr. Arnell and he replied that there was no report ready from that Branch.

The engineer told me that he was recommending a stoker for the boiler and an electric pump located on the school for the main water supply. You can see from the previous correspondence that the fire fighting set up is very poor. At present the pump house at the edge of the lake is under water and we have to pump the water with a hose to the main supply tank. The main pipe from the water tank is in very poor condition; this was mentioned as an emergency repair in the inspectors report. The radiators, according to the engineer, are 75% defective.

Any Building and Repairs grant for this year should be used for these repairs especially for a stoker. The cost of wood in this district and in these times of inflationary prices is prohibitive.

Would it be possible for you to see if some action could be taken in this matter before it is too late as I don't think that we can carry on for another winter under the present conditions.

Thanking you for your kind attention in the past.

Yours sincerely,

J.P. Mulvihill
Lejac Indian Residential School
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers
Lejac, B.C.

Jan. 9th 1948

Mr. R. Howe
Indian Office
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Sir:

In reference to the Boiler Inspectors report-

The fire pump which is also the main water supply pump is out of date and in very poor repair. He recommends a new pump at the school building itself. Under the present system in case of fire we have to run a quarter of a mile to start the pump and then run another quarter of a mile in another direction to shut off the valve at the water tank. By this time the fire could be out of control.

He recommends a starter for the Diesel lighting plant, the present system is very dangerous.

He recommends emergency repairs to be done at once on the main water line at the tank.

He finds the piping and woodwork in the laundry in bad shape.

The heating system is badly in need of repair. The installation of this system twenty-five years ago could not have been done according to contract. The return pipes were placed in such a manner that it is impossible to prevent air locks. At present it is impossible to heat one wing of the building properly. The pipes in some places are paper thin, the fittings on the radiators are so badly corroded that half of them do not function. The Dunham Company of Edmonton states that the system is so antiquated that parts are no longer procurable. They suggest modernizing the system.

In view of these facts, some of an emergency nature would it not be possible to send a heating engineer to examine the system and some steps be taken to place it in working order. In view of the fire hazard I think that it should be done with the least possible delay.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that I have inspected the Machinery owned by
the DEPARTMENT of Mines and Resources (Indian Affairs Branch)
and located at Indian Residential School - Lejac, B.C.
on the 17th day of October
and have found it in the following condition:

**Fire Pumps:** Old and out of date. Worn rods, leaky glands. Recommend
Condition: a new unit and present pumps repaired sufficiently to
use in case of emergency.

**Condensate Pumps:** ----
Condition:

**Boiler Feed Pumps:** ----
Condition

**Stokers:** ----
Condition

**Electric Lighting Plants:** The 20 H.P. Diesel requires a small air
Condition: compressor and receiver for starting purposes. The
present method of slipping the belt on and off is very
dangerous.

**Laundry Machinery:** Old. Piping and woodwork failing but in fair
Condition: running condition.

**Steam Engines:** ----
Condition

**Gasoline Engines:** Four fair.

**Diesel Engines:** 1 5 - 1 model Poor
Condition: 2 9 - 1 model Fair
3 20 H.P. Vivian 2 cylinder 10KW - Good

**REMARKS:** There must be no valves between the hot water tanks and relief
valves. The present one must be removed. All the assortment of tanks
old and new, and water jackets should be dismantled and the system
modernized with a Government inspected all welded steel tank 36" Diameter
and 6 feet long with a capacity of approximately 260 Imperial gallons.
The present system of putting a boiler here and a water jacket there
and burning rubbish in any of the boilers instead of an incinerator
could easily cause a fire. The pipe between the wooden main and the
main water tank is corroded and very thin and should be replaced as an
emergency repair, and not wait for next year's estimate. A condensate
pump would be a good investment now a larger electric plant has been
installed.

"J. E. Halsall"

MEMORANDUM

OTTAWA July 8, 1948

Further to our memorandum of June 23rd with reference to the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of Mr. Unsworth's report dated June 8, 1948. This document is a twenty-eight (28) page treatise, and the author has presented a great deal of information which will take some little study to digest. Two drawings and a map showing the location of the school are attached to the report.

A preliminary analysis shows that vitally essential data necessary to make definite recommendations are lacking, and this statement is in no way intended to reflect on Mr. Unsworth's effort.

Before a recommendation calling revisions or additions to the equipment can be made, it is felt that we should await result of the Donald Inspection Company's report.

In the meantime, we will prepare an interim recommendation based on Mr. Unsworth's data with reference to the possibility of increasing the efficiency of operation of the present system and we expect to submit this within the next few days.

From a preliminary study of Mr. Unsworth's report, it can be inferred that poor attention to the operation of the mechanical services, particularly the heating equipment, is responsible to some degree for lack of heat in some parts of the building.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

MEMORANDUM

Re: Lejeu Indian Residential School,
Stuart Lake Agency, B.C.

Further to our memorandum of July 7th with reference to the report submitted by Mr. A. Unsworth of Mr. Webb's office, the following preliminary analysis is presented for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

It can be assumed from the report that the building is equipped with a Dunham Return Heating System, and that the rear section of the installation was not installed to this principle, which has resulted in an unsatisfactory distribution of heat to this area.

The report goes on to state that the ground floor of the front section of the building is satisfactorily heated, but that difficulty is experienced with the upper floors.

It is also reported that a pressure of eight ounces per square inch is carried in the boilers. This would be in order if the piping was of consistent good design and if the firing periods were not spaced too far apart. Since no mention is made of a condensation pump, it may be assumed from Mr. Unsworth's description of the system that in addition to air eliminators, return traps is used. This trap is not mentioned in the report and it is likely that when revisions are made a condensation pump will be found necessary.

On January 9th, Reverend J.P. Mulvihill, Principal of the school reported that the Edmonton office of the C.A. Dunham Company stated that the system was too antiquated to procure replacement parts, and suggested that it be modernized. The Principal also stated some of the piping was "paper thin". These points were not commented on in Unsworth's report. The report does state however, that some radiator valve handles are missing and that some valves are damaged and are in a locked position either open or closed or partially open. The radiator traps are said to be in good condition as far as can be observed. In addition to the foregoing, it is pointed out in the report that some rooms are overheated with all the radiators turned on while others are cold with some radiators turned off. This would indicate that either the valves are not easy to operate or that little or no attempt is made to operate them. It is evident from Mr. Unsworth's report that extensive alterations and replacements will be required to put this system into good operating condition.

In delivering coal to the boiler room from the outside, an old cauldron on a rope sling is used and is manned by the older boys. This operation takes place daily and results in the outside door being left open for approximately three hours.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6445, file 881-5, part 9)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
This is a source of great heat loss from the building and on occasions has caused the blow-down piping from the gauge glass on one of the boilers to freeze. It is stated that a small storage bin is being prepared to eliminate the present system of sealing.

The boilers are subjected to uneven firing and as a result a great deal of condensation forms in some parts of the system and until this is cleared by the traps and the air eliminators, steam for heating can not be satisfactorily distributed. Many other items can be cited to further explain the general unsatisfactory state of the heating system.

While there is a great deal of meticulous and detailed information in the report, some vitally essential observations are missing and lacking these data, it is not possible to definitely recommend extensive changes to the present installation.

Summing up, it can be stated that one stoker should be installed, the air eliminators removed and one condensation pump be provided. It is also likely that much of the piping will have to be replaced and some parts of the system will require redesigning. The installation is twenty five (25) years old and of a design now considered to be more or less obsolete and it can be expected that a general deterioration will have taken place.

However, until more detailed technical data is available, it is not possible to prepare a design showing the full extent of the revisions which may be necessary and it is suggested that the Donald Inspection Limited's report should be available before a commitment is made by this Division.

We are writing to the Donald Inspection Limited and requesting them to amplify certain phases of Mr. Unsworth's report and to provide this Division with the necessary technical data in order that we may prepare a recommendation.

When the Donald Inspection Limited's report is received, and analyzed, you will be further advised.

Chief Engineer.

Type of Heating:

The building is heated by two horizontal return tubular boilers of (?) 104 h.p. each. This system is the Dunham type. It is obsolete, and consists of steam traps at each radiator and a separate line for the release of the condensate by gravity to the boilers. (This is called the line, and a separate line for discharging the air from the system is called the dry line). This system does not operate satisfactorily, and appears to have been messed up so that nobody seems to know where it is.

We noticed also that the inlet valves for the steam are connected at the top of each radiator instead of at the bottom.

I suggest that every steam trap in this building be examined, as we are sure all are not functioning properly; do away with the air line and run wet return back to a receiving tank and vacuum pump, which will make this system less complicated, and still sufficient heat to make the building comfortable. You will note that this does not make very much change in the present system as the steam traps are already installed, and the only thing to be done is to disconnect the air pipes and remove them entirely; connect the steam inlets to the bottom of the radiator and run the existing wet return to the receiving tank, which is part of the vacuum pump mentioned above. The most satisfactory pump that I know of is the Skidmore pump, which is mounted on a receiving tank and which has a vacuum pump for drawing out the condensate, and a feed pump which pumps the condensate back into the boiler.

Father Mulvihill has talked about the installation of a mechanical stoker, but at the moment it would not be possible for him to get ready to put the stoker in before the cold weather is here. For one thing, the distance between the floor and the bottom of the boiler drums is not sufficient to permit stoker being installed. The only way that this could be done would be to dig a water-proof pit two feet minimum below the existing floor. By this means the combustion chambers of the boiler would be big enough to burn the amount of coal which the stoker would supply. These boilers are fired, one with coal and the other with wood. Natural draft is used.

Ventilation:

There are two large ventilators on the roof. These ventilators are piped from the various rooms, such as toilets, dormitories, etc. The main ventilators are supposed to revolve with the wind so that proper ventilation can be obtained. We found on examining these, however, that the ventilators could not turn and, probably, have not turned for years, as the wheels on which they are supposed to revolve were rusted and had evidently never been greased or oiled since they were put in. I would suggest that the existing wheels be removed and that wheels with ball-bearings be installed in their stead. With such an arrangement the wind would be able to turn the ventilators, and we are of the opinion that proper ventilation could be obtained. If this is not sufficient, then we would suggest that exhaust fans be placed in each of these ventilators which are about three feet in diameter inside. An 18" exhaust fan would be ample (1 for each ventilator).
Water Supply:

This water is pumped from Fraser Lake to an elevated tank about 2,100 feet distance from the pump to the tank. The school at which the pump connection is taken off is about 1,200 feet from the pump and 900 feet from the tank. The total head from the pump to the tank is approximately 102'. A pressure of about 40 lbs. is maintained at the school.

With regard to the statement that some of the pipes were paper thin, this, as far as we can see, only applies to two or three small pieces of pipe. These places, particularly where galvanized pipe is used, have been allowed to leak slightly and corrode. In any event, we do not think these places are numerous. The only thing to do is to replace them with black iron pipes when leaks show up.

It will be noted that the water is slightly acid.

You will note on the plans that there are two tanks which were installed for domestic hot water. These tanks are not in use, and the domestic water is heated by two water jackets and two vertical tanks. The suggestion is made that these tanks, which are now in use, should be removed from their present location and installed in the place which is now used as a coal bunker. There are also in the same place two large tanks which are not in use.

The idea is to get a larger bunker in which to store coal. As it is now, the coal is dumped just outside the boiler-house with a wooden shed covering it. This wooden shed we consider a fire hazard, and should certainly be removed. As a matter of fact, we have noticed in all the schools that wooden stacks are built in close vicinity to the school. We believe that the Department should take the necessary steps to see that this is not done in the future, and that the existing ones are removed.

The blue prints enclosed herewith show exactly how the pipe for the heating system should be installed, but, as stated previously, it has been so messed around by one and another that no one seems to know here it is.

With regard to the eliminators in the boiler room. We would say that these connections are practically as shown on the blue prints, with the exception of the fourth one from the left, which is 15" higher than the others. As stated previously all these so-called air pipes should be removed and a vacuum pump installed, when the trouble with the heating system would cease.

Please note that the pump on the edge of the lake which pumps water to the elevated tank, as heretofore mentioned, is old and should be renewed.

They have at present one 10 k.w. one 2-1/2 k.w., and one 4-1/2 k.w. generator. The small generator has a burnt-out bearing, but we understand from Father Mulvihill that a new bearing has been ordered, and as soon as it arrives it should be put in working order.

An inspection was made of this school in company with Constable W. Murdock, Local Assistant Fire Marshal.

OWNER - Dominion Government
Department of Mines and Resources.
SUPERVISION - Indian Commissioner
Occupancy - Residential Indian School
DESCRIPTION - 3 storey Brick construction

RECOMMENDATIONS

1. That first aid fire extinguishers be thoroughly checked and serviced.
2. That the main interior stairways be fully enclosed.
3. That access to the metal fire escapes be at floor level and through standard doorways.
4. That the outside fire escapes be protected from the weather. (At the time of inspection, certain of the escapes were useless owing to the heavy deposit of ice.)
5. Either properly protect or seal off the dumb waiter.
6. Install a direct means of egress from the following classrooms to the fire escapes:

   Primary
   Grade 3 and 4 classroom
   Grade 2
   Senior Classroom

This may be accomplished by partitioning off the Hallway at each end of the building and installing additional doorways from the classrooms where required to give access to the fire escape opening.

7. The present means of escape from the High Dormitory (girls) which at present is through the supervisors room, should be altered to allow a direct access to the escape.
8. That the escape facilities from the North Dormitory (girls) be increased by installing an additional fire escape to lead directly to grade.

9. That the present furnace chamber be equipped with a standard fire door and standard fire door hardware.

10. That the boiler in the Laundry room be enclosed in a standard furnace chamber.

11. Properly install the smokepipes from the heater installed in the laundry. At the present time this smokepipe passes through the floor above into a ventilator.

Respectfully submitted,

Further to our memorandum of February 24th, 1949, and to previous memoranda from Major MacKay bearing your notations in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

We have reviewed and considered the correspondence and reports received from Mr. Webb's office early last year on which Indian Affairs took no action and the Donald Inspection Company report prepared as part of their assignment last fall. Conflicting opinions as to the condition of the heating system and the proposed remedies, raise doubts regarding the technical value of the recommendations.

Mr. Unsworth's report dated June 8th, 1948, states that the piping is of good design. This is not borne out by his detailed description of the distribution system and the application of various traps and other accessories. In one instance, it is stated that "thermostatic traps are used to drip the ends of various steam mains. Such traps are not considered satisfactory for this application."

In a letter dated July 13th, 1948, to the Donald Inspection Company, we requested them to have their inspecting engineer clarify and amplify several phases of the work in connection with the heating system. Their report is along general lines and the specific questions raised in our letter, are not dealt with. However, their engineer describes the system to be "messed up so that nobody seems to know where it is".

From a study of the Unsworth and Donald Inspection Company's reports, we gather that the system is a complicated arrangement of several composite designs, and that in itself would indicate faulty distribution and unequal heating.

It is our considered opinion that the reports are inconclusive and that in spite of the amount of information received, many essential data are lacking. As a consequence, it is not possible to offer recommendations which would correct the present installation.

It can be expected however, that as the system has been installed for twenty-five years and taking into consideration that during this time, it has given a great deal of trouble, nothing short of major changes can be expected to bring about an improvement.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
It is felt that in order to make an intelligent recommendation, an officer from this Division should be sent to the school as soon as he can be spared from the office for the required time. As the situation stands at present our one heating engineer has just returned from an inspection trip of residential schools at Sioux Lookout, Saginaw, Marie and Kenora, which occupied his time for as long as his office duties permitted him to be absent from Ottawa.

As you are aware, priority projects, such as the work on the Wabasca Residential School, the Bay Lakes Residential School, and heating designs for other Indian Affairs and Parks buildings, present difficulties in assigning this officer to distant inspections at any particular time, a situation we hope to remedy as soon as additional assistance can be obtained.

The matter has been discussed with officers of the Indian Affairs Branch, who realize that the western inspections they have requested must be fitted into our programme to the best advantage.

We will endeavour to make the best arrangements we can, but we are unable at present to say just when the inspections will be carried out.

WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM OF THE LE JAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Date of Examination - January 15, 1949.

Location

Le Jac Indian Residential School is situated on the shore of Fraser Lake 3.9 miles east of the village of Fraser Lake and 3.5 miles west of Fort Fraser on the Jasper-Prince Rupert Branch of the Canadian National Railways.

Water Supply Source

Fraser Lake, the source of the school's water supply, receives water from three sources. The Stellako and Endako Rivers, which are the chief sources, flow into the lake from the west. Water from Ormonde Lake enters the north side of the lake at a point opposite the Le Jac school. The Nechako River drains the lake at its west end. Fraser Lake is approximately 12 miles long and has an average width of 1½ miles.

Description of Water System

General - the water system was installed in 1923 one year after construction of the school was completed. Water flows by gravity from the lake through a system of pipes and settling chamber to the pumphouse well and is then pumped through a main to an elevated storage tank. Water used at the school is tapped from the main and received on the first floor of the school at an average pressure of approximately 48 p.s.i.

Intake - water enters the screened intake through 207 ft. of 8-inch iron pipe and then flows through 18 ft. of 10-inch by 10-inch wooden box pipe to a timber settling chamber. The chamber is 16 ft. long, 5 ft. wide, and 8 ft. deep and is composed of two 8 ft. sections in series. After having the heavy sand particles removed by the settling chamber, the water passes through 32 ft. of 8-inch iron pipe to a concrete well located below the pumphouse. Water can rise in the well to a maximum depth of 13 ft. without flooding.

Pumphouse - the 10 ft. by 14 ft. pumphouse is of frame construction on a concrete foundation. Pumping equipment includes one 10 H.P. Fairbanks Morse horizontal gasoline engine, belt connected on each of its sides to two 3½"×6" stroke, double-acting, horizontal Fairbanks Morse pumps which are rated to deliver a total of 100 gallons per minute under a pressure of 100 p.s.i. Actual pressure during pumping varies between 66 and 73 p.s.i. depending on the elevation of the water in the storage tank.

Storage Tank - Water is received at the elevated storage tank through 2,100 ft. of 4-inch wood stave main. The tank is supported by 21 ft. timber bents which sit on concrete pedestals that rise 2 ft. above the ground's surface. A 4-inch galvanized iron pipe connects the storage tank with the main. The tank is 16 ft. deep and 16 ft. in diameter, giving a storage capacity of 20,000 gallons.
Conclusions and Recommendations

1. The Fraser Lake water supply appears to be of good chemical quality.

2. The negative results obtained from the bacteriological analysis cannot be interpreted as meaning that the water supply is safe at all times of the year.

3. The Stellacoo and Endeko Rivers are open to contamination but some natural purification by storage takes place since the supply intake is situated 5½ miles from the rivers' entrance to the lake.

4. It seems improbable that the current caused by the water's entrance to and exit from the lake would be strong enough to carry any appreciable amount of pollution to the school's intake.

5. A regular shore line on the intake side of the lake aids in preventing the formation of stagnant water areas.

6. Animals should be kept from grazing on the school's pasture land at the edge of the lake to minimize chance pollution from surface drainage.

7. Bathing in the lake should not be allowed above a point located at least ½ mile from the downstream side of the intake.

8. It is recommended that arrangements be made for taking water samples from the intake and water supply during the summer months for bacteriological analysis. The results of these will indicate the necessity or otherwise of disinfection of the supply.

Field Work by Mr. M.J. Stewart, Asst. Sanitary Engineer.

A.H. Perry
Supervising Engineer

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School, British Columbia.

In connection with Major Mackay's request contained in his memorandum to you of March 10th last to have an officer from this Division visit the above school and advise if new electrical equipment requisitioned by Superintendent Howe is essential, you are advised as follows:
