MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, July 5, 1949.

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School,
British Columbia.

On his recent inspection trip through British Columbia and Alberta, our heating engineer visited the above and surveyed the mechanical services.

The school is heated by a two pipe gravity low pressure vapour steam heating system, powered by two horizontal return tubular brick set boilers, each rated at 104 horsepower. These boilers are over 26 years old. Up till recently wood had been the principal fuel used, but some coal was burned last year which resulted in a slight improvement in the efficiency of the heating system. The use of coal even though hand fired, naturally brought about a somewhat steadier pressure.

The condensation is returned by gravity through a system of wet and dry return piping and is admitted to the boilers through combination air eliminators and boiler return trap. This combination is badly rusted and is not in satisfactory operating condition.

The piping connections at the boilers is of extremely poor design, resulting in a contribution to faulty circulation and unsteady water-line. The boiler shells, independently suspended by steel members, are in fair condition, but the brick work is in an exceptionally poor state of repair and the top covering of the exposed part of the shells, is practically non-existent.

The piping distribution system is more or less correctly laid out, to what is known as a vapour system, but is not the correct design for a building of this size. There are no traps at the end of the mains and branch mains. In lieu of traps, these mains are dripped at the end by means of bleeder connections into the wet return and in some cases by dry returns overhead back to the boiler return trap and it is this phase of the design which is responsible for a major part of the faulty circulation. In addition, run-out connections from risers to radiators and from mains and risers to first floor radiators, are all badly graded. This is due in part to the settlement of the building through the passage of time. These improperly graded run-outs and spring pieces form pockets where the condensation and air collect and circulation to the radiators is very difficult to obtain. When the pressure is raised in the boilers to overcome these conditions, short circuiting results, and the steam, taking the line of least resistance, travels back to the boilers through the return piping instead of passing through the radiators as it should.

To complete the picture, it is judged that 90% of the radiator traps and valves are defective, which also contributes to short circuiting in many areas.

Generally speaking the building is in a fairly good state of repair and appears to be well looked after especially on the inside.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
The domestic hot water service is inadequate to meet the needs of the pupils and staff. Two small jacket heaters and two domestic hot water storage tanks connected in series have capacities which are far short of the requirements.

It can be stated however, that in spite of previous pessimistic reports submitted in the past, the heating and domestic hot water systems are by no means so far gone that satisfactory revisions are impossible short of a complete re-installation. All the previous reports having been considered together with the survey carried out by our officer, would lead to the following recommendations.

(a) Install some additional radiation where required.

(b) Re-grade mains where necessary and re-grade all laterals and spring pieces to risers and radiators throughout the building.

(c) Provide new float and thermostatic traps on ends of all steam mains and connect to return mains as will be detailed on drawing.

(d) Provide new horizontal condensation pump to replace old and worn out boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.

(e) Make necessary piping revision at the boiler as will be detailed on drawing.

(f) Provide one new steel portable fire box type low pressure steam heating boiler and make repairs to brick setting on remaining existing boiler.

(g) Install new stoker (at present in storage at the school) under new boiler.

(h) Provide new domestic hot water storage tank of 900 gal. capacity.

(i) Provide new indirect steam fed heater consisting of cast iron shell and copper tubes with self contained regulating valve.

(j) In addition to the above, it will likely be found that some sections of piping will have to be replaced as the work is in progress. This can only be determined when the work actually gets under way. Owing to the nature of this work and to the somewhat isolated location of this school, it is expected that contractors would be willing to submit a firm tender. It is felt that this particular work should be awarded on the basis of cost plus, which in our opinion, would result in a more favourable cost to the Department than a firm tender.

The foregoing recommendations can not be closely estimated, until the layout has been prepared, but it is felt that the sum of $12,000.00 to $15,000.00 will be required.

Upon receiving approval and the instructions to proceed with the layout, we will prepare plans and specifications and call for tenders.

Re: Barn - Lejac Residential School

This Office has endeavoured for the past eighteen months to obtain a reasonable tender on the construction of a new barn at Lejac.

Plans and specifications were received from Beatty Brothers Limited, which were forwarded to the only contractor in the area interested, Messrs. Bovil & Hann, Contractors, Smithers, B.C., who submitted a tender which was forwarded to the Department with my letter of September 23rd, 1948, wherein the estimated total cost of the barn was approximately $16,000.00. This tender was not accepted due to no funds having been appropriated for this purpose for the 1948-49 fiscal year.

Having been advised that $12,000.00 had been appropriated for the 1949-50 fiscal year, tenders were again called for in the area; two were received, one from Bovil & Hann, Smithers, B.C., for approximately $19,000.00, and one from A.P. Anderson, Prince George, B.C., for approximately $20,100.00. The above figures include the cost of the steel barn equipment which was to be supplied by the Department at a cost of approximately $1,500.00. The above contractors have since advised that they could not start construction until 1950.

The B. & A. Power and Construction Company, of Vancouver, were asked to submit a tender, which has just been received, amounting to $23,522.00, plus the cost of the steel equipment.

As the above tenders are exceedingly high and as it is
essential that construction be completed as soon as possible, the following alternative proposal is submitted for your consideration and approval:

(1) Convert present piggery into a dairy barn and build silo.
(2) Convert present implement shed into a granary.
(3) Build new piggery.
(4) Build new implement shed.

Our Regional Supervisor, Mr. W.J. McGregor, investigated and discussed this proposal on the ground with Father J.P. Mulvihill and Superintendent Howe and he definitely recommends that it be carried out.

I am enclosing herewith Superintendent Howe's letter of August 25th, 1949, and attached tenders and plans in duplicate submitted by Father J.P. Mulvihill, for remodelling the present piggery for use as a dairy barn, constructing new piggery, remodelling present implement shed for use as a granary and building new implement shed as well as a new silo, for the overall sum of $8,500.00, excluding steel barn equipment, which it is estimated will cost approximately $1,800.00, total expenditure of $10,300.00.

Father J.P. Mulvihill is the Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School at Lejac, a practical man, and we are confident that he can secure the necessary carpenters and labourers locally and that the construction can be carried out successfully, under the supervision of Superintendent R. Howe.

The Finning Tractor & Equipment Company, of Vancouver, are sending their Prince George representative to Lejac immediately. He will submit a complete quotation on the steel equipment and hardware which will be forwarded to the Department when received.

It is recommended that each of the enclosed tenders totalling $8,500.00 be approved and that $1,800.00 be set aside to cover the cost of the steel equipment. As little time remains for the completion of the concrete work prior to frost, I would appreciate receiving your instructions by wire as soon as possible.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, October 15, 1949.

Memorandum

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School,
Lejac, British Columbia.

Further to our memorandum of July 5th in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

Plans and specifications covering the necessary extensive revisions and additions to the mechanical services have been prepared and competitive tenders secured through the medium of W.S. Arnell, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C. Of the three firms invited to bid on this work, only two were in a position to submit a price. The prices received are as follows:

Mitchell Brothers Limited,
1990 Burrard Street,
Vancouver, B.C. .................. $26,923.00

Barr and Anderson Limited,
1060 Homer Street,
Vancouver, B.C. .................. $28,300.00

Each of these firm tenders was accompanied by a security deposit for ten per cent (10%) of the tender price in accordance with the requirements of the tendering documents.

These prices are considerably higher than our rough estimate of $12,000.00 to $15,000.00 mentioned in our memorandum of July 5th. After the complete analysis of field notes and inspection data had been made, it became apparent that more extensive operations would be involved than originally anticipated, if the mechanical services were to be brought up to acceptable standards.

This added work, together with the remote location of the school, which involves unusual transportation difficulties, would in a large measure account for the difference between our estimate and the lowest tender of $26,923.00.

It is felt that if the Indian Affairs Branch decide to proceed with this work, consideration should be given to Mitchell Brothers Limited tender. If advised that this work is to be undertaken, we will prepare a Memorandum to Council and Contract Agreements and will arrange to have operations started.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Lejac Residential School

We are informed that the Reliance Lumber Company, Vancouver, and presumably other firms, have been requested by the Purchasing Agent to tender on the supply of 11,000 sq. ft. of 3/4" Rock Wool Insulation, for the Lejac School.

This matter has already been the subject of correspondence with you, reference my letter of September 16th, and Mr. Phelan's letter of November 3rd. With my letter I submitted quotations on 2" Rock Wool, which is the thickness asked for by the Principal and, as a matter of fact, we are not aware that there is such a thing as 3/4" insulating batts; these come in 2" and 3" sizes and in British Columbia, there is very little demand for the 3" size.

We have been informed of previous instances where the Purchasing Agent requested Vancouver firms to quote on materials which were already covered by quotations to this Office, which quotations were forwarded to you, and it appears to me that we are wasting not only our time but the time of local firms if the quotations secured by us are not acceptable to the Purchasing Agent, as a basis for the issuance of a Purchase Order. I should like to be advised if in future we should secure quotations on materials, the ordering of which must necessarily be referred to the Purchasing Agent, or if we should leave it to him to call for tenders. In the case of the Insulation for the Lejac School, I have suggested to the Reliance Lumber Company that they quote to the Purchasing Agent on 3" Battts.

for W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Lejac Indian Residential School

Dear Father Mulvihill:

As you are probably aware, I have been absent from my office inspecting schools and am just now beginning to answer some of the accumulated correspondence.

I was sorry to read of the difficulties encountered in securing tenders for the erection of the barn and Father Birch spoke to me about your tender. (Since withdrawn due to the lateness of the season.)

When I last discussed this matter with him, I suggested that we prepare a bill of materials for the building which you intend to erect. This requisition could be submitted through Mr. Arnell to here and we could get the Departmental Purchasing Agent to work on it immediately. I presume that all of the materials, with possibly the exception of the cement, could be stored at your school until spring permits erection of the barn.

We will include an amount for labour in our next year's Estimates so that, with the materials on hand, work can begin early in May or as soon as weather conditions permit.

I would suggest the hiring of a foreman carpenter as was done by Father O'Grady at Kamloops. With the materials already on hand, the building could then be erected without delays.

......2
during the spring and summer.

I am sending copies of this letter to both Mr. Howe and Mr. Arneil so that they will be aware of our plans. In fact, we would like to expend as much as possible of the funds available for this project before the end of the fiscal year and naturally the best way to do this is by the purchase of all materials.

In fact we could order the cement for delivery by the 20th of March and still be within this year's vote.

I understand that the Lands and Development Services Branch have just made a submission to Council recommending the acceptance of the lowest tender submitted by the firms bidding on the revisions and additions to the plumbing and heating at this school. This amounts to very close to $27,000.00 and should put your school in good condition. With regard to the other items, I believe that Purchase Orders have been issued for the potato peeler, the two laundry washers and the commercial range.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

Thank you for your letter of Nov. 5th. I did not know that you were absent on an inspection tour until I received your letter.

Yesterday I was speaking to Mr. Howe and he suggested that I should write to you and have this point clarified. The materials to be purchased—Are they for the plan that I suggested in my tender or for a new barn? I think that it would be a great deal cheaper to build according to the plan I submitted and also it would be more servicable to the school.

I had already drawn up a list of materials for this project and if it is the mind of the Department then I will submit this list to Mr. Howe and discuss the matter with him. I am firmly convinced that this plan of building will be of greater service to the school.

Memorandum

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School,
Lejac, British Columbia.

In connection with Major MacKay's memorandum of December 7th bearing your marginal notation of the 8th instant you are advised as follows:

Mr. Webb brought up the question of re-locating the boilers in his letter of November 25th and we replied on December 2nd fully explaining our reasons for locating the new boilers in the position shown on our drawings. It would appear that Mr. Webb's response to our letter has been directed to Major MacKay through Mr. Arneil.

We have wired Mr. Webb pointing out that boiler manufacturers' drawings must be submitted for approval by this office before the units are shipped. We have specified the type and capacity of the boilers required for this work and any proposed changes should of course be submitted to this Division for final analysis and approval before being proceeded with.

An examination of the original building plans shows that insufficient fuel storage and boiler room space was provided in the original design and there is evidence that a change was made at a later date in an attempt to improve the situation. Owing to the character of the building as now constituted, major basic changes to the structure involving an unwarrantable sum of money would be necessary in order to bring the fuel storage facilities up to a reasonable capacity.

Therefore it is highly important from our viewpoint that no encroachment of the boiler room itself be made without approval from this Division which can only be given following a full consideration of all features involved.

When the boiler manufacturer's drawings have been received and analyzed, we will be in a position to judge whether or not it will be possible to re-locate these units closer to the rear wall of the boiler room. At such time you will be further advised.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

allocation of space by the school officers to purposes other

taken to restore the original fuel storage room to its pro-
per use. We must state emphatically that we do not approve
of any encroachment on the boiler room space.

clear in front of the boilers to permit withdrawal of the

Major MacKay, Director

Heating Installation
Lejac Indian Residential School,
Stuart Lake Agency, British Columbia.

Attached are copies of correspondence exchanged between officers of the Indian Affairs Branch in British Columbia, together with a copy of Indian Commissioner Arneil's covering letter to the Chief of our Engineering and Construction Service, regarding action taken by the school principal, with the contractor now carrying out work on the heating system at the above residential school.

Under date of the 3rd January last, a letter was written to District Engineer Webb, copies of which were sent to Commissioner Arneil and yourself, containing comment regarding difficulties created by school officers when unauthorized changes are made in diverting space to purposes other than intended.

You will note by the latest correspondence that the principal has taken it on himself to make changes to the boiler room layout. Comment by our field officers indicates that these changes are an attempt to locate coal storage space nearer to the boilers than at present, which is necessitated by the previous diversion of the coal storage space provided in the original design, to use as a root cellar.
On numerous occasions it has been found that school principals undertake structural changes in schools under their control from funds at their disposal, without referring the matter to Ottawa for approval. These changes are often poorly conceived and present obstacles to the economical solution of technical problems which may arise at a later date.

Commissioner Arneil has taken action at the Lejac school which he has probably reported to you, but it is of prime importance that school principals be restrained from carrying out structural revisions before such matters have been studied by responsible technical officers, thus avoiding infractions of the National Building Code, and preventing the creation of fire and other hazards.

The matter is drawn to your attention for your consideration and comment.

Director.

I am writing to Father Mulvihill informing him that he has exceeded his authority in this regard and that the changes presently being made to the boiler room by the school management must be discontinued until his proposals are submitted to us in detail and approved but in the meantime I feel that it would only be reasonable to consider Mitchell Brothers contract as satisfactorily completed.

I might mention that the Rev. Principal notified us by wire on March 23rd that the 13 valves and traps referred to in Mr. Martin's memorandum were installed.

Memorandum to Mr. Arneil:

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School Inspection Report

Attached is a memorandum by Mr. R.M. Martin based on his recent inspection of the mechanical services revision at the above mentioned school now being carried out by Mitchell Brothers of Vancouver.

You will note that there are four parts of the work that are not completed. Three of these, namely, 1st, patching of the holes in the wall, 2nd, painting of hot water storage tank and heater, 3rd, closing of opening in wall of boiler room, should have been completed.

As on a previous inspection, Mr. Martin had left instruction with the Contractor to have these repairs made as they fall within the scope of the Contract. However, the Principal of the institution had, on his own responsibility, made arrangements with the Contractor that he would look after this work. Although there is probably nothing serious in this arrangement, it is certainly a practice that should be discouraged. This type of interference prevents the inspecting engineer from making a concise report on final inspection and leads to general dissatisfaction and misunderstanding between the inspector and the Contractor.

You will also note that the Principal of the school is carrying out alterations to the boiler room. I am not aware on what authority these alterations are being made, but in this particular instance the alteration will interfere with removal of the coal stoker worm provided the coal bin, which is now being built, is full or only partially full of coal.

As a general rule it would not be advisable for the local school authority to make changes or alterations to these buildings without first referring the subject to some authority on such matters.

Enc. (Inspection Report) (Sgd) Norman P. Robinson

Memorandum to Mr. Robinson:

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School
Inspection Report

On March 21 I made an inspection of the heating installations put in by Mitchell Brothers Limited.

This contract is now complete except for the following:

(1) Patching of holes in walls.
(2) Painting of hot water storage tank and heater.
(3) Closing of opening in wall of boiler room.
(4) Installation of 13 valves and traps in the sleeping quarters.

An arrangement has been made between the contractor and the Father in charge of the school for the Father to complete the first three items.

The 13 valves and traps were to be installed on March 22 and the Father will notify this office by wire when this is done.

In addition to the contract, the following extra work has been satisfactorily completed.

(1) Installing 8" main steam valve.
(2) Installing by-pass system on condensation pump.
(3) Installing condensation drip line in laundry corridor.

At the present time the Father is carrying out alterations in the boiler room. A coal bin is being constructed with concrete walls. There is a wall being constructed just clear of the hopper of the stoker with an opening for withdrawal of the worm. If the bin is full of coal, difficulty would be encountered removing the worm. It is the intention of the Father to close the existing boiler room entrance on the outside wall. I do not think it wise to do this.

(Sgd) R.M. Martin, B.Sc.

Dear Mr. Neary:

In further reference to your telegram of April 20th, I wish to quote the last paragraph of Mr. Arneil's letter of March 27th. "I NOTE ALSO FROM MR. MARTIN'S REPORT THAT YOU ARE CARRYING OUT CERTAIN ALTERATIONS IN THE BOILER ROOM. THE LEJAC SCHOOL IS A DOMINION GOVERNMENT BUILDING AND NO ALTERATIONS MAY BE MADE THERETO WITHOUT SPECIFIC AUTHORITY FROM THE DEPARTMENT. I HAVE THEREFORE TO REQUEST THAT YOU DISCONTINUE THE WORK AND IN THE MEANTIME PROVIDE COMPLETE DETAILS OF THE CHANGES YOU PROPOSE IN ORDER THAT THEY MAY BE REVIEWED BY OUR ENGINEERING STAFF."

I replied to this letter on March 28th stating, "IN YOUR LAST PARAGRAPH YOU ADVISE ME TO DISCONTINUE THE WORK ON THE COAL BIN. THAT WORK HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND I AM ENCLOSING A SKETCH OF THE WORK DONE. THERE HAS BEEN NO CHANGES MADE TO THE FOUNDATIONS NOR HAVE ANY PARTITIONS BEEN REMOVED. THERE HAD TO BE SOME PROVISION MADE FOR COAL STORAGE, SO FAR IT HAS BEEN PILED OUTSIDE IN THE YARD OPEN TO THE WEATHER AND A GREAT EYESORE."

I do not know what report Mr. Martin made to the Department but it seems to me to be greatly exaggerated from all the excitement it is causing. I waited two years from the time Mr. Unsworth made his recommendations for changes in the heating system until the work was started. If I had to wait two years more for a simple matter of a coal bin it would be ridiculous.

According to Mr. Arneil's letter no alterations can be made without specific authority from the Department. Does this mean that a floor cannot be repaired or a wall painted without specific authority from the Department? I brought Major Davies down a few weeks ago to look at the coal bin and explain the matter to Mr. Arneil. He did not think that any grave breach of Red Tape had been made. I had intended to do some painting this summer and patch up walls where the plaster has fallen off. The cement floors in the basement need repairing but if this work has to be delayed by the Engineering Department there is little hope of having it done this year.

The work on the coal bin has been completed three weeks ago so there is nothing much I can do at present except await further developments.

Yours very truly,

J.P. Mulvihill

Dear Sir:

I am submitting a request for a new Lighting Plant for this school.

We have a 10 K.W. Plant at present but during the winter the Heating plant was changed and a 3 H.P. motor was installed on the stoker and a 3/4 H.P. on the return pump; this has placed too heavy a load on our present plant.

With the present installations and the number of lights in the building we need an 18 K.W. Plant to prevent overloading.

This building was inspected by an electrical engineer from the Department on November 11th, 1949, and his report will confirm this necessity. In fact he told me that he would not let them install the stoker with the present Plant but this did not take effect and the contractors installed the stoker.

This engineer investigated the possibility of a Power Line passing through this part of the country, but I have been informed by the Provincial Member of Parliament that this will not be in effect for some years yet.

The present Plant is a Vivian Diesel installment with 10 K.W. DC rating. For the most economical operation this plant can be used during the daytime when the load is light and an 18 K.W. plant operated at night when the load is too heavy for this smaller unit. Therefore, I think that a Vivian Plant would be the most suitable for the 18 K.W. unit. However the electrical engineer has all the data on this school and will be able to recommend the proper installment.

Yours truly,

"J. P. MULVIHILL"

June 30th, 1938

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Wanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Sir,

Herewith I beg to submit the report for the quarter ending June 31st, 1938.

HEALTH. The General health of the children has been very good. There have been two or three cases of active T.B. and the children were sent home at once.

Trachoma. We were worried about the possible spread of this disease among the children but the report of Dr. Wahl was very encouraging. He finds a marked improvement among the children and feels that if the present treatment is continued, most of the children will leave the school practically cured.

Discipline. Apart from the restlessness at the approach of the holiday season, we are well pleased with the conduct of the children. There have been no runaways and the children seem quite contented.

VISITS OF PARENTS. In previous reports I have called attention to the necessity of stricter regulations to control the visits of the parents and other Indians to the school. The Department approved of the regulations submitted for this purpose and I am glad to be able to report that since the regulations have been in force, we have had no trouble at all. All that is needed now in order to have complete control of this point, is a house near the school for Indians coming from a long distance during the winter. At present there is no building available except the railway station and I do not think that the C.N.R. officials take very kindly to the use of the station for this purpose.

Classrooms. The program of studies has been followed closely and we hope that the Inspector will find that the matter covered has been well learned by the children. One of the great difficulties we have is to get the children to speak correct English. The majority of the children come to the School without knowing any English at all and the result is that the English spoken during recreation is so poor that the standard is lowered for the whole School. I believe that it might be well to suggest to the Inspector certain modification in the amount of matter to be covered during the school term, so that more time could be devoted to the teaching of correct speech. No doubt the Inspector has met this problem before and would be able to make practical suggestions.

Manual Training. We have not done as much this year in this Department as we had hoped. We only had about a dozen big boys altogether and by the time they had been divided up for the various works, it was extremely difficult to give the Manual Training Instructor sufficient time with each group. However, of the twelve big boys at least nine were able to learn a great deal about practical carpentry, cement and concrete work etc. Two of the boys have become quite proficient in this work.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
DOMESTIC SCIENCE. As the girls are more numerous it has been easier to divide them into fairly large groups and the work has been very successful. To the usual program two new items have been added, the preparation of wool from our own sheep and the knitting of Indian woolen sweaters from natural wool prepared at the school. This is just a beginning. The girls are also learning to make mattresses from Sheep wool. This year we have had for this purpose about 250lbs of wool and as our flock increases, we hope to develop this branch of the training given to the girls.

Improvements. We are expecting the final approval of the specifications for the new piggery and this work will be started as soon as the permission is given.

We are planning this year to make the grounds as attractive as possible. A nicely decorated gate has been built on the Highway and we are hoping to be able to plant trees and shrubbery from the Highway to the School. A great deal of fencing is being done and every effort will be made this summer to make the whole farm and the outbuilding look as neat as possible. Each year there seems to be an increase in the number of visitors during the summer months and the School is looked upon by many as a kind of experimental farm.

Agriculture. A week ago it looked as if our crops were going to be a complete failure. We had no rain for ninety days and nothing was growing except the Alfalfa and it was beginning to turn yellow. However, we had a good heavy rain four days ago and things look more hopeful. It is doubtful if we shall be able to thresh any grain as the season is now very late and the oats and wheat are barely out of the ground. But we shall have plenty of green feed if we get a little more moisture.

The experience we have had this spring has naturally turned our thoughts to irrigation. We had already begun to build and install the necessary flumes to irrigate the potatoes when the rain came. Everyone agrees that in most years we could almost double our Alfalfa and other crops, if we had irrigation. The official statistics give the annual rainfall for the district as 12 inches, which means that the school is situated in what is known as the semi-arid part of British Columbia. This means that no matter how well we may prepare the land in the spring or no matter how good the seed may be, we cannot under normal conditions expect sufficient rain at the right time to guarantee a good crop. Our land is easy to irrigate, we have a huge lake at our front door, we have the water tank necessary for irrigation but we lack a pumping system sufficiently economical for the purpose. If it were possible to change our present pumping system and install a modern diesel engine, it would be easy for us to irrigate the whole farm at a very reasonable cost. Our present main costs $50 an hour to pump 100 American gallons a minute and I am told that the modern diesel engine could do the same or even better work for £1.00 a day. It would be a big saving even in the cost of supplying the water required for the daily use of the School.

The various branches of the farm work are doing well. The Dairy, the poultry, the sheep and beef cattle are all helping to provide the school with good wholesome food and even the bees (we have twelve hives) are contributing their share. We have started in a small way to develop an interest in rabbits so that the children, when they leave school, will have seen the many ways in which they can help to provide food and recreation for themselves later on.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.

Ottawa,
September 14, 1928.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 30th instant you may make the necessary arrangements to place Elizabeth and Dick Johnson in the Lejac Indian Residential School. The application forms for these children reached the Department on September 1 and quite possibly you have already received our letter of that date.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

H. Reed, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Telegraph Creek, B. C.
Sir,

Upon my recent visit to the Atlin end of the Agency, the affairs of the Davey Johnson Family was again gone into and found to be even worse than ever. Drink has been the ruination of this family.

In this family however are two children: Elizabeth age 10 years, very fine little girl, and clean - and her brother Dick age 7 years, also well worth saving. The older daughter has now two illegitimates, and the other children (three) are under school age.

His Lordship Bishop Bunoz O.M.I. has requested that the above two children be sent to LEJACK Indian School, and as the case is so drastic, your agent wishes to back up his application. These youngsters must be sent out of that district if more trouble is to be avoided as they grow up, and Lejack seems to be the only place to send them.

Therefore, their papers were made out and signed by Dr Roth, M.D. of Atlin, who was warned to take every effort to find traces of T.B. He states they are clear and can be sent to school. The papers were then forwarded to His Lordship Bishop Bunoz, requesting him to forward direct to The Department, two copies and the third copy to be sent to this Office.

This copy has not yet arrived, no doubt His Lordship has not yet returned from his Yukon Inspection, but the other two copies might have arrived in Ottawa by now.

This is to request that authority be allowed at once to move these youngsters out of Atlin and to Lejack School, and that all necessary paper routine be caught up with at a later date. The reason for such hurry being that the Fall is fast approaching and transportation is shutting down.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

Sylvester Patrick, an Indian of the Fort Fraser Reserve, has approached me with the request that I take his two young children into the school. The children are Elizabeth, 6 years old, and Holland, about 5 years old.

As you are aware, Amelia Patrick, the mother of the children in question, died last May; so there is no one in the family who can give proper care to the children. Sylvester, of course, has to work and is away from home the greater part of the time.

However, I told Sylvester that I would refer the case to you. At the present time we have 169 children residing at the school, $ over our per capita allowance; and there is the probability that this number will be increased by the return to the school of some of the children who did not come back after the holidays.

Nevertheless, I would be willing to accept these two children if the Department will give me some monetary assistance in taking care of them. Otherwise it would mean depriving other children, perhaps, who have a legal right to be at the school, of some of the things that they need.

So, if you think it well to recommend the admission of these children to the Department, will you do your best to persuade them to allow me an extra grant to take care of them?

With kindest personal regards, I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant with reference to the pupilage at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

I note your recommendation that the pupilage be increased to 175. No provision was made in the current year's appropriation for this increase nor was it found possible to provide grant for an increased pupilage at this school in our estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40. However, if you consider that the two children of Sylvester Patrick require institutional care you may place them in the school provided the Principal has accommodation for them and is willing to accept them. Supernumerary grant will be allowed for these two children from the date of their admission to the end of June, 1939. At that time in view of pupils being discharged it should be possible to absorb them among the regular grant earning pupils. In the event of the children entering the school a special note should be made on the December, March and June returns quoting the date and file number of this letter authorizing payment of supernumerary grant for them.

With special reference to the second paragraph of your letter I am writing to Indian Agent Mortimer advising him that in future he should not apply for admission of children to the Lejac Residential School until he has first written to the Principal and ascertained if accommodation can be provided for them. This procedure will permit the Principal to first provide for the children from the Stuart Lake Agency.

Sir:

I wish to bring the attention of the Department to the condition of affairs which exists at the Lejac Indian Residential School this year in so far as the number of pupils attending the school is concerned.

At present the school authorities receive a grant for 160 children while at the present time there are 168 there and several more who should be there and whose parents have asked that they be accepted. The point that I wish to bring to your attention is the system which exists at present whereby the Department authorises Agents of other Agencies to send children from their Agencies to school and which I know nothing about until after they arrive. I refer particularly to six or eight children whose applications for admission were sent in by Agent Mortimer and approved by the Department, and again in the case of Agent Reed of the Stikine Agency having received authority direct from the Department to send two children from his Agency down here.

The point is that these children from other Agencies come to school and owing to the fact that the school is not receiving a grant for a large enough number of the children of this Agency are being allowed, of necessity, to remain at home with their parents or guardians when they really should be at the school. The school authorities are not against taking a certain number of children over and above the number that they are given a grant for but it is unreasonable to expect them to take too many, especially as crowding is likely to result.

Personally I am of the opinion that we could handle comfortably at the school a maximum number of pupils totaling 175 and I feel that of that number the Department would only be doing the right thing to the school authorities, as well as the children themselves, if you could see your way clear to raise the per capita grant from 160 to 165. It is either a case of doing that or else not allowing children from other Agencies to go to the school unless the time arrives when this Agency cannot keep up the quota required.

Having this in mind I wish to attach hereto a letter received from the Rev. Principal which I trust you will find self explanatory. The two children of Sylvester Patrick mentioned in the Principal's letter should really be at the school, although one of them is only five years old. There was T.B. in this family on both of the parent's sides and while these children are perfectly healthy with no sign of T.B. it will only be a matter of time until they are affected unless properly cared for, and this cannot be done by their father alone and there are no suitable relatives on the father's side to look after them and certainly none on the mother's side.

I would be greatly obliged if you would kindly give this question consideration and advise me fully on the subject. At the moment I am not taking any action in so far as these two children, mentioned by the Rev. Principal, are concerned.

Your obedient servant,

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

In the Agency's Monthly Report for February, the sad case of the Davey Johnson Family of Atlin B.C. was mentioned. Therein is mentioned the fact that it was necessary to send two of their children to Lejack Industrial School in the Fall of 1936—which turned out to be the correct action, to have been taken. Since then the mother with her twins have died, leaving the distracted father Davey Johnson with his eldest daughter and her three illegitimate children, and also the above very nice little lad—on his hands to maintain.

Therefore His Lordship Bishop Coudert, O.M.I., was asked if he would accept the lad at Lejack School, so that he could be there with his brother and sister—providing of course that the Doctor in Atlin can pass the lad as entirely free from T.B., etc. His Lordship's reply was as follows:

"In regard to Davey Johnson's boy, I think for the time being it is certainly a wise move to have the said child sent to the Lejack School, providing his admittance is arranged by you with the Department, as I have nothing to say in the matter. I know that actually the school is crowded to capacity with an excess number of more than ten children; the Principal however will always be glad to harbour—even free of charge, such orphans as the one you are referring to."

The Principal of the Lejack was also written to, explaining the matter to which no reply has as yet been received, but there is little doubt but what room will be made for the above lad, if required.

Therefore may the necessary authority be granted for the above lad to be removed from Atlin B.C. and placed within the Lejack Industrial School. Such movement will take place when some white person from Atlin B.C. will be able to see the lad down to Prince Rupert, on their way to Vancouver B.C. for business purposes.

The necessary papers will of course have their due attention over the movement.

I am,

Sir,

Sir,

In the Fall of 1932, whilst in Atlin B.C. an Indian youngster was found about the Town that was not on our Census. Going into this matter it was found that an Indian Telegraph Jack had brought him in by way of the Taku River - from Juneau, S.E. Alaska, with any authority what-so-ever.

An effort was made to send him back to Juneau, but the lad about 10 years old, was taken out into the bush for the winter. Later the Jack Family somehow or another managed to have Father A Allard then in charge of Atlin R.C. Missions, send the lad to Lejack School.

As far as is known no papers have ever been signed to cover this lad, as he was a U.S.A Citizen. Much correspondence has passed over the matter with the Lejack School Authorities, and no definite reply has been received as to if the papers were ever signed or not. Might this matter be looked into.

To day the School Authorities wish to return this lad to Atlin, and it is thought that any other place would be better than to that point. Really he should be returned to Juneau, where he would be able to follow up his training received at Lejack school. There will be nothing for him to do in Atlin and the fur trapping has nearly gone, with no more traplines for him to take up.

In the meanwhile the Mission have been requested to not return this Lad, until such a time as can be arranged. Mrs Telegraph Jack of Atlin claims to be the lad's Aunt, but it is thought he is an illegitimate, however there is a lot of drinking going on with the Jack Family, and no place for this lad to return to.

I am,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. Mines & Resources.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 22nd ultimo, in which you submit for departmental consideration the case of a boy now enrolled at the Lejac Indian Residential School, who formerly entered Canada from Juneau, Alaska.

It is exceedingly difficult to state exactly what action should be taken with respect to the boy at this date. If he really came from Juneau, he should have been returned to that point at the time he was enrolled at the Lejac school. The school authorities should be prepared to accept some responsibility at this date for placing him in a reputable home.

If the school authorities know of no such home, would it be possible for you to communicate with a missionary or an Indian administrator in Alaska, asking if the relatives of the boy at Juneau would be prepared to accept him. If the Juneau authorities are not prepared to receive the boy, it will be somewhat difficult for you to ignore the claims of Mrs. Telegraph Jack for the custody of this boy. You should exercise your own best judgment in respect to the matter. Any recommendation you care to make will be acceptable to the Department.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant with reference to James Oliver.

It is noted that this boy has been admitted to the Lejac residential school on the understanding that the mother will pay for his maintenance. In this connection I would point out that even though she does this there are numerous free services such as medical attention and books that he will receive. In addition no child can be admitted to a residential school without the Department's approval.

We have already considered the case of this boy and he is not considered one of our wards. Therefore this Department is not responsible for his education. If principals were allowed to admit children who are not eligible as grant-earning pupils on the condition that those interested would pay for their maintenance it would have the effect of using accommodation in residential schools that is necessary for recognized Indian children.

I feel certain that if you show this letter to the Principal of the Lejac residential school he will appreciate our position in the matter and have the boy returned to his mother immediately.

Yours truly,

J.H.F. Lacey, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, File No. 163-1-10 regarding James Oliver, the son of Mrs. Antoine J. Antoine of the Stony Creek Band of Indians. I have informed the Rev. Father A.R. Simpson, Principal of the Indian Residential School, at Lejac, of your ruling in the matter. He has informed me that before your reply was received the mother of the boy took him to the Indian School and agreed to pay for his maintenance there out of her monthly allowance from the boy's father. He states that the mother of the boy wishes to have him brought up in a Roman Catholic School and not in the Public School. He also points out that the boy would have to walk three miles to school at the Public School from his home on the Stony Creek Indian Reserve, which he considers too far for a boy of seven years.

Owing to the fact that the Rev. Principal is asking for an additional grant to cover children already at the school over and above the number paid Per Capita Grant and that the father of the boy wishes to have him brought up in the Public School; I would not recommend that he be admitted to the Lejac Residential School but would respectfully request your further instructions in this case.

Your obedient servant,

Jas. H.F. Lacey,
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

re - Application for Admission to Residential School.

I enclose an application for admission of Francis Isadore, age 12, to the Lejac Indian Residential School.

This boy came before the Juvenile Court Judge in Smithers on August 11th on a charge of theft. Sentence was reserved pending the Department's consideration of the case. If approval for the admission of the boy to Lejac be granted and he remain there for three or more years, the Juvenile Court Judge would give sentence accordingly.

I would strongly recommend the application be approved in this case. The home environment of this boy is by no means good. The mother is serving sentence in Oakalla at the present time. The father, although industrious, has no control over his wife or family and trouble has been caused on the Moricetown Reserve - to which they belong - by one member or another.

I feel sure the boy's future will be greatly benefitted by his removal from his home surroundings at this time.

May I ask if the Department will forward me a reply by air mail, and oblige?

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The fare amounted to $2-45. The boy was in the hospital for a few days and then returned to the School, his fare back being paid by the hospital authorities. Bishop Coudert has requested a refund of the $2-45 paid by him for the boy's ticket. Your Reverence,

Upon arrival here, for a winter inspection, the question of sending little Peter Deve Johnson, age 6, to the Lejack Residential School was taken up with Father Heyser O.M.I., who is now resident in the local R.C. Mission of these parts.

We both felt that he should go down and join his brother and sister at Lejack. The doctor was seen, and the lad has been passed as fit, having been under observation for over 6 months now.

The above authorities cover this movement, and all fares etc have been arranged, except that from Prince Rupert to Lejack, the cost of which is not known here. A warrant for this can be obtained from the Indian Office in Prince Rupert, which of course would be chargeable to this agency. A very nice lad—Jnr Murray Junr is going to Prince Rupert also, and he has been paid some small amount to care for this indian lad en route down. Lejack has been requested to advise you of this movement, when they accepted this entrance to Lejack, in yesterday's "wire".

It is hoped that this meets with your wishes. No doubt Father De Heyser will be writing you also, on this matter, and also regarding the recent troubles of this Camp. With all the Season's Greetings for good health etc.

I am Sir,

His LORDSHIP.

Yours sincerely,

Bishop Bunn, O.M.I.

PRINCE RUPERT, B.C.

Harper Reed Indian Agent.
ATLIN, B.C.
January 28th, 1940.

Sir,

Re: Indian Lad, Peter JOHNSON, Atlin.

I beg to submit attached a copy of a letter directed to His Lordship Bishop Bumez, O.M.I., of Prince Rupert B.C., in connection with sending the above Indian lad to the Lejac Residential School, under the above authorities. The lad leaves here tomorrow morning.

Father O. DeKeyser, O.M.I., now here in Residence, with your Agent have gone into this matter very carefully, and despite the expenses involved, we shall in the long run save expenses by moving this very nice little lad, away from this rather rough mining camp of Atlin B.C.

Over Xmas and the New Year, much trouble with the Indians has again come about, which will be reported in due course, and it is hoped that within a few days more, it will be possible to have all the Indians out again on their trap-grounds - and away from this Townsite.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.
